item.title: Feral File #019 ‚Äî Doppelganger ü™ê
item.description: Feral File #019 ‚Äî Doppelganger ü™ê
item.ns0:encoded:
Doppelganger
Announcing a new group show that crosses and fuses notions of digital and physical self, curated by Chris Coleman.
Exhibition Opening:
August 25, 2022
14:00 UTC (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
See the
Price List
for complete details.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on August 25 at 14:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúMetamultimouse‚Äù by Matthew Plummer-Fern√°ndez. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce Doppelganger, an exhibition featuring works by Matthew Plummer-Fern√°ndez, Jeremy Bailey, Rodell Warner, Sophie Kahn, Rujunko Pugh (Syberweerd), Laleh Mehran, and LaTurbo Avedon.
Collectors of these editions will be eligible to receive a ‚Äúdoppelganger,‚Äù in the form of a 3D printed counterpart of the work from Shapeways. Feral File will contact collectors within two weeks of the auction closing for fulfillment. Shipping and printing costs are included in the price of the work. Note that all orders will take
6-8 weeks
to deliver.
Curator Chris Coleman on the exhibition:
‚ÄúThe works in Doppelganger explore identities that cross and fuse boundaries. Each of the artists are exploring how they define the self, especially in connection with technological change. Each of the works will exist in digital and physical forms, the same and yet also very different because of the materiality or lack thereof. Perhaps each format will bring collectors a different understanding of the ideas, empowered by touch instead of channeling through a cursor. Hopefully balance and reconciliation can be found between the physical and digital, letting us celebrate both and also consider what control means in the rapids of our swift life streams.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
‚ÄúRelic Viewports‚Äù by LaTurbo Avedon. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Relic Viewports
As avatar artist LaTurbo Avedon continues to expand the simulated world of the Materia System, here it is visualized through a series of Viewports. These objects operate as windows and mirrors of immaterial space, rendering perspectives of the Materia System through their specific forms. Materia is a mythos emerging from the long term interactions and connections with LaTurbo in their worlds. For this exhibition, Avedon has created the work ‚ÄúRelic Viewports,‚Äù which is tethered to a limited series of physical objects, offered as tangible records of the System‚Äôs early development.
Metamultimouse (Pictured Above)
Matthew Plummer-Fern√°ndez‚Äôs ‚ÄúMetamultimouse‚Äù is a digital and physical figurine that is both one and many at the same time, embodying the paradox of distributed ownership for hybrid digital-physical artworks. In digital form, the work exists as an animation made with CGI and AI software, morphing between various computer-generated patinas. In physical form, each copy manifests as one of its possible versions. ‚ÄúMetamultimouse‚Äù continues the artist‚Äôs inquiry into changing attitudes towards copyright, especially in relation to 3D printing, often using derivatives of Mickey Mouse to exacerbate copyright conundrums. In this latest installment, a smoothed-out version of Mickey rendered free from copyright now has to grapple with NFT culture, where popular characters are expected to be both unique and discernibly similar, often using code to create variants and randomize their distribution.
‚ÄúFFF (Famous Fractional Face)‚Äú by Jeremy Bailey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File
FFF (Famous Fractional Face)
The acronym PFP refers to ‚Äúpicture for proof‚Äù or ‚Äúprofile picture.‚Äù PFP NFTs emerged as a ubiquitous format from projects like CryptoPunks where thousands of digital avatars are randomly generated as unique 1/1 NFTs. Famous New Media Artist Jeremy Bailey is a living digital avatar, but unlike PFPs, his identity is fixed and unique. How might we all benefit from this emerging asset class that relies on variation without diluting Bailey‚Äôs famously consistent identity? The solution is simple: by dividing himself into 100 unique slices or ‚Äòcoins,‚Äô many more collectors can own a unique share of his total self. Each coin will be available as a real physical coin referencing a cross section of Famous New Media Artist Jeremy Bailey‚Äôs head. Every collector will also get access to a digital augmented reality (AR) model of his complete head for their reference and enjoyment.
About Feral File
Feral File is where artists, collectors, and curators convene to co-create a new paradigm for digital art. We commission curated exhibitions of file-based artwork, and partner with artists and institutions to establish transparent protocols for exhibiting and collecting. Evolving from the art gallery and digital publishing models, we are borrowing the best traits of each to inform a new kind of art space. Feral File works in tandem with a community of technologists, new media artists, and curators to redefine and frame a sustainable model for digital experimentation.
PRESS CONTACT
Eileen Skyers
Gallery Director, Feral File
eileen@feralfile.com

item.title: +GRAPH sale closes in 3 hours
item.description: +GRAPH sale closes in 3 hours
item.ns0:encoded:
+GRAPH, curated by Casey Reas, is closing in 3 hours
Time is running out to collect¬†your favorite sets from Feral File's latest¬†exhibition,
+GRAPH
!¬†Collecting ends in 3 hours at 15:59¬†UTC+0.
+GRAPH
is¬†an exhibition of software art and plotter drawings by Licia He, Joanie Lemercier, Aleksandra Jovaniƒá, James Merrill, Iskra Velitchkova, and Julien Gachadoat. It is¬†curated by Casey Reas.
Collecting essentials
Twenty-two sets of 6 unique artworks available
Reserve Set Price: 2.1 ETH
Every set comes with a set of software artworks and a set of physical drawings, plotted and signed by the artists in their studios.
The 24-hour highest-bid auction ends on November 17 at 15:59 UTC. Any bid placed within the last 5 minutes extends the auction window for another 10 minutes.
A few things to note:
Credit card bids are processed by Stripe. You may experience faster bids with ETH.
If you are outbid, bids placed with ETH will be refunded immediately, while credit card refunds will take up to 10 minutes to process after the tx outbid is confirmed on the blockchain.
VIEW SETS
In the words of Casey Reas: ‚ÄúEach of the six artists in +GRAPH created generative software that is capable of making limitless new drawings, and has transformed 30 of these variations into physical works using a plotter machine. Every plotter drawing in this exhibition is a 1/1 artwork, meaning only one will ever be created. Along with each of these unique drawings, there are millions of other compositions that are embedded in the original code.‚Äù
Please visit our
exhibition walkthrough
for an in-depth conversation with the curator and¬†artists in +GRAPH.
VIEW VIDEO
Watch the +GRAPH Exhibition Notes video with Casey, Licia, Aleksandra, Joanie, Iskra, Julien, and James.

item.ns0:encoded:
View Now: Patterns of Flow / ÊµÅ„Çå„ÅÆ„Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥
Feral File is pleased to announce the opening of
ÊµÅ„Çå„ÅÆ„Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥ / Patterns of Flow
, an exhibition celebrating a new generation of Japanese artists working with code.
Channeling the experimental aesthetics of computer art pioneer Hiroshi Kawano,
Patterns of Flow
explores the power of generative systems to capture a world in flux. Led by prominent artist and creative coder Shunsuke Takawo ‚Äî who inspires the Processing community in Japan with daily coding ‚Äî all ten featured artists are united by their love of code as a creative medium.
VIEW EXHIBITION
View IRL and Online
ÊµÅ„Çå„ÅÆ„Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥ / Patterns of Flow
represents Feral File‚Äôs first hybrid exhibition. It will be displayed at NEORT++ in Tokyo from September 25 ‚Äì October 6, 2024 and online at Feral File from September 25 ‚Äì October 15, 2024.
Curated by Yusuke Shono and Alex Estorick, the exhibition is a collaboration with
Massage Magazine
and
Right Click Save
. It is accompanied by a special essay by critic and curator Jasia Reichardt. The exhibition features works by 10 contemporary artists inspired by computer art pioneer Hiroshi Kawano, whose work is featured courtesy of Tama Art University Museum. The exhibition is made possible thanks to the support of Noriaki Nakata and NEORT++ with research by artist and academic Hasaqui Yamanobe.
Not in Tokyo, but still want to experience
Patterns of Flow
IRL? Feral File invites you to download our app (for
iOS
and
Android
) to bring the exhibition into your home. For a limited time, our new ‚ÄúDaily‚Äù feature will let you display one artwork from the exhibition every day on your smart TV, so you can become immersed in these phenomenal works wherever you are in the world.
EXPLORE THE EXHIBITION
Changes, Cycles, and Shapes in Between #1
by mole^3
Collecting Guide
Collecting will open in two phases.
Phase 1: Wednesday September 25 - Wednesday October 2
Collect now in person at NEORT++
Purchase an exhibition set (all 10 works) for
.575¬†ETH by emailing
lauren@feralfile.com
. To custom-curate your set, include the number from each series that you would like to collect in your email.
Phase 2: Wednesday October 2 - Wednesday October 15
Collect individual artworks from the exhibition (from remaining available artworks) at
feralfile.com
Exciting update: Feral File will no longer require collectors to purchase exhibition sets by series number. Instead, collectors can now pick their preferred artworks by artist and assemble their own set. Or, collectors can acquire individual artworks starting October 2.
EXPLORE THE EXHIBITION
Sea of Code #1
by Kazuhiro Tanimoto
Get the Full Picture: How Japanese Artists are Shaping Generative Art
‚ÄúIt was a philosopher Hiroshi Kawano (1925-2012) who pioneered computer art in Japan, expressed through his writings on computational aesthetics and early experiments with an OKITAC 5090A computer at the University of Tokyo‚Ä¶ Thanks to the NFT as well as the global profile of the Processing community, a new generation of Japanese creative coders is currently elaborating on the aesthetic universe once imagined by Kawano.‚Äù
‚Äî Curators Yusuke Shono and Alex Estorick
READ MORE
Share
Share
Forward

item.title: Announcing Chain Reaction, an exhibition curated by Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
item.description: Announcing Chain Reaction, an exhibition curated by Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing Chain Reaction, an exhibition curated by
Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
‚ÄúSeed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124‚Äù by Amelia Winger-Bearskin. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Join us on Discord
Feral File
is pleased to announce Chain Reaction, an exhibition of inventive experimental gestures that set into motion a course of action. Curated by Christiane Paul, curator of digital art at the Whitney Museum, Chain Reaction features tokenized visual artworks by eight renowned artists, each of which emphasize the concept, process, and capacity to trigger events.
Featuring new artworks from:
Amelia Winger-Bearskin
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Ira Greenberg
and Marina Zurkow
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Alfredo Salazar-Caro
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Stephanie Dinkins
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Sara Ludy
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Jennifer and Kevin McCoy
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 93, with each edition priced at $100 USD.
Exhibition Opening:
March 7, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
on March 7 at 14:00 UTC (9am EST) for a conversation between the curator and the artists.
Curator Christiane Paul on Chain Reaction:
‚ÄúChain Reaction strives to underscore the inherent connections between the blockchain as a list of data blocks facilitating the recording of transactions and tracking of assets, and the generative social, aesthetic, and environmental contexts and networks in which these assets are embedded. The works in this exhibition explore their existence as ‚Äòtokens‚Äô beyond just being technological records of a transaction: they function as catalysts in precipitating events or actions, from environmental preservation and sustainability of a creative process to aesthetic choices. NFTs are functionally defined by their non-fungible status. They are capable of encapsulating and proving ownership of digital artworks that are often characterized by malleable, generative, untraceable, or imperceptible qualities. The artworks in Chain Reaction highlight the porous boundaries between NFTs as a mechanism for unique identification, on the one hand, and as a common ‚Äòkeepsake‚Äô of a social contract and commitment, or collective action, on the other.‚Äù
Preview of Selected Artworks:
Public View / Private View by Jennifer and Kevin McCoy
Jennifer and Kevin McCoy‚Äôs ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù opens up the artistic process of creation ‚Äî usually driven by artists‚Äô concepts and aesthetic choices ‚Äî to a community of donors and art supporters connected to the McCoys. Collectors receive an animated composite of a series of images that are based on pictures submitted to the McCoys by a group of donors of the artists‚Äô work who thereby participated in the NFT‚Äôs creation process. ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù is based on the McCoys‚Äô 2018 project ‚ÄúPublic Key / Private Key‚Äù for which they produced a short 16mm film, donated it to the Whitney Museum‚Äôs Special Collection, then issued 50 Ethereum ERC-721 tokens to represent the right to be named as one of the ‚Äúdonors of record‚Äù for the film and selected 50 donors from an open call for applications. The tokens were allowed to freely circulate for a period of six months. For ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View,‚Äù the McCoys asked these 50 donors of record to submit an image personally meaningful to them and created a coded interpretation of it. The interpretations of the donors‚Äô 50 images were then combined into the animation that collectors can purchase as NFT. The 50 donors receive an ink-on-paper version of the image. While ‚ÄúPublic Key / Private Key‚Äù made the donation process accessible to a wider public, ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù involves the donors in the creation process itself. Using the blockchain as authentication and distribution mechanism, the two projects form a creative chain that not only binds the artists as makers to an expanding community of interested supporters, but makes the nodes along the way a formal part of the work itself. In ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù the blockchain anchors the creation, distribution, and archiving process of the artwork.
Seed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124 by Amelia Winger-Bearskin (Image Above)
Amelia Winger-Bearskin‚Äôs ‚ÄúSeed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124‚Äù involves collectors in her ongoing artwork inspired by seeds and their caretakers. The NFT edition consists of an image of an identical pile of corn seeds that have been colored by the artist in 100 variations, wrapping the seeds in hand-drawn patterns. As still life, the seed piles imagine what the future seven generations of corn seeds might look like, suggesting textile and beading patterns or more alien mutations. Corn is one of the ‚Äúthree sisters‚Äù (corn, beans, and squash) according to the knowledge of the Haudenausaunee people. (Winger-Bearskin is an enrolled member of the Seneca-Cayuga Nation of Oklahoma, which is part of the Haudenosaunee confederacy.) The three sisters are grown together, giving nutrients, shade, and support. The ‚Äúseven generations‚Äù concept reminds us that our current knowledge is built on that of the seven generations before us, and that we must make good decisions for our descendants seven generations in the future.
Each of the seed pile variations has a unique DLITE (Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time) number, riffing on the Terrestrial Dynamical Time that NASA uses as a timestamp for celestial voyages.¬†The future that Winger-Bearskin imagines for seeds is inspired in equal parts by several sources: the celestial storytelling of the Seneca-Cayuga; NASA‚Äôs Project Artemis; as well as the work of her colleagues‚Äô Robert Ferl and Anna-Lisa Paul, plant molecular biologists who lead a team focused on growing plants in space at the University of Florida Space Plant Lab.
Along with the NFT, collectors receive a participation contract and access to the Seed Protocol website, asking¬† them to contribute to the larger seed protocol project. They will receive regular updates on all online and in-person events related to Seed Protocol project 2023-2024. Collectors will also play an active role in shaping the project by agreeing to make contributions: engaging with a local seed bank or heirloom seed society in their area and uploading information about the organization to Amelia Winger-Bearskin‚Äôs Seed Bank Directory or engaging with one of the seed groups with whom the artist is working.
‚ÄúThe Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater‚Äù by Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
The Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater by Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow
Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater‚Äù allows collectors to purchase an oyster, a unique NFT in the digital ocean. While the outsides of the oyster shells are similar, each of the 100 oysters in the edition is unique. The insides are structured through custom generative software according to four categories, each based on an aspect of oyster physiology, purpose, and lore: Oyster Engineer (plumbing, cleaning, sifting, filtering machinery); Oyster Artist (creating beauty, wonder, inspiration, well-being); Oyster Sex Symbol (aphrodisiacal and sex-changing); and Oyster Kin (with other animals, including humans who ‚Äúfarm‚Äù and eat them). The artists used AI to generate the oyster elements and backgrounds; embedded across the four categories are fifteen unique surprises, with varying degrees of rarity.
Along with their oyster, collectors receive a unique password that gives them access to the OysterCraftReef website, where they see their NFT come together with the other collected oysters to form a visual reef. As a collective structure, the oyster reef supports real-world projects such as oyster reef cultivation, conservation, and awareness work. After no more than 90 days after the birth of the reef, collectors will vote on distributing the funds generated through their purchase to three different groups supporting oyster reef conservation, which has been identified by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) as a priority. The project title, ‚ÄúThe Dorises,‚Äù alludes to Doris, a sea goddess in Greek mythology. Doris was one of the 3000 Oceanids, daughters of the Titans Oceanus and Tethys, and represents the fertility of the ocean. Her name connects the two words¬†D√¥ron, meaning ‚Äúgift‚Äù or ‚Äúabundance,‚Äù and¬†Z√¥ros, meaning the ‚Äúpure‚Äù and ‚Äúunmixed,‚Äù often used to describe fresh water.
Exhibition Opening:
March 7, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.

item.title: Announcing FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
item.description: Announcing FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
Join the Discord Conversation
Feral File
is pleased to announce FeralVerse, an exhibition that explores the myriad ways in which words and image intertwine. Curated by
theVERSEverse
, a collective of poets, artists, and technologists interested in the creative potential for poetry on the blockchain, FeralVerse is the first exhibition of verse on Feral File. It includes 10 new works, each of which is a collaboration between a writer and an artist and each offered as an edition of 50.
Featuring new artworks from:
Victoria Chang
x
Alexandra Crouwers
Lillian Yvonne Bertram
x
Dina Chang
P. Scott Cunningham
x
Connie Bakshi
John James
x
Solim√°n L√≥pez
Seth Bockley
x
Helena Sarin
Denise Duhamel
x
Diane Drubay
Ana
Mar√≠a
Caballero
x
Nancy Baker-Cahill
Kalen Iwamoto
x
Julien Silvano
Sasha Stiles
x
Nathaniel Stern
Marci Calabretta Cancio-Bello
x
Gretta Louw
In true literary form, FeralVerse will be initially offered as an anthology to collectors: for the first 72 hours, all 10 of the artworks in the exhibition will be sold together in sets for $1,000 USD. Collectors of the full set will receive an exclusive edition of a poem written by VERSA, theVERSEverse's emergent AI poet, trained on the corpus of poems published by this literary gallery. This poem was seeded using words from the poems in FeralVerse.
Any sets remaining after 72 hours will be broken into individual editions, with each edition priced at $100 USD, until April 16 at 14:00 UTC +0.
Exhibition Opening:
April 6, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Please join us for a
Twitter Spaces
on¬†April 6 at 15:00 UTC+0 (11am EST)¬†for a conversation between the curator and the artists.
Curators Sasha Stiles, Kalen Iwamoto, and Ana Mar√≠a Caballero (theVERSEverse) on FeralVerse:
‚ÄúOur Feral File offering ‚Äî the first exhibition of verse on this platform ‚Äî is planted here as a seed for the poetry journal of the future, in which authorial imagination is unbounded, language and art exist in symbiosis, and every contributor is a vital force in a literary ecosystem in which connection to verse can lead to collection.
In celebration of both National Poetry Month and Earth Month, the texts published here as non-fungible Tezos tokens ‚Äì each a collaborative performance between writers and artists at the avant-garde of web3 poetry, including some of the planet‚Äôs most renowned voices ‚Äì reflect diverse perspectives, aesthetics, and approaches to the worlds around us and inside us, always in flux. Every work invites its reader to step into a reality augmented through the art of poetry, and to engage deeply with the untamed universe of possibilities for writers on (and off) the blockchain.‚Äù
About theVERSEverse:
Launched in November 2021, theVERSEverse is a collective of critically acclaimed poets, writers, artists, and creative technologists working on and off the blockchain to unlock the literary potential of web3. Through hybrid events, community outreach, and partnerships, theVERSEverse is creating new opportunities for writers and reshaping the future of literature.
Preview of Selected Artworks:
‚ÄúSpring So Uneasy‚Äù by Lillian-Yvonne Bertram x Dina Chang. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
Spring So Uneasy by Lillian-Yvonne Bertram x Dina Chang
‚ÄúSpring So Uneasy‚Äù is a collaboration between poet Lillian-Yvonne Bertram and artist Dina Chang, in which Chang‚Äôs visuals provide a stunning photographic take on Bertram‚Äôs poem ‚ÄúThe Body Deformed by Tidal Forces.‚Äù The poem is a muscular lyrical meditation on the physics of tidal forces that simultaneously create solidity and changes of season through rotation and gravitational push/pull and threaten destruction when the same forces of these rotating celestial bodies are brought into too close a contact to sustain their individual integrities. The same phenomenon, Bertram suggests, literally and figuratively applies to earth-bound human bodies and the ways people too are bound to an ungodly planet spinning ferociously through the cosmos.
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù by Seth Bockley x Helena Sarin. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù by Seth Bockley x Helena Sarin
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù is part of Seth Bockley‚Äôs Nature Speaks! series. This initiative, created through the poet‚Äôs position as director of creative engagement for Sovereign Nature Initiative, a web3 tech/theory/art collective, imagines giving human voice to nonhuman experiences, while recognizing the impossibility of fully translating those experiences. Helena Sarin‚Äôs visual rendering pays homage to the hackberry seed itself, the wood of the tree, its germination, pulsating, becoming, and the smile and energy with which the poet delivers the poem.
‚ÄúFuturum Febris‚Äù by Denise Duhamel x Diane Drubay. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
Futurum Febris by Denise Duhamel x Diane Drubay
‚ÄúFuturum Febris,‚Äù fruit of the collaboration between the poet Denise Duhamel and visual artist Diane Drubay, takes us on a journey towards a distressing transcendence. The planet becomes a metaphor for the memories and thoughts of the narrator of ‚ÄúPilgrims,‚Äù Duhamel‚Äôs poem. Like a path that accompanies the text, going from the naivety of youth to the realization of a conflicting system, the exploration of the two planets invites us to travel towards a feverish future.
The visual piece is composed of an excerpt from Duhamel‚Äôs poem ‚ÄúPilgrims,‚Äù encircling the planets like a blue guiding thread. The two rotating 3D objects are covered with photographs of interference colors captured in the sky. One is calming and peaceful, creating a meditative state and a moment of harmony. The second is heated and alarming, causing a sense of fascination and panic at the same time. Drubay uses psycho-active colors and the feeling of total isolation to heighten the senses and embrace new ideas and perspectives.
This work plays with a descriptive narrative that takes the viewer/reader into a scene of changing emotions and states, calling for transformation by creating true impact.
Exhibition Opening:
April 6, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later

item.title: Announcing LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
item.description: Announcing LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
‚ÄúLMG4.PCX‚Äù by Lee Mullican. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Join the Discord Conversation
Feral File
is pleased to announce LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works by Lee Mullican (1919-1998), a renowned painter and pioneer of digital art. An institutionally recognized painter with works in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, among others, Mullican started making digital art in 1986, at the age of 66. Curated by Anika Meier in collaboration with Cole Root, director of the Estate of Lee Mullican, this exhibition features 12 of Mullican‚Äôs digital works, each artwork will be released as an edition of 20.
The exhibition will be sold initially through 20 sets featuring an edition of all 12 artworks for $2,400. Sets will be sold for the first 24 hours; any remaining sets will then be broken up into individual editions¬†priced at $200 USD.
Exhibition Opening:
March 23, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Please join us for a Twitter Spaces conversation between curator Anika Meier, Cole Root, director of the Estate of Lee Mullican,¬†Alex Estorick,¬†writer and editor-in-chief of Right Click Save,¬†and Susanne P√§ch, wife of Herbert W. Franke.
March 23, 14:00 UTC+0:
OPENING LEEMULLICAN.PCX
Twitter Space
with Anika Meier, Cole Root,¬†Alex Estorick, and Susanne P√§ch
Curator Anika Meier on LEEMULLICAN.PCX:
‚ÄúAs a pioneer of computer art, Lee Mullican has devoted his life to finding new ways to create images. He embraced new technologies and tools of the day. In the fall of¬†1986, Lee Mullican participated in UCLA‚Äôs Advanced Design Research Center‚Äôs Program for Technology in the Arts. The program allowed the then¬†66-year-old Mullican to start exploring the digital realm.
The exhibition LeeMullican.PCX presents 12 NFTs that demonstrate the artist‚Äôs relentless experimentation. Mullican is an institutionally recognized painter, he is in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, among others. He skillfully used his knowledge of painterly techniques as a guide when he began working with computers and found common ground with his own style of painting and the chance made possible by the computer.‚Äù
About Lee Mullican:
Lee Mullican was born in 1919 in Chickasha, Oklahoma and died in Los Angeles in 1998. Upon his graduation from the Kansas City Art Institute in 1942, Mullican was drafted into the army, serving four years as a topographical draftsman before moving to San Francisco in 1946.
After winning a prestigious Guggenheim Fellowship in 1959, he spent a year painting in Rome before returning to Los Angeles where he joined the UCLA Art Department in 1961, keeping his position for nearly 30 years. He divided the later part of his life between his homes in Los Angeles and Taos, traveling internationally and co-organizing exhibitions at UCLA. A retrospective spanning 50 years of the artist‚Äôs work was organized by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2005.
Mullican is in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, New York; the San Francisco Museum of Art; the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles; and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, among others.
Exhibition Opening:
March 23, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later

item.title: Announcing Material Wonderland, Artist Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition
item.description: Announcing Material Wonderland, Artist Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing Material Wonderland, Artist Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition
‚ÄúMaterial World Knight" from "The Great Adventure of Material World,‚Äù by Lu Yang, courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
,
Vellum LA
, and
Fabricatorz Foundation
are pleased to announce Material Wonderland, the first exhibition of NFT works by Chinese multimedia artist Lu Yang, presented physically at Vellum LA and online on Feral File from February 16-March 5, 2023. The exhibition is co-curated by Alice Scope, curator of Vellum LA, and Barry Threw, executive and artistic director of San Francisco-based cultural incubator Gray Area.
Feral File Exhibition Opening:
February 16, 2023
14:00 UTC (6am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Physical exhibition at Vellum LA:
February 16-March 5
Vellum LA, 7673 Melrose Ave
Los Angeles, CA 90046
Gallery hours: Thursday‚ÄìSunday 1PM‚Äì6PM
Please join us for the opening reception at Vellum LA on Thursday, February 16th from 6‚Äì9pm PST. RSVP here:
https://bit.ly/luyangsoloshow
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Join us on Discord
About the show:
Material Wonderland includes eight new NFT works minted on Ethereum, which will be available to purchase through Feral File. Also shown at Vellum LA will be works available as non-NFT digital files: two full-length video works exploring the game world as well as a massive video triptych of ‚ÄúMaterial World Knight,‚Äù presenting genome-edited human beings, human-machine composites with powered exoskeleton, and robots on an immersive 600 sq ft panoramic LED wall for Vellum LA‚Äôs opening reception.
The NFT works in the series are video loops rendered from within Lu Yang‚Äôs 2019 computer game, ‚ÄúThe Great Adventure of Material World,‚Äù first shown at the 2018 Shanghai Biennale. The game is initially experienced as a standard Japanese anime role-playing computer game, where players embody the Material World Knight as they complete quests and battle enemies together with other characters drawn from the artist‚Äôs earlier works, while growing in power and abilities. However, over the course of ten stages players undergo multiple identity transformations as they move beyond tropes of popular manga culture to explore the control of identity liberated from the rigid confines of nationality, gender, and sexuality.
Material Wonderland is set in dialogue with the LACMA‚Äôs Coded: Art Enters the Computer Age, 1952‚Äì1982, open from February 12th, which explores how the rise of computer technology, together with its emergence in popular consciousness, impacted the making of art in the age of the mainframe.
About Lu Yang
Lu Yang (b.1984 China, based in Tokyo, Japan) creates fantastical, often painful and shocking images which represent a blend of religion, philosophy, neuroscience, psychology and modern technology, as well as references to real life forms and structures of natural and religious origin. Lu Yang‚Äôs output spans gaming engines, 3D-animated films, video game installations, holograms, motion capture performances, virtual reality and software manipulation. The artist also collaborates with acclaimed scientists, psychologists, performers, designers, experimental composers, music producers, robotics companies and pop stars.
Yang‚Äôs work has been shown in major exhibitions at the UCCA, Centre Pompidou, ICA London, Mus√©e d‚Äôart Contemporain Lyon, Momentum Berlin, MAXXI National Museum of XXI Arts, and the Asia Society NY Art Triennial. He has also participated in numerous Biennales such as: Shanghai Biennale, (2018 and 2012), Athens Biennale (2018), Liverpool Biennial (2016), Montreal International Digital Art Biennial (2016), and Fukuoka Asian Art Triennale (2014). Lu Yang was selected for the Chinese Pavilion at the 2015 Venice Biennale and has featured new work in The Milk of Dreams exhibition at the 2022 Venice Biennale.
Feral File Exhibition Opening:
February 16, 2023
14:00 UTC (6am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Physical exhibition at Vellum LA:
February 16-March 5
Vellum LA, 7673 Melrose Ave
Los Angeles, CA 90046
Gallery hours: Thursday‚ÄìSunday 1PM‚Äì6PM

item.title: Announcing Peer to Peer, an Exhibition in Partnership with the Buffalo AKG Art Museum
item.description: Announcing Peer to Peer, an Exhibition in Partnership with the Buffalo AKG Art Museum
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing Peer to Peer, an Exhibition in Partnership with the Buffalo AKG Art Museum
Organized by Buffalo AKG Curator and digital art scholar Dr. Tina Rivers Ryan,
Peer to Peer
is the first survey of the leading artists engaged with blockchains presented by an American museum. The exhibition stages exchanges between these artists and their historical ‚Äúpeers‚Äù in the Buffalo AKG‚Äôs iconic collection of modern and contemporary art, highlighting the continued relevance of the historical ‚Äúpeers‚Äù and the contributions of the emerging ‚Äúpeers‚Äù to art‚Äôs expanding network of ideas.
Half the proceeds from the sales will benefit the museum, which reopens in 2023 with a state-of-the-art gallery dedicated to media art and a hands-on digital technology lab.
Exhibition Opens November 21, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York , 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting Opens November 29, 2022
22:00 UTC+0 (5pm New York, 7pm S√£o Paulo, 11pm Berlin, 6am Shanghai)
Auctions End¬†December 2, 2022
22:00 UTC+0 (5pm New York, 7pm S√£o Paulo, 11pm Berlin, 6am Shanghai)
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
Full collecting details will be announced next week.
Join us on Discord
and Twitter Spaces for our first live conversation between exhibition artists and AKG Curator Dr. Tina Rivers Ryan on November 21 at 16:00 UTC.
Monday, November 21, 16:00 UTC+0 (11am EST):
FIRST PEER TO PEER TWITTER SPACE
on blockchains and the metaverse with:
LaTurbo Avedon, Simon Denny, Sarah Friend, Rhea Myers
Wednesday, November 23, 16:00 UTC+0 (11am EST):
SECOND PEER TO PEER TWITTER SPACE
on figuration in digital art with: Mitchell Chan, Auriea Harvey, Amir Fallah, Osinachi, Sarah Zucker
Sunday, November 27, 16:00 UTC+0 (11am EST):
THIRD PEER TO PEER TWITTER SPACE
on abstraction/AI/generative art with: Entangled Others, Casey Reas, Anne Spalter, Itzel Yard
If you will be in Miami for Art Week, please join the AKG team at the Peer to Peer
launch party
on November 29 at the Mondrian South Beach. VIP tickets are $250 and benefit the museum; a limited number of public tickets will be released soon, depending on availability.
Peer to Peer features 13 new artworks from:
LaTurbo Avedon
Mitchell F. Chan
Entangled Others
(Sofia Crespo and Feileacan McCormick)
Simon Denny
Amir H. Fallah
Sarah Friend
Auriea Harvey
Rhea Myers
Osinachi
Casey Reas
Anne Spalter
Itzel Yard
(aka Ix Shells)
Sarah Zucker
About the exhibition:
The exhibition therefore celebrates both the continued relevance of the historical ‚Äúpeers‚Äù and the contributions of the new ‚Äúpeers‚Äù to art‚Äôs expanding network of ideas.
From its founding in 1862, the Buffalo AKG has been committed to defining artistic movements as they emerge, including those born from dialogues with technologies such as photography and video.
Peer to Peer
continues this legacy into the present, while reconsidering the role of museums in a decentralized art world. As digital technologies increasingly influence every aspect of our lives, museums have an opportunity ‚Äî and responsibility ‚Äî to amplify the voices of artists who are creatively and critically exploring the aesthetic potentials and social consequences of these powerful new tools.
Peer to Peer
presents 13 new works produced with a variety of technologies, from Artificial Intelligence to 3D modeling, and ranging in format from videos and GIFs to PDFs, websites, software applications, and smart contracts. While technologically experimental, the works also speak to ‚Äî and transform ‚Äî themes explored by artists over the last two centuries, including the relationship between abstraction and figuration, the creativity of the unconscious mind, and the definition of art as a conceptual system.
We look forward to seeing you at the opening on Feral File and in Miami.

item.title: Announcing Two Major Exhibitions Celebrating Two Years of Feral File
item.description: Announcing Two Major Exhibitions Celebrating Two Years of Feral File
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing Two Major Exhibitions Celebrating Two Years of Feral File
Feral File is pleased to announce two exhibitions that get at the heart of Feral File‚Äôs work over the last two years:
The Experiment
and
Feral File 1.0
.
To celebrate the launch of Feral File 2.0 ‚Äî which comprises a refreshed look, a rework of our exhibition program, and a new way to collect works ‚Äî these two exhibitions pay homage to the ‚Äúexperiment‚Äù that started it all, and the amazing roster of artists we‚Äôve had the privilege of collaborating with thus far.
Exhibition opening:
June 28, 2023
14:00 UTC+0
(7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
More about The Experiment
In 2019, Casey REAS, Rick Silva, Addie Wagenknecht, and artist duo exonemo (SEMBO Kensuke and AKAIWA Yae) invited a group of artists to bring one editioned artwork to swap with each other over the course of a week. The experiment was called a2p, short for artist-to-peer network, and it became the basis for the structure and ethos of Feral File. Now, over two years since Feral File launched, The Experiment brings a2p back into focus, with Feral File‚Äôs first non-collectable exhibition.
The Experiment features works from:
Alan Butler, Andrew Benson, Auriea Harvey XLVIII, √âmilie Brout & Maxime Marion, hiroyuki nisougi, Kim Asendorf, LaTurbo Avedon, Lee Blalock (L[3]^2), LIA, Morehshin Allahyari, Nicolas Sassoon, peter burr, Sabrina Ratt√©, Sara Ludy, Sarah Rara, shawn√© michaelain holloway, Tabor Robak, Theo Triantafyllidis, and Yoshi Sodeoka
Artwork preview:
‚Äú
Mode Confusion‚Äù by Peter Burr
‚Äú
Speculative Fetish (Vive Controller)‚Äù by Theo Triantafyllidis
‚ÄúAliqua‚Äù by Sabrina Ratt√©
More about Feral File 1.0
Alongside The Experiment, and in celebration of the launch of a refreshed Feral File 2.0, this exhibition features one
artwork from each of our 33 past exhibitions. Curated by Casey REAS, Feral File 1.0 includes artworks in a wide variety of media, and resurfaces a selection of pieces from artists we‚Äôve had the honor of working with over the years.
Feral File 1.0 features works from:
Dmitri Cherniak, Claudia Hart, Andrew Thomas Huang, Cao Shu, Lauren Lee McCarthy, ertdfgcvb, Helena Sarin, Jan St. Werner, Refik Anadol, Tyler Hobbs, Morehshin Allahyari, Sofia Crespo, Sage Jensen, Rafa√´l Rozendaal, Whistlegraph, 0xDEAFBEEF, VNS Matrix, p1xelfool, Laleh Mehran, Gene Kogan, Zach Blas, John Gerrard, Auriea Harvey XLVIII, LaTurbo Avedon, AES+F, Peter Burr, Lu Yang, Amelia Winger-Bearskin, Lee Mullican, Ana Maria Caballero √ó Nancy Baker Cahill, Rick Silva, Kim Asendorf, and Serwah Attafuah
Artwork preview:
‚ÄúHaristory‚Äù by Auriea Harvey
‚ÄúMaterial World Knight: Flying Mode‚Äù by Lu Yang
‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Machine Hallucinations ‚Äî MoMA Generative Study 1‚Äù by Refik Anadol
‚Äú
F(l)ight‚Äù by Tyler Hobbs
Exhibition opening:
June 28, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)

item.title: Autonomous and Alive: Kim Asendorf on his new work COLORS OF NOISE
item.description: Autonomous and Alive: Kim Asendorf on his new work COLORS OF NOISE
item.ns0:encoded:
Autonomous and Alive: Kim Asendorf on his new work COLORS OF NOISE
Still from ‚ÄúCOLORS OF NOISE‚Äù by Kim Asendorf
Visit exhibition
The German visual artist speaks with curator Peggy Schoenegge about shades of noise, the role of the algorithm, and working with sound.
Read the full conversation on
Feral File
.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm very much fascinated by the power of noise‚Ä¶ In audio engineering, you can actually split up the full spectrum of noise ‚Äî which is called white noise ‚Äî into various shades, which are named by colors, such as pink noise, brown noise, and white noise.
With this work, I use these different shades of acoustic noise to drive a visual animation.‚Äù
‚Äî Kim Asendorf
Still from ‚ÄúCOLORS OF NOISE‚Äù by Kim Asendorf
‚ÄúWhat I'm really doing is having algorithms generate the noise acoustically, and I use the wave form of it ‚Äî the wave shape, which is basically showing the current value of the audio ‚Äî which is displayed in the center of the screen, triggering some kind of reaction around it.‚Äù
‚Äî Kim Asendorf
Read full conversation

item.title: Autonomy is coming: a mobile-first NFT viewing experience
item.description: Autonomy is coming: a mobile-first NFT viewing experience
item.ns0:encoded:
https://feralfile.com
Welcome to the first Feral File newsletter! To keep our community in the loop with all things Feral File, we‚Äôll be sending out a newsletter every two weeks. We‚Äôll share news about upcoming exhibitions, plus behind-the-scenes updates as we continue developing the platform.
Our next exhibition will open on
September 9, 2021, at 14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 3pm London, 10am New York, 7am Los Angeles).
As usual, collecting will begin one hour later.
Learn more
through our press release and
join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Pau Waelder.
Instructions Follow
Announcing a new exhibition of digital artwork reflecting on the codes, regulations, and defaults that govern our present time, curated by Pau Waelder. The show will feature video, web-based, interactive, generative, and conceptual artworks by a group of twelve international artists and artist groups. Encompassing a variety of formats, each work will be made available to collectors as editioned NFTs.
Neonumens by Solim√°n L√≥pez. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Site Updates: Support for Ethereum & Account 2FA
Last week, we held a community discussion on
Discord
about our bridge to help users bring their Feral File NFTs to Ethereum. We are planning to launch this at the end of the month. You can
read more about the technical details on our HackMD
.
We‚Äôve enabled optional two-factor authentication (2FA) on the site. 2FA/MFA secures your account by having you submit a code generated by an authenticator app (like
Google Authenticator
or
Authy
) in order to transfer funds outside of Feral File or sell and transfer an edition. Without 2FA, if someone were to gain access to the email account you connected to Feral File, they could place your collection on sale or transfer your funds to their own account. But with 2FA, your account is much more secure. Find it in your account settings.
In our last exhibition, collectors paying with crypto had an advantage over those who used credit cards: crypto collectors could complete the transaction faster and beat a credit card collector in making a purchase. This is no longer the case - as long as you complete a transaction in the time provided, your purchase window is exclusive to you.
Coming soon: Autonomy, a mobile-first NFT viewing experience
We have big plans to launch a universal NFT experience for mobile phones called Autonomy. To give you a sense of what we‚Äôre building, you can look forward to a seamless, customizable new way to enjoy your Feral File collection securely on your phone. Just like you wouldn‚Äôt display a piece of art in your home without thinking about how to frame and light it, you should have options for how to view and enjoy your NFT collection everywhere you go‚Äîand we‚Äôre excited to share our solution with you soon.
The first version of Autonomy will be released by early October, first for iPhone and then for Android in Q4.
Connect with Feral File
If you‚Äôd like to be among the first to access Autonomy and give feedback, please join the Autonomy channel on our
Discord
. There‚Äôs so much more that we‚Äôre planning to roll out by the end of the year, and we‚Äôll be sharing peeks of what‚Äôs to come with our community‚Äîso don‚Äôt miss out.
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
I appreciate all your support.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: Autonomy is now available on TestFlight for iOS.
item.description: Autonomy is now available on TestFlight for iOS.
item.ns0:encoded:
Note: broken link

https://feralfile.com
Our next exhibition, P1x3L, will open on
September 23, 2021 14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 4pm Berlin, 11am S√£o Paulo, 7am Los Angeles)
, with collecting to begin one hour later.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Casey Reas.
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 30 (240 editions for sale), with each edition priced at $450 USD. To learn more,
see our press release
[Link removed ‚Äì no longer available]
or read on.
Curator Casey Reas on P1√ó3L
‚ÄúA P1√ó3L is the atomic unit of digital and generative art. It can‚Äôt be quantified. A P1√ó3L is vibrant and alive. Artists choreograph P1√ó3Ls and P1√ó3Ls possess artists. P1√ó3Ls are ideas about image-making that transcend the technology they flow through‚Ä¶. This remarkable group of artists has each pushed the boundaries of the fields of digital and generative art in their own ways. As a counterpoint to the stream of technology being developed to make itself invisible, these artists foreground the materiality of their medium.
Online spaces for digital and generative art are at the highest energy I‚Äôve seen in over two decades, and things have shifted even since we started organizing this exhibition in June. I‚Äôm thrilled to present this new work from a group of artists who committed to digital and generative art over a decade ago and remain vibrant creators. Their past work has stood the tests of time and their current work pushes forward.‚Äù
Nicolas Sassoon, ‚Äú3 ORBS.‚Äù GIF, 1920x1080 pixels, 72 frames, 25 fps, 256 colors.
Site Updates: Autonomy on Testflight, Ethereum compatibility
In our last newsletter, I mentioned our work on Autonomy, a mobile-first NFT viewing experience. At first, it will let you enjoy your Feral File collection everywhere you go, but we‚Äôll quickly add NFT support for other blockchains including Ethereum. We‚Äôre currently looking for feedback on
our TestFlight release
(iPhone only) - leave us feedback through our autonomy-app channel on
Discord
.
We are finishing up development of our ERC721 bridge. We expect collectors to be able to move their editions from the Bitmark chain into the Ethereum chain by the end of October. Feedback from the community was helpful in fine tuning our metadata to make it easy to search for Feral File artworks in Opensea. For anyone interested in the technical details,
learn more
on our HackMD.
Connect with Feral File
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: Autonomy now available on iPhone!
item.description: Autonomy now available on iPhone!
item.ns0:encoded:
Autonomy is now ready for all iPhone users (Android coming this year). It‚Äôs the home for all your NFT art and other collectibles ‚Äî a seamless, customizable way to enjoy your collection. Its beautiful user interface is coupled with a decentralized key management system we initially built to help people protect their Bitcoin.
Download it now on
Apple‚Äôs App Store.
You would never display a piece of art in your home without thinking about how to frame and light it. Autonomy finally gives you options for how to view and enjoy your NFT collection everywhere you go.
Last month we released an early preview of Autonomy with support for Feral File NFTs. In this alpha release, we‚Äôve added support for Ethereum NFTs (ERC-721) and WalletConnect. In Q4, we will be adding more blockchains like Tezos (Hic et Nunc), in moving towards universal NFT support and functionality such as seed import.
We‚Äôd love to hear what you think and we could really use your feedback on the new ERC-721 support.
You can leave us feedback through our autonomy-app channel on
Discord.
Announcing our Open Call for Curators
We started building Feral File in June 2020, opening the first exhibition in March 2021. Since then, we‚Äôve increased the options for what forms Feral File exhibitions can take, and now have a modular set of pieces that can be put together by artists and curators in different ways.
We are pleased to invite you to become part of our next wave of curators with our open call for proposals.
Learn more about our submissions process here.
Jan St. Werner‚Äôs Polyarrythmia
Our next exhibition, Polyarrythmia, will open on October 26, 2021 14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 4pm Berlin, 11pm S√£o Paulo, 7am Los Angeles), and collecting will begin one hour later. With this solo exhibition of electronic musician Jan St. Werner, the idea is to put audio at the forefront, positioning it at the same level as visual work within the framework of digital art.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors and St. Werner.
Each audio work will be released as an edition of 90, with each priced at 110 USDC. Additionally, the complete set will be released as an edition of 60; with each priced at 990 USDC.
Jan St. Werner on Polyarrythmia:
‚ÄúPolyarrythmia is an album or an exhibition or a selection of pieces, or maybe just a narrative in sound. None of the compositions have a strict metronome; there is no click or clock. The album as a whole has these interlocking peaks, micro-moments and movements, and then larger arcs, which meet and then disperse. To me that is very much what rhythm is, thus the name Polyarrythmia.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe compositions were mastered to be as present and intense as possible. The actual files that people download when they collect will provide the maximum resolution that people will be able to play back. I‚Äôm happy for listeners to experience the compositions separately, but to me, Polyarrythmia is a set, it‚Äôs a narrative as a whole. The pieces were all constructed in relation to each other, based on a visionary brain space, let‚Äôs call it. I was thinking, how far can I let these things drift off? How much space can I give it to unfold and go its own way? When I draw it back, that‚Äôs what becomes an individual composition or a piece.‚Äù
Our first solo exhibition, Jan St. Werner‚Äôs Polyarrythima.
Request: Help us Improve our Upcoming Auction Experiences
By the end of the year, Feral File will launch highest bidder and group auctions in support of our artists. I‚Äôll be discussing the details around these auctions and why we‚Äôve decided to implement them as we get closer to launch.
For now, our product team would love to have you test out the user interface to make sure we‚Äôre making the bidding process as smooth as possible.
You can join the tests through our #features channel the Platform section of our
Discord.
Connect with Feral File
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.

item.title: Ethereum Bridge and Physical Rewards for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised
item.description: Ethereum Bridge and Physical Rewards for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised
item.ns0:encoded:
Our next exhibition,
‚ÄìGRAPH
, will open on
November 30, 2021 14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 3pm Berlin, 11am S√£o Paulo, 6am Los Angeles)
, with collecting to begin one hour later.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Casey Reas.
Save this date to your
Google
or
ICS-compatible calendar.
Each of the artists in ‚ÄìGRAPH has created one software artwork that creates 30 unique physical drawings. Twelve sets (bundles of all six works) will be made available to collectors, as well as 11 of the editions from each artist. The pieces will be auctioned to the highest bidders, and the first collector of each edition will receive the corresponding plotter drawing shipped directly from the artist‚Äôs studio. Each software NFT includes millions of other compositions that are embedded in the software that can be viewed through an interface created by each artist.
See our
press release
for the full details, the "
price list
" for collecting information, or read on.
Curator Casey Reas on ‚ÄìGRAPH:
‚ÄúWhen I made my first plotter drawings, I can say without exaggeration that it completely transformed my understanding of the history of computer-generated drawings. Before, I had vaguely understood how they were created, but now I felt their production in detail... Each drawing is truly unique and is often the result of careful physical adjustments and extreme patience.
Making plotter drawings is difficult and wonderful, and the artists in ‚ÄìGRAPH are passionate about this medium. These artists all share a love of working with visual systems and writing code, and transforming how the code is rendered through drawing machines.‚Äù
‚ÄúUmwelt‚Äù by Julien Gachadoat. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Additions to the Ethereum Bridge
We have been making steady progress with our Ethereum bridge. We have just added support for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised and in total can handle migrations for:
#009 - Unsupervised (
See the OpenSea Collection
)
#008 - Polyarrythmia
#007 - Reflections in the Water
#006 - P1√ó3L
We will finish supporting the remaining five shows before the end of the year.
As a reminder, you can access the bridge for supported artworks when you view your edition within your collection. We have also received great feedback about how to improve our presence on OpenSea - you will see these optimizations rolled out over the next week.
You can help us further by sharing feedback and participating in user tests through our #features, #feedback, and #troubleshooting channels in the Platform section of our
Discord
.
Physical Rewards for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised
Collectors who are holding three artworks (within one account) from the ‚ÄúDreams‚Äù series (9 artworks x 100 editions) as of December 1, 2021 will receive archival prints of their images shipped from the artist‚Äôs studio in early 2022. The prints will be 22" high and 12.4" wide.
This requirement can be met by purchasing editions from secondary marketplaces. On Feral File, you can view editions for sale from other collectors by viewing the artwork you prefer, and click "Collect".
Collectors who won the 1/1 auctions will receive physical editions of their NFTs.
While Refik Anadol is finalizing the logistics, receive the latest updates
in his community on Discord.
Feral File on Sustainability
Since we launched earlier this year, we have received many questions about our mission to build a sustainable curated ecosystem for digital art. As an overview, we focus on sustainability in the following areas:
Economic ‚Äî by creating sustainable relationships between artists and collectors, through evolution of the classic 1971 legal agreement ‚Äú
The Artist‚Äôs Reserved Rights Transfer and Sale Agreement.
‚Äù
Environmental ‚Äî by offsetting 125% of our estimated carbon impact and supporting additional measures, with the goal of being a net-positive contributor to the planet‚Äôs environment.
Technological ‚Äî by supporting open infrastructure in the same ways that facilitated the creation of TCP/IP and the Web.
You can learn more on our new
Sustainability
page.
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.

item.title: Ethereum Bridge Support Completed, MoMA Benefits for Unsupervised Collectors
item.description: Ethereum Bridge Support Completed, MoMA Benefits for Unsupervised Collectors
item.ns0:encoded:
Our next exhibition,
For Your Eyes Only
, will open on
December 15, 6pm Los Angeles (11pm S√£o Paulo, 3am Berlin Dec 16, 10am Shanghai Dec 16)
, with collecting to begin one hour later.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Domenico Quaranta.
Save this date to your
Google
or
ICS-compatible calendar.
Each of the 13 artworks will be available as an edition of 115, with each edition priced at $180 USD. 50 sets will be made available at a price of $2,340 USD. All sales will be run through group auctions;
learn more about them in our FAQ
.
See our
press release
for the full details, the "
price list
" for collecting information, or read on.
Curator Domenico Quaranta on For Your Eyes Only:
‚ÄúFor Your Eyes Only is a curatorial concept that aims to stimulate a conversation with contemporary artists about the future of human visual culture, and to investigate how they are working, in different ways, on the development of a visual language capable to resist the machine gaze and its implications, and to improve human visual communication‚Äîa post-AI, posthuman human vision. The exhibition includes images of diverse nature and origin, submitted as answers to the questions [of machine vision and the human gaze]. And yet, images can be used like words, but they are not words. They can be paraphrased, explained, and described, but no description will ever exhaust them. They can be used like answers, but they are rather proofs. They have been sent by a human to another human, each of them carrying much more than what I asked for. They are not delivering an answer, they are the answer. Try to read them, and you‚Äôll soon find out that they have as many readings as readers. Enjoy, they‚Äôre for your eyes only.‚Äù
‚Äúsmoking-vase-1‚Äù by Petra Cortright. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Ethereum Bridge Completed
Feral File‚Äôs Ethereum Bridge now supports all past exhibitions. You can see this option when you view an artwork as shown in the image below.
When collectors use our Ethereum Bridge to transfer an NFT from the Bitmark blockchain to the Ethereum blockchain, their Bitmark Certificate is replaced with an ERC-721 standard NFT. There‚Äôs an Ethereum gas fee associated with this, required by the Ethereum network to create that new NFT; the collector pays for the gas when they choose to move their Feral File NFT to the Ethereum blockchain. Our Bridge preserves the provenance of the artwork edition, other metadata such as the contract, and the artwork itself. This is done by creating a new IPFS directory containing the data and referencing it in the ERC-721. That‚Äôs how Feral File maintains
the artist and collector rights
across the trust boundary between the Bitmark and Ethereum blockchains.
Coming up next, we‚Äôll continue to work on optimizations for OpenSea, such as displaying the artist‚Äôs name with the artwork. This is an OpenSea-specific customization ‚Äî this information is already properly formatted within the ERC-721 spec.
MoMA Benefits for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised Collectors
As part of our collaboration with the Museum of Modern Art, original owners of the 1/1 series and the nine editions of 100 series will be entitled to a free one year Access membership at MoMA. These include both on-location and internet-based benefits. We will be sending an email to these individuals with more information on how to redeem it in the next week ‚Äî we're working hard with Refik and MoMA to get this done quickly.
Also, in case you missed Casey Reas and Refik Anadol‚Äôs talk with MoMA Curator Michelle Kuo last Wednesday, watch
The Art of NFTs
.
New Autonomy Releases
New versions of Autonomy for
iPhone
and
Android
have been released.
Our goal is to make Autonomy the most enjoyable way to view and experience your NFTs. Autonomy now supports Feral File (Bitmark NFTs), ERC-721, and Tezos (iPhone).
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.

item.title: Exclusive Redemption Offer for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA Series
item.description: Exclusive Redemption Offer for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA Series
item.ns0:encoded:
Exclusive Redemption Offer for Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA Series
We are excited to announce a special offer to Feral File collectors,
in partnership with Refik Anadol and MoMA
.
From Friday, May 19th, 2023 at 9:00am PDT to Sunday, May 21st, 2023 at 11:59pm PDT, collectors will be able to redeem exclusive gifts by ‚Äúburning‚Äù (exchanging) their editions.
You can start the redemption process on Friday, May 19th, 2023 at 9:00am PDT at
feralfile.com/burn-and-mint
.
Burn √ó3 to receive
Unsupervised ‚Äî Burned ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA ‚Äî 2D NFT
a 2D print of the artwork (22" x 22")
and a MoMA Day Pass
Burn √ó6 to receive
Unsupervised ‚Äî Burned ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA ‚Äî 3D NFT
a 3D print of the artwork (3" x 3" x 3") Max 250
and a MoMA Day Pass.
Burn √ó9 to receive
Unsupervised ‚Äî Burned ‚Äî Hallucinations ‚Äî MoMA Dreams #X NFT
a 2D print of a x / 100 unique AI data paintings (44" x 22") Max 100
and a MoMA Day Pass.
Please
check the secondary market
if you need to acquire more. You can also
join Refik‚Äôs community
to discuss this promotion.
Note:
If you're looking to migrate your Refik Feral File NFTs to be able to participate in the burn, do not use the Autonomy free migration feature. While we'd love for you to try Autonomy, the migrations won't be fast because we're optimizing for gas fees. Thus, if you need the migrations done right away, please do a manual migration (1 at a time, you pay the fee). You can find this feature in the individual artwork page under your collection on Feral File.
If you have requested an Autonomy migration, and need to cancel it, you can do so by clicking ‚ÄúCancel Web3 Move‚Äù at the top of Feral File‚Äôs home page on the top of the header.
On behalf of Refik Anadol and MoMA, thank you for supporting Feral File.
‚Äì The team at Bitmark Inc.

item.title: Feral File #001 ‚Äî Social Codes opens March 19th
item.description: Feral File #001 ‚Äî Social Codes opens March 19th
item.ns0:encoded:
View this email in your browser
Feral File is pleased to announce the opening of Social Codes on March 19th. Please join us for the launch of the online exhibition and for a video chat reception:
19 March 2021
10 am PST / 1 pm EST / 6 pm CET
https://feralfile.com
Featured Artists:
Andrew Benson, LIA, Dmitri Cherniak, Raven Kwok, Anna Carreras, Manolo Gamboa Naon, Maya Man, Frederik Vanhoutte, Saskia Freeke, Dave Whyte
Video chat reception:
19 March 2021
10 am PST / 1 pm EST / 6 pm CET
https://videolounges.com/feralfile
Please read about the exhibition and artwork following the signature.
‚Äî Feral File
//
Nodes and Edges: Social Codes Curator‚Äôs Note
Casey Reas
For the last twenty five years, I‚Äôve shared my time and ideas with artists who write code. The internet has always been essential for us, because the web isn‚Äôt just a space for documentation‚Äîit‚Äôs the main place where our work is shared and discussed. For many of us, the internet is also the primary place to exhibit work, and be in community. The Social Codes online exhibition is a view into this community of hybrid artists/coders in 2021.
Social Codes is an exhibition of software art, also called generative art. All of the work is comprised of code written by artists to create visual experiences. Some works in the exhibition relate to the visual histories of drawing, painting, animation, and video, but all of it is native digital art, in that each artwork is a performance of code choreographed by the artist.
Artists have been working with code since the 1960s, and within that time frame, code has evolved from languages written by engineers to run on room-sized computers to artist-created coding languages running inside a web browser. In 2021, artists are writing code in many languages and environments. Each programming language is like a different material to work with.
As I started working on this exhibition in September 2020, I asked the following on Twitter: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm researching ‚Äògenerative art‚Äô on ‚Äòsocial media‚Äô with a focus on the ~present. Who‚Äôs doing the most interesting work in this space? Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, OpenProcessing, etc. What do you think?‚Äù Over a few days we created a
public document
with a crowdsourced list of over three hundred people. This was the seed that grew into this exhibition.
In Social Codes, the artists‚Äô works are presented together in an intentional way, instead of spread out across different online platforms and accounts. The majority of the work in Social Codes is related to the coding platform Processing and the JavaScript library p5.js. As one of the co-founders of Processing,I‚Äôm tuned into that community more than others, so the artwork in Social Codes clearly doesn‚Äôt represent everything happening within this online space right now. So, if this is your first time seeing this type work, I hope you‚Äôll go on to seek out more of it. There are decades of amazing works to explore, all through your browser.
Anna Carreras‚Äô
work has a strong relationship to the Spanish landscape where she spends her time, and her piece in Social Codes, ‚ÄúArrels,‚Äù connects drawing, code, and the environment through a cycle of growth and decay. While Anna looks to nature for the source of her work, she interprets and transforms her experience into carefully choreographed generative animation. In ‚ÄúArrels,‚Äù growing tendrils the color of earth and sky collide in a vibrant dance. New growth in the arid soil overtakes the old, and the cycle continues.
Andrew Benson
is a video feedback aesthete who works with code intuitively, and ‚ÄúScrampled‚Äù is an iconic example of his bright and gestural software paintings. To make his animations, he creates his own software tools the way a traditional craftsperson might build a custom tool for a specific task. In this way, Andrew creates bespoke software that is completely tailored to his process, and unlike code written by anyone else. When ‚ÄúScrampled‚Äù is started, a series of gestural lines are drawn to the screen, and as other gestures begin to excise and copy textures, a new visual world unfolds. The process of mark-making and mark-interrupting becomes a feedback loop that pushes and pulls pixels across the screen in a luscious dance.
Dave Whyte
is in a category by himself in creating code-generated looping animations. Through early machines like the praxinoscope and zoetrope, animation in this style has been created and enjoyed for nearly 200 years‚Äîbut with his attention to the subtleties of motion and perception, Dave has pushed the medium further than anyone else. His online Bees & Bombs media accounts are deep collections of striking motion studies, and his ‚ÄúShimmer‚Äù software in Social Codes is an evolution of his work that moves it toward direct presentation of the software, rather than as a fixed, looping animation created from code.
LIA
was a pioneer in creating internet art in the 1990s, and since then, she has continued to experiment and explore into the present. Her latest work, ‚Äúdada data,‚Äù is aligned with her early works in its focus on minimal, generative animation. With a red dot as a focal point, a network of lines undulate and coil left and right in a way that nods to Marcel Duchamp‚Äôs hypnotic ‚ÄúRotoreliefs.‚Äù Although the linear forms that comprise ‚Äúdada data‚Äù are minimal, the motion is complex and entirely engrossing.
Manolo Gamboa Naon
has been called the first prodigy of generative art. While he deflects this praise, those of us who know his work know that it‚Äôs true. In an incredible burst of energy from 2014 to 2020, Manolo created a sequence of images unlike anything seen before, which went on to influence the next generation of artists who code. After a pause from exhibiting work, he‚Äôs returning to premiere the vivid ‚Äúuneasy dream‚Äù, a continuously-evolving generative animation that surges, expands, and contracts in an ongoing flow.
Raven Kwok‚Äôs
work is always inventive and meticulous, and ‚ÄúIDE94‚Äù, his piece in Social Codes, is no different. ‚ÄúIDE94‚Äù is a generative visual artwork based on a two-dimensional tree map structure. Its random yet organic visual texture and motion pattern are created by controlling nodes on every recursion level of the tree structure, and by assigning a position for each node, Kwok dynamically changes the density and pattern of the consecutive line segments within the finite space. ‚ÄúIDE94‚Äù is a semi-automatic artwork; it constantly changes its own geometry, but at any moment the viewer can pull and stretch it apart, only to watch it return to its starting point, step by step.
Dmitri Cherniak‚Äôs
artistic medium is automation. He creates intricate code systems that generate a wide range of images and animations, and over the last few years, he has produced work at an intense pace, posting the results daily to his Instagram account. Scrolling through his feed feels like touring through a tightly controlled explosion of ideas. In his new work, ‚ÄúTransparent Grit‚Äù, ethereal lenses orbit around a fixed point. The captivating result feels like it could represent any scale, from a vast galaxy, to a tiny atom. As another way to play with scale, the viewer can change the work‚Äôs dimensions to view ‚ÄúTransparent Grit‚Äù from a distance, or from the inside.
Maya Man‚Äôs
unique contribution to Social Codes offers a new way to think about software and performance. Her deep explorations in art, dance, and code come together in ‚Äúcan I go where you go?‚Äù As a video clip of Maya dancing plays, her code analyzes the video frames one by one to generate a silhouette. This contour becomes an ever-changing shape the viewer can take charge of by drawing with it, or they can simply watch as the software performs itself.
Saskia Freeke
has created new coded visuals every day since January 2015, posting these ‚Äúdailies‚Äù online as a kind of public sketchbook. Her ‚Äúenchanting luxuriance‚Äù software brings some of the ideas explored through this daily practice together into a refined world of abstracted interfaces. As the viewer watches, containers of geometric grids float slowly upward, each one obstructing others from view. As the individual elements vie for our attention, each grid conforms to its container while pulsing with vibrant color gradations.
Frederik Vanhoutte
has pushed his work into a new direction with ‚ÄúLamia‚Äù, an isometric presentation of the poem with the same name written by John Keats in 1819. The work cycles through the 728 lines of the poem, with one line presented every 8 seconds, so it takes 97 minutes for the entire text to cycle back to the start. The selected 3√ó3 pixel font intentionally obscures the text, but with practice, it can indeed be read. Frederik is interested in two interpretations of the poem: first, as a way to express the idea that scientific knowledge doesn‚Äôt destroy the romantic idea of beauty; and second, as a cautionary tale of misguided cultural subversion.
Copyright (C) *|CURRENT_YEAR|* *|LIST:COMPANY|*. All rights reserved.
*|IFNOT:ARCHIVE_PAGE|**|LIST:DESCRIPTION|**|END:IF|*
*|IFNOT:ARCHIVE_PAGE|**|HTML:LIST_ADDRESS_HTML|**|END:IF|*

|
Unsubscribe
*|IF:REWARDS|* *|HTML:REWARDS|* *|END:IF|*]]>

item.title: Feral File #003 ‚Äî Fragments of a Hologram Rose opens June 28th
item.description: Feral File #003 ‚Äî Fragments of a Hologram Rose opens June 28th
item.ns0:encoded:
Fragments of a Hologram Rose
Announcing a new digital sculpture and video exhibition of sci-fi, otherworldly plant specimens from 11 groundbreaking digital artists, curated by Rick Silva.
Exhibition Opening:
June 28, 2021
7pm EDT / 4pm PDT
Collecting Begins at 8pm EDT (NFT Editions)
Mutant Bagua by Andrew Thomas Huang. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce internationally renowned artist
Rick Silva
as the curator of the platform‚Äôs third exhibition, which will feature new editioned digital sculptures and videos by a group of eleven groundbreaking artists:
Andrew Thomas Huang (Los Angeles)
Brandon Blommaert (Montreal)
Ido Radon (West Coast)
Kim Laughton (Shanghai)
Kyttenjanae (Los Angeles)
Lawrence Lek (London)
Nate Boyce (New York City)
Peter Burr (New York City)
Rosa Menkman (Amsterdam)
Sabrina Ratt√© (Marseille - Montr√©al)
Sara Ludy (New Mexico)
Curator Rick Silva on Fragments of a Hologram Rose:
‚ÄúThe artists featured in this exhibition were asked to imagine and create their own sci-fi plants‚Äîwhether it be by rendering an alien pollen, some photosynthetic architecture, or a flower whose weirdness is only revealed by its description.
Like botanists from a parallel future or an unknown world, these artists cultivate their fictions into existence. They sub-scatter seed pods, prune polygon cuttings, give their models plenty of volumetric lighting, and soak with fluid simulations. The 3D objects in this exhibition have secret pathways and telepathic tendrils. They bloom on neon skins and disperse nano mold spores through LCD screens.‚Äù
As for the title, ‚ÄúThis exhibition borrows its name from Willliam Gibson‚Äôs first published short story, ‚ÄòFragments of a Hologram Rose‚Äô (1977). As the story notes, when a hologram is cut into pieces, even the smallest section still contains the whole of the image. In a similar way, plant cuttings and an edition of digital works can both hold these mirroring elements of origin and multiplicity.‚Äù
Preview of Select Artworks:
Andrew Thomas Huang ‚Äî Mutant Bagua
(Pictured Above)
Mutant Bagua is a 3D sculptural reinterpretation of the Taoist Bagua (ÂÖ´Âç¶) as a machine-spirit interface. By uploading ancient Taoist script into virtual form, the work serves as an ancestral portal to digital spirits that haunt the interface between Taoist structural code and digital data.
Sabrina Ratt√© ‚Äî Floralia II
Floralia II by Sabrina Ratt√©. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Floralia II is part of a series inspired by the writings of Donna J. Haraway, Ursula K. Le Guin, and Greg Egan. The work plunges us into a speculative future where samples of then-extinct plant species are preserved and displayed in a virtual archive room. Floralia II is a simulation of ecosystems born from the fusion of technology and organic matter, where past and future coexist in the perpetual tension of the present.
Lawrence Lek ‚Äî Temple Lily
Temple Lily by Lawrence Lek. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
As Lek describes his imagined specimen: ‚ÄúThe rare Temple Lily requires music in order to grow, and higher frequencies cause the flower‚Äôs characteristic interference pattern on its petals. Widely known for its therapeutic and healing qualities, multiple attempts have been made to clone the flower for pharmaceutical purposes. Despite these attempts, only several known specimens currently exist.‚Äù
