item.title: Feral File #004 ‚Äî The Long Cut opens August 10th
item.description: Feral File #004 ‚Äî The Long Cut opens August 10th
item.ns0:encoded:
The Long Cut
Announcing a new digital exhibition from 7 groundbreaking artists exploring the boundary between the real and the simulated, curated by Iris Long.
Exhibition Opening:
August 10, 2021
6:00 UTC+0 (2pm Shanghai, 7am London, 2am New York, 11pm Los Angeles on August 9th)
Collecting begins one hour later
Steering Pixels by Studio Above&Below. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the platform‚Äôs fourth exhibition, which will feature new editioned NFTs by a group of seven international artists:
Cao Shu (Hangzhou)
Guo Cheng (Shanghai) & Weihao Qiu (Irvine, CA)
He Zike (Beijing)
Shi Zheng (Shanghai)
Lin Ke (Shanghai)
In_K (Beijing)
Studio Above&Below (London)
Each artwork is an edition of 75, each sold for $75 USD.
Curator Iris Long on The Long Cut:
‚ÄúThe exhibition ‚ÄòThe Long Cut‚Äô features works that investigate the remote, latent, and liminal space of technologies, and how this awareness can trigger alternative pathways and maps for our shared technological reality. More importantly, it investigates how artists navigate between the perspectives of the ‚ÄòProgress-tracer‚Äô and ‚ÄòTopology-mancer‚Äô‚Äîtwo fictional personas representing different approaches to understanding reality‚Äîin order to find their own way of living with the hybridity of the physical and the digital.‚Äù
Preview of Select Artworks:
Studio Above&Below ‚Äî Steering Pixels
(Pictured Above)
‚ÄúSteering Pixels‚Äù was born through a fluid simulation interpreted through a generative adversarial network (GAN), which was trained on hundreds of images of ever-changing water surfaces‚Äîdata collected and sculpted by the artists. Machine vision and machine learning techniques are used to document changing environments to lead to multiple, unexpected, and diverse perspectives.
Guo Cheng & Weihao Qiu ‚Äî Abstract Oracle Miner 0009328437
Abstract Oracle Miner by Guo Cheng & Weihao Qiu. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúAbstract Oracle Miner 0009328437" generates visual prophecies through rendering several complex 3D scenes. During the process, the temperature of hardware running the webpage may rise, the cooling fan may generate noises and the image rendering may slow down. In other words, the ‚Äúoracle" takes the offering from the hardware‚Äîthe foundational structure of the virtual world, reminding viewers that the ‚Äúvirtual" is by no means effortless, weightless, or light as a feather.
Shi Zheng ‚Äî Free Fall Study III
Free Fall Study III by Shi Zheng. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Shi Zheng‚Äôs ‚ÄúFree Fall Study III‚Äù captures a computer-simulated mask that keeps falling downwards. A computer-vision facial recognition system identifies whether the image of each falling mask matches the features of a human face. Numbers between 0.0 and 1.0 represent the approximation value of ‚Äúhuman" identified by the machine compared to a ‚Äúreal human.‚Äù The face-detection algorithms in this work programmatically translate complex human-face information into numbers, which end up overly simplifying the diversity of what a face looks like. Thus, the falling ‚Äúmask‚Äù in the work not only physically embodies products‚Äîincluding facial processing and digital filters‚Äîbut it also epitomizes what it means to be ‚Äúhuman‚Äù in our data-flooded era.

item.title: Feral File #005 ‚Äî Instructions Follow opens September 9th
item.description: Feral File #005 ‚Äî Instructions Follow opens September 9th
item.ns0:encoded:
Instructions Follow
Announcing a new exhibition of digital artwork reflecting on the codes, regulations, and defaults that govern our present time, curated by Pau Waelder.
Exhibition Opening:
September 9, 2021
14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 3pm London, 10am New York, 7am Los Angeles)
Collecting begins one hour later
Neonumens by Solim√°n L√≥pez. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the platform‚Äôs fifth exhibition, which will feature video, web-based, interactive, generative, and conceptual artworks by a group of twelve international artists and artist groups. Encompassing a variety of formats, each work will be made available to collectors as editioned NFTs.
Participating artists:
Lauren Lee McCarthy (Los Angeles, US)
Thierry Fournier (Paris, FR)
Joana Moll (Barcelona, ES)
Guido Segni (Lucca, IT)
Alba G. Corral (Sant Carles de la R√†pita, ES)
Disnovation.org (Paris, FR/ Berlin, DE)
Martin John Callanan (Fife, UK)
Antoine Schmitt (Paris, FR)
Alix Desaubliaux (Rennes, FR)
Solim√°n L√≥pez (Madrid, ES)
Irma Marco (Barcelona, ES)
Varvara & Mar (Tallinn, EE)
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 75, with each edition priced at $75 USD.
Curator Pau Waelder on Instructions Follow:
‚ÄúThe artworks in Instructions Follow explore our relationships with digital devices and information systems from the perspectives of both humans and machines. Overall, the exhibition is a reflection on the instructions and codes that have always been a part of our societies.
Each artist addresses the notion of ¬´instructions¬ª from their own conceptual perspective, focusing on the aspects that directly relate to the subjects they explore in their own unique practice. Hence, the exhibition is characterized by the diversity of the artworks‚Äîboth in their formal approach, format, and behavior‚Äîwith some of them establishing a direct interaction with the viewer, whose actions inform the ultimate contents of the piece.‚Äù
Preview of Select Artworks:
Solim√°n L√≥pez ‚Äî Neonumens
(Pictured Above)
In ‚ÄúNeonumens,‚Äù Solim√°n L√≥pez plays with the notion of social media influencers as modern-day pagan deities, extending their power over the masses of believers who worship them. Two images from the Instagram feed of Brazilian beauty blogger Camila Coelho are recreated using 3D libraries and image recognition software, and then incorporated into a virtual installation. A video created by the artist explores the simulated piece, a composition that is reminiscent of both an altarpiece and a futuristic shop window display.
Lauren Lee McCarthy ‚Äî What do you want me to say?
What do you want me to say? by Lauren Lee McCarthy. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In ‚ÄúWhat do you want me to say?,‚Äù Lauren Lee McCarthy reflects on the ways femme-voiced virtual assistants are commanded and controlled by their users and developers. In her own words:
¬´Exhausted by Zoom calls, I created a digital clone of my voice to replace me. Upon collecting and visiting the work, you are asked by my voice, ‚ÄòWhat do you want me to say?‚Äô However you reply, my voice responds by speaking your own words back to you. Then it asks again, ‚ÄòWhat do you want me to say?‚Äô¬ª
For the first month of the exhibition, this interactive work will be fully accessible to anyone. After this period, collectors alone will have access to the interactive version for a full year. Then, after one year, the piece will convert into an archive playback version, which will include the set of phrases her voice was instructed to say by various viewers over the course of the year.
Antoine Schmitt ‚Äî Minos
Minos by Antoine Schmitt. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúMinos‚Äù is an interactive game based on the well-known Greek myth in which the player, in the role of Theseus, has to escape an invisible maze before getting caught by a Minotaur. Conceptually, the game explores the unspoken rules and codes that we encounter in our daily lives, whether on the level of administrative regulations, social behavior, or software. The player has to discover the rules by playing, and in that sense, it is a game with instructions that follow.

item.title: Feral File #007 ‚Äî Reflections in the Water opens October 6th
item.description: Feral File #007 ‚Äî Reflections in the Water opens October 6th
item.ns0:encoded:
Reflections in the Water
Announcing a new exhibition of AI art exploring nature and the human form, curated by Luba Elliott.
Exhibition Opening:
October 6, 2021
15:00 UTC+0 (11pm Shanghai, 5pm Berlin, 12pm S√£o Paulo, 8am Los Angeles)
Collecting begins one hour later
Vague Recollection by Mario Klingemann. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the platform‚Äôs seventh exhibition, which will feature artwork from a group of 12 international artists exploring the natural form and its possibilities of representation with AI. Encompassing a variety of formats, each work will be made available to collectors as editioned NFTs.
Participating artists:
Entangled Others (Berlin, DE)
Anna Ridler & Caroline Sinders (London, UK)
Mario Klingemann (Munich, DE)
Scott Eaton (London, UK)
Daniel Ambrosi (California, U.S.)
Vadim Epstein (Moscow, RU)
Terence Broad (Newcastle, UK)
Libby Heaney (London, UK)
Mal Som (Berlin, DE)
Yuma Kishi (Tokyo, JP)
Helena Sarin (New Jersey, U.S.)
Jake Elwes (London, UK)
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 88, with each edition priced at $222 USD.
Curator Luba Elliott on Reflections in the Water:
‚ÄúLooking into a still pond, we see a clear, gently blurred version of ourselves staring back at us, while turbulent waters return mere rippled echoes of our shape. These changing reflections of ourselves are similar to images generated from data, which can be hyperrealistic depictions of the original, or images that are surreal and barely recognizable, as flaws and errors creep in.
Reflections in the Water looks at the way artists represent nature and humans, using the latest machine learning technologies to conjure seascapes, imaginary marine creatures, autumn leaves as well as musing on the human form, its shapes and possibilities. Masks and faces akin to the grotesque rear their heads, reminding us both of the early errors of these technologies and the eternal human fascination with depicting ourselves. These artists present AI as a tool to both craft new reflections on perennial subject matters as well as a creative partner, conjuring new landscapes, creatures, and human forms.‚Äù
Preview of Select Artworks:
Mario Klingemann ‚Äî Vague Recollection
(Pictured Above)
Mario Klingemann‚Äôs ‚ÄúVague Recollection‚Äù explores the nature of memory, time, and their interplay with AI. In this work, we see a face form in the monochrome stillness, a fleeting memory of a human as rendered by a neural network, unable to commit the exact features and distinguishing particularities. The work is based on a neural network embedded in the browser, which attempts to remember an encounter in time. As the time vector approaches the point where the recollection is the strongest for a brief moment we can observe the memory fragments forming a face only to disperse again as the vector continues its trajectory in latent space.
Entangled Others ‚Äî There once was a jellyfish ...
There once was a jellyfish ‚Ä¶ by Entangled Others. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúThere once was a jellyfish ‚Ä¶‚Äù is a piece that exemplifies Entangled Others‚Äô fascination with the marine world, particularly with jellyfish. Initially with a phobia of jellyfish as a child, Sofia Crespo, one-half of the artist duo, has developed a curiosity into its visual elements, including its dimensions, physical size, and appearance as well as its average lifespan. The typical life-cycle of a jellyfish spans multiple stages, some involving cloning, which result in potentially countless expressions of itself across a variety of stages, some even potentially in reverse. As humans, we only catch glimpses of jellyfish; our presence for minutes, days, or even a year may not be at all adequate to chart even a single gelatinous life in the depths of the ocean. Here, AI helps‚Äîits generative abilities and imagination help us bridge the divide between our life form and others.
Vadim Epstein ‚Äî Pixie
Pixie by Vadim Epstein. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Vadim Epstein‚Äôs ‚ÄúPixie‚Äù is a piece from an ongoing series using art imagery to explore the emergence of complexity. The neural network in this piece has been used here recurrently, reprocessing its own output without any additional inputs, as if jammed between broken mirrors. The models have been trained on a dataset that encompasses various figurative imagery ‚Äî from photography to rough drawings ‚Äî to enrich and intensify the visual experience. Part of the training data was synthetic itself: some of the source datasets were generated, adding another layer of mediation and thus distancing it even further from the real. Eventually, we observe an ever-changing, shape-shifting, loosely-controlled abstract flux, which appears more lifelike on its own, rather than the flashing snapshots of stiff flesh, stuck in convolutions.

item.title: Feral File #008 ‚Äî Polyarrythmia Opens October 26th
item.description: Feral File #008 ‚Äî Polyarrythmia Opens October 26th
item.ns0:encoded:
Polyarrythmia
Announcing Feral File‚Äôs first solo exhibition, featuring nine sound works by electronic music composer Jan St. Werner.
Exhibition Opening:
October 26, 2021
14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 4pm Berlin, 11am S√£o Paulo, 7am Los Angeles)
Collecting begins one hour later
Polyarrythmia artwork by Rupert Smyth. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the platform‚Äôs eighth exhibition, and first solo exhibition, featuring nine sound works by the electronic music composer Jan St. Werner. This audio-only exhibition puts sound at the forefront, positioning it at the same level as visual work within the framework of digital art. The individual compositions and complete sets will be made available to collectors as editioned NFTs. Each composition will be released as an edition of 90, with each priced at 110 USDC, and the 60 complete sets available are priced at 990 USDC.
Jan St. Werner on Polyarrythmia:
‚ÄúPolyarrythmia is an album or an exhibition or a selection of pieces, or maybe just a narrative in sound. None of the compositions have a strict metronome; there is no click or clock. The album as a whole has these interlocking peaks, micro-moments and movements, and then larger arcs, which meet and then disperse. To me that is very much what rhythm is, thus the name Polyarrythmia.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe compositions were mastered to be as present and intense as possible. The actual files that people download when they collect will provide the maximum resolution that people will be able to play back. I‚Äôm happy for listeners to experience the compositions separately, but to me, Polyarrythmia is a set, it‚Äôs a narrative as a whole. The pieces were all constructed in relation to each other, based on a visionary brain space, let‚Äôs call it. I was thinking, how far can I let these things drift off? How much space can I give it to unfold and go its own way? When I draw it back, that‚Äôs what becomes an individual composition or a piece.‚Äù
‚ÄúPolyarrythmia could be a musical. The whole record has this cabaret connotation, with the sounds doing odd things, stepping up or doing a weird little trick, or waving its hand and having a mustache or something. I also perceive it symphonically, an orchestra of unknown instruments. After all, maybe we still have to figure out what sound is. Maybe it helps to reconsider that idea. Hopefully some people will experience this exhibition not just as sound-based, but as something physical as well, a reconsideration of perceptual signal flow.‚Äù
About Jan St. Werner
Jan St. Werner is an artist and electronic music composer based in Berlin. Widely recognized as one half of the electronic music group Mouse on Mars, he has also pursued a solo career creating sound works under his own name as well as Lithops, Noisemashinetapes, and Neuter River. Starting in the mid-1990s as part of Cologne‚Äôs A-Musik collective, St. Werner has released a steady stream of records both as a solo artist and with Mouse on Mars. He has collaborated with Oval‚Äôs Markus Popp as Microstoria and contributes music for installations and films by visual artist Rosa Barba. During the 2000s Werner acted as the artistic director for STEIM, the Dutch Studio for Electro-Instrumental Music. In 2013 St. Werner released Blaze Colour Burn, the first of a series of experimental recordings called the Fiepblatter Catalogue. St. Werner realized sound interventions and installations in art spaces such as the ICA London, documenta Athen and Kassel, Kunsthalle Duesselorf, HKW Berlin, Lenbachhaus Munich. Werner has been a visiting Professor at MIT‚Äôs Program in Art, Culture and Technology (ACT) in 2016 & 2017, served as Professor for Dynamic Acoustic Research (DAF) at the Academy of Fine Arts Nuremberg between 2017 and 2021 and was a visiting Professor for Sound and Performance at the Academy of Fine Arts Munich. He is currently Artist in House at Staatliche Kunsthalle Baden-Baden, Germany.

item.title: Feral File #010 ‚Äî ‚ÄìGRAPH Opens November 30th
item.description: Feral File #010 ‚Äî ‚ÄìGRAPH Opens November 30th
item.ns0:encoded:
‚ÄìGRAPH
Announcing a new exhibition of software art and plotter drawings, curated by Casey Reas.
Exhibition Opening:
November 30, 2021
14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 3pm Berlin, 11am S√£o Paulo, 6am Los Angeles)
Collecting begins one hour later
‚ÄúUmwelt‚Äù by Julien Gachadoat. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs tenth exhibition, featuring plotter drawings from six international artists who are transforming how code is rendered through drawing machines.
Participating artists:
Aleksandra Jovaniƒá (Serbia)
Iskra Velitchkova (Spain)
James Merrill (United States)
Julien Gachadoat (France)
Licia He (United States)
Tyler Hobbs (United States)
Each of the artists in ‚ÄìGRAPH has created one software artwork that creates 30 unique physical drawings. Twelve sets (bundles of all six works) will be made available to collectors, as well as 11 of the editions from each artist. The pieces will be auctioned to the highest bidders, and the first collector of each edition will receive the corresponding plotter drawing shipped directly from the artist‚Äôs studio. Each software NFT includes millions of other compositions that are embedded in the software that can be viewed through an interface created by each artist.
Curator Casey Reas on ‚ÄìGRAPH:
‚ÄúWhen I made my first plotter drawings, I can say without exaggeration that it completely transformed my understanding of the history of computer-generated drawings. Before, I had vaguely understood how they were created, but now I felt their production in detail... Each drawing is truly unique and is often the result of careful physical adjustments and extreme patience.
Making plotter drawings is difficult and wonderful, and the artists in ‚ÄìGRAPH are passionate about this medium. These artists all share a love of working with visual systems and writing code, and transforming how the code is rendered through drawing machines.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Julien Gachadoat ‚Äî Umwelt
(Pictured Above)
Julien Gachadoat‚Äôs ‚ÄúUmwelt‚Äù relies on the combination of a subdivision algorithm and a curved-line-drawing algorithm to produce a set of minimalist compositions. Each image in the series is the result of partitioning a square into a series of smaller areas and then filling those areas with a dense group of curved lines. The spacing of these lines, their orientation, and their precise curvature are defined by harmonic functions that create rhythms within a spatial geometric melody.
Aleksandra Jovaniƒá ‚Äî (The illusion of) depth of knowledge
‚Äú(The illusion of) depth of knowledge‚Äù by Aleksandra Jovaniƒá. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In ‚Äú(The illusion of) depth of knowledge,‚Äù Aleksandra Jovaniƒá explores apophenia, the tendency to perceive a connection or meaningful pattern between unrelated or random things. Each drawing in the series is generated through random numbers, but the internal connections suggest that more is happening. In Aleksandra‚Äôs words, these images show ‚Äúhow things in life are pretty simple most of the time, but we tend to complicate them.‚Äù
Iskra Velitchkova ‚Äî ‚ÄúCHERTI‚Äù
‚ÄúCHERTI‚Äù by Iskra Velitchkova. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Iskra Velitchkova‚Äôs ‚ÄúCHERTI‚Äù is a series of drawings that explore the relationship between physical drawings and software drawings. On that topic, Iskra writes, ‚ÄúThe difference between digital and physical allows me to see the process itself. The constraints of the pen, the paper, and many other circumstances that only happen in real life make me more aware of how much we can learn from technology and its capacity to produce complexity.‚Äù The software drawing seen in the web browser is a small window of the full composition, to show more detail. The physical drawing reveals the whole picture, and both views are displayed together to convey this relationship.
Chaos Blocks ‚Äî James Merrill
‚ÄúChaos Blocks‚Äù by James Merrill. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
James Merrill‚Äôs ‚ÄúChaos Blocks‚Äù drawings explore the tension between order and chaos. Each drawing in the series is reminiscent of a geological drawing, and we see them created on the screen as each layer draws on top of the next. After the layers are created, each is filled with an unexpected, vibrant pattern. James is reacting against the inhuman perfection that often characterizes visual art created through machines. With this focus, his work has a strong relationship to many of the first plotter drawings created in the 1960s that explored randomness to circumvent precision. James amplifies this further with his library of dense and meticulous patterns.
Licia He ‚Äî Endless Monologue
‚ÄúEndless Monologue‚Äù by Licia He. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
With ‚ÄúEndless Monologue,‚Äù Licia He reflects on questions that she subconsciously asks herself like, ‚ÄúWho am I?‚Äù and ‚ÄúIs this correct?‚Äù In thinking about these repetitive and constant questions, she writes, ‚ÄúThey are soft murmurs yet enormously demanding. They are intricate but chaotic. Gloomy or bright, they are all colorful, tangled, and bizarre.‚Äù A selection of 31 phrases from her internal monologues are the seeds for the random number generator that defines each artwork in the series. The visual manifestation is a dense surface of flowing curves that intersect and create networks. When she uses paint and brushes to translate her images from code to paper, these lines merge into solid blocks as the paint spreads through the paper.
F(l)ight ‚Äî Tyler Hobbs
‚ÄúF(l)ight‚Äù by Tyler Hobbs. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Tyler Hobbs‚Äô ‚ÄúF(l)ight‚Äù a study of the aesthetic overlap and differences between the natural world, hand-made artwork, and algorithmic tendencies. It‚Äôs a return to his long-standing interests in the continuum of representational images to total abstraction. In relation to his idea that code and algorithms become increasingly important within culture and art, Tyler says, ‚ÄúI am interested in what parts of the analog world we can capture, what we can improve, and what is lost.‚Äù

item.title: Feral File #011 ‚Äî For Your Eyes Only Opens December 15th
item.description: Feral File #011 ‚Äî For Your Eyes Only Opens December 15th
item.ns0:encoded:
For Your Eyes Only
Announcing a new exhibition of artworks exploring the machine gaze and its implications, curated by Domenico Quaranta.
Exhibition Opening:
December 15, 2021
6pm Los Angeles (11pm S√£o Paulo, 3am Berlin Dec 16, 10am Shanghai Dec 16)
Collecting begins one hour later
‚Äúsmoking-vase-1‚Äù by Petra Cortright. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs eleventh exhibition, featuring works from 13 international artists investigating the future of human visual culture amid the ubiquity of machine vision.
Participating artists:
Morehshin Allahyari (U.S.)
Sara Bezov≈°ek (Slovenia)
√âmilie Brout & Maxime Marion (France)
Anna Carreras (Spain)
Petra Cortright (U.S.)
Francoise Gamma (Spain)
Theodoros Giannakis (Greece)
Kamilia Kard (Italy)
Jonas Lund (The Netherlands/Germany)
Lev Manovich (U.S.)
Petros Moris (Greece)
Katja Novitskova (The Netherlands)
Jon Rafman (U.S.)
Each of the 13 artworks will be released as an edition of 115, with each edition priced at $180 USD. There will be 50 sets made available at a price of $2,340 USD. Collectors can purchase the artworks via a group auction.
Curator Domenico Quaranta on For Your Eyes Only:
‚ÄúFor Your Eyes Only is a curatorial concept that aims to stimulate a conversation with contemporary artists about the future of human visual culture, and to investigate how they are working, in different ways, on the development of a visual language capable to resist the machine gaze and its implications, and to improve human visual communication‚Äîa post-AI, posthuman human vision. The exhibition includes images of diverse nature and origin, submitted as answers to the questions [of machine vision and the human gaze]. And yet, images can be used like words, but they are not words. They can be paraphrased, explained, and described, but no description will ever exhaust them. They can be used like answers, but they are rather proofs. They have been sent by a human to another human, each of them carrying much more than what I asked for. They are not delivering an answer, they are the answer. Try to read them, and you‚Äôll soon find out that they have as many readings as readers. Enjoy, they‚Äôre for your eyes only.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Petra Cortright ‚Äî smoking-vase-1
(Pictured Above)
Like the webcam videos Cortright has been working on since 2007, ‚Äúsmoking-vase-1‚Äù was filmed with no post production, just live use of standard webcam software. Similar to Instagram or Snapchat videos, the effects are part of the original recording, but by contrast, ‚Äúsmoking-vase-1‚Äù is not part of a networked system designed for data mining and facial recognition. The looping animation is slow, simple, and with a focus on beauty, which led Cortright to her choice of subject as well as the obsolete filter. To shoot ‚Äúsmoking-vase-1,‚Äù Cortright used an old 2014 Mac OS, which gives the image a vintage flavor. A favorite subject of her digital paintings, flowers are featured here as a fragile metaphor of time passing, of a relationship between the real and digital sphere that is ever evolving, never the same.
Jonas Lund ‚Äî Smart Cut
‚ÄúSmart Cut‚Äù by Jonas Lund. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
According to the art critic Arthur C. Danto, ‚ÄúTo see something as art requires something the eye cannot decry‚Äîan atmosphere of artistic theory, a knowledge of the history of art: an artworld.‚Äù Since 2014, Jonas Lund has been making abstract paintings using elements sampled from paintings by other emerging artists, optimized for market success. The morphing animations in ‚ÄúSmart Cut‚Äù are made out of images from this series that were not selected for production: works as part of the process, works as they were before they got ‚Äúgood,‚Äù left-over abstractions. Turned into animations, these discarded images‚Äînot art, according to Lund's ‚Äúartistic theory‚Äù‚Äîhave been selected by a smart cut algorithm as the best ones and automatically pieced together.
Katja Novitskova ‚Äî ‚ÄúPatterns of Activation (gardens of the galaxy)‚Äù
‚ÄúPatterns of Activation (gardens of the galaxy)‚Äù by Katja Novitskova. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúPatterns of Activation (gardens of the galaxy)‚Äù is a GIF assemblage of images from various datasets the artist indexed on a citizen science platform, where volunteers are asked to index, draw on, and categorize images from various datasets, usually with the goal of training image processing AI algorithms. The images Novitskova worked on mostly include wildlife cam photos, astronomy, snail embryos, and monkey blood cells. If the overabundance of instrumental, machine-readable images may cheapen any meaning or aesthetic value, Novitskova actively digs some poetry out of these datasets. Such poetry comes from a combination of technology and the reality that it attempts to capture: glowing eyes of animals that reflect the flash-light of the camera, digital low resolution artifacts, accidentally stunning compositions of galaxies and forests, etc. The GIFs mechanical speed is faster than the usual human perception‚Äîit is functional to the machine gaze, but in itself it creates a new type of poetic image, too.

item.title: Feral File #012 ‚Äî Field Guide Opens January 20th
item.description: Feral File #012 ‚Äî Field Guide Opens January 20th
item.ns0:encoded:
Field Guide
Announcing a new exhibition of five artists who use generative art to create new universes and breathe life into novel forms.
Exhibition Opening:
January 20, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (6am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
‚ÄúHypothetically Micro‚Äù by Iskra Velitchkova. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs twelfth exhibition, featuring 10 generative artworks that leverage Edward Tufte‚Äôs concept of small multiples to explore the process of creation.
Participating artists:
Jared S Tarbell (U.S.)
Iskra Velitchkova (Spain)
Sasha Belitskaja (Scotland)
Ilya Shkipin (U.S.)
Sofia Crespo (Portugal)
Each of the 10 artworks will be released as an edition of 100, with each edition priced at $150 USD. There will be 50 sets made available at a price of $1,500 USD. Collectors can purchase the artworks via a Dutch auction. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Curator Jason Bailey on Field Guide:
‚ÄúRather than act as a mirror, dutifully recreating or reporting back on the world around us, these artists often act as a portal to an entirely new universe. A universe where the artist has crafted unique entities from scratch through many compressed cycles of evolution. A universe where fascinating beings and impossible environments blend the foreign and the familiar, giving us a sense that there is life here, but perhaps not life as we‚Äôve known it.
In this show I wanted to focus on the artistic process for each artist, highlighting how the proliferation of work afforded by digital tools often leads the artist to spend as much time curating as creating. However, it can be hard for the viewer to gather much context when looking at just one or two works by an artist. So as part of my prompt, I also asked them to leverage Edward Tufte‚Äôs concept of small multiples. Small multiples display a set of images in close proximity together, typically in a grid-like pattern, to facilitate comparisons across the full group of images at a glance.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Hypothetically Micro ‚Äî Iskra Velitchkova
(Pictured Above)
‚ÄúHypothetically Micro‚Äù confronts us with a dozen bold ribbon-like entities placed against flat backgrounds of solid color. Familiar on the surface, they become increasingly difficult to place, particularly in terms of scale. Velitchkova‚Äôs lyrical specimens are artfully cropped in a way that suggests we may be looking at the tail, wing, fin, or frond of a much larger organism. Yet something about the color palette also recalls the dyes used in microscopy: These forms could just as easily be microorganisms as much larger birdlike or fishlike creatures. Her work shines next to other generative artists for its elegant biomorphic forms and subtle exploration of color. Velitchkova is a magnificent biological architect, painstakingly crafting visual systems while bringing delicate new creatures to life.
Jared S Tarbell ‚Äî Entity
‚ÄúEntity‚Äù by Jared S Tarbell. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúEntity‚Äù is a wonderful dance of life. Colorful microorganisms are born, engage in naturalistic individual and group behaviors, evolve, and then terminate, making room for new specimens to emerge. The balletic choreography is governed not by linear animation but through the artist‚Äôs deep exploration and understanding of force-repulsion fields. Indeed, work with this complexity and nuance would seem impossible to animate by hand and feels closer to systems and behaviors we are accustomed to seeing only in nature. Such is the unique brilliance of Jared S Tarbell that his work does not capture nature, it rivals it.
This work is a programmed system and the video artifact was a capture of live interaction by the artist. The collectors will receive the interactive software as part of the acquisition. The music in this piece is ‚ÄúInfinity Machine‚Äù by Tonepoet.
Ilya Shkipin ‚Äî Blooming Valetudinarian
‚ÄúBlooming Valetudinarian‚Äù by Ilya Shkipin. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúBlooming Valetudinarian‚Äù is a stunning interplay between attraction and repulsion. As a group, the forms read as 100 beautiful winged insects, a diverse entomological collection of moths or butterflies. But upon closer examination, many of the butterflies reveal a surreal vignette of entangled biomorphic forms that feel voyeuristic if not bordering on pornographic. Shkipin‚Äôs specimens elicit unsettling emotions similar to works from Egon Schiele or Francis Bacon. The images pull in just enough elements from reality to hint at the familiar, while largely leaving us on our own to fill in the blanks. The emotional resonance, compositional awareness, and sensitivity to color, brought by Shkipin highlight what neural networks like CLIP are capable of when placed in the hands of a true artist.

item.title: Feral File #013 ‚Äî Primordium Opens February 24th
item.description: Feral File #013 ‚Äî Primordium Opens February 24th
item.ns0:encoded:
Primordium
Announcing a solo exhibition with media artist Sage Jenson, curated by symbios.wiki.
Exhibition Opening:
February 24, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (6am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Save exhibition calendar
‚Äú36 Points#07 (enmeshed_singularities)‚Äù by Sage Jenson. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs thirteenth exhibition, featuring the first web-based work from media artist Sage Jenson.
Starting with the exhibition opening, new artworks will be revealed over three days. On February 24, 10 1/1 software artworks will be auctioned to the highest bidders. The next day, a video artwork will be sold for $120 in an edition of 100. One day later, 26 1/1 software artworks, a special Display Edition, and a signed archival print will be auctioned to the highest bidders. All auctions will take place over 24 hours. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Curator symbios.wiki on Primordium:
‚ÄúA primordium is an organ at the earliest stages of development, a mass of cell tissue teeming with potentiality. For Sage Jenson, primordium is material at the precipice of desire, and their material of choice. Their work functions in the aesthetics of immanence; a place where machinic systems imbue each other with unending possibility, a world in motion, out of equilibrium, and pulsating with unstable flows. Each piece in Primordium, their solo exhibition, embodies this sense of becoming, hypnotizing the viewer with an ever-unfolding actualization of the shadow future.
In each of the works in the show, there are agents (particles) that can sense, navigate, and modify their environment. The environment acts as both an arena and a message board for the agents. All of the shapes and patterns within the pieces are emergent behaviors within a rich parameter space. In one sense, the behavior of the agents can be viewed as a reaction to the current state of the environment, and in another, the environment is a creation of the agents‚Äô will upon it.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
36 Points#07 (enmeshed_singularities)
(Pictured Above)
In ‚Äú36 Points,‚Äù the keyboard is an instrument for traversing curated locales within the phase space of a home-grown bio-sim. A multitude of particle-agents inhabit this playable terrarium. Their emergent behavior feeds-back and folds onto itself to create a rich and evolving primordium, teeming with material potentiality. The system yearns for the next keystroke, a symphony vibrating within a virtual membrane.
Each edition provides the collector with a unique system state that is loaded at instantiation. To access any of the other points, the user may press keys 0-9 or a-z, and the system will interpolate into its new state. However, the point will drift back to its original configuration over time.
‚Äú36 Points‚Äù culminates three years of research into Sage‚Äôs first web-based instrument. The embedding of the system within the web is intentional, as browsers offer cross compatibility and built-in interactivity. This also allows for the pieces to be collectable, yet open. It is interesting to note that the total file size of the work is 32kB and fits entirely within the metadata.
Embryogenesis
‚ÄúEmbryogenesis‚Äù by Sage Jenson. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In the summer of 2020, Sage set out to synthesize their previous experiments into an emergent virtual organism. They developed new particle behaviors and an artisanal rendering engine. Particles imbued with homeotic potentiality shapeshift into various behavioral species, and give life to a plethora of embryonic stages. In one particular experiment, this amalgamation beget an uncanny offspring, whose particular genetic code has been unreproducible, creating an anomaly, and a treasure.
The only remaining record of this creature is a 4,437 frame video detailing the poignant gaze of its emergent eye. ‚ÄúEmbryogenesis‚Äù represents a sort of
post-partum document
to the extinct resonances within the code. Forever trapped in a loop, lost to the symbolic order of memory. It is with a heavy heart that Sage releases their spawn into the wild, but it is the inevitable eventuality of parenthood that children escape the petri dish.
36 Points #28 (ink_on_white)
‚Äú36 Points #28 (ink_on_white)‚Äù by Sage Jenson. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In ‚Äú36 Points,‚Äù the keyboard is an instrument for traversing curated locales within the phase space of a home-grown bio-sim. A multitude of particle-agents inhabit this playable terrarium. Their emergent behavior feeds-back and folds onto itself to create a rich and evolving primordium, teeming with material potentiality. The system yearns for the next keystroke, a symphony vibrating within a virtual membrane.
Each edition provides the collector with a unique system state that is loaded at instantiation. To access any of the other points, the user may press keys 0-9 or a-z, and the system will interpolate into its new state. However, the point will drift back to its original configuration over time.
‚Äú36 Points‚Äù culminates three years of research into Sage‚Äôs first web-based instrument. The embedding of the system within the web is intentional, as browsers offer cross compatibility and built-in interactivity. This also allows for the pieces to be collectable, yet open. It is interesting to note that the total file size of the work is 32kB and fits entirely within the metadata.

item.title: Feral File #014 ‚Äî Infinite Entropy Opens March 25th
item.description: Feral File #014 ‚Äî Infinite Entropy Opens March 25th
item.ns0:encoded:
Infinite Entropy
Announcing a new solo exhibition with Rafa√´l Rozendaal
Exhibition Opening:
March 25, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúInfinite Entropy 14‚Äù by Rafa√´l Rozendaal. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs new solo exhibition with artist Rafa√´l Rozendaal, who has created a series of 25 unique artworks. Each Infinite Entropy artwork will be auctioned to the highest bidder. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Rafa√´l Rozendaal on Infinite Entropy:
‚ÄúThe way I think visually is with lines ‚Äî it‚Äôs very simple, and very quick; it‚Äôs similar to drawing diagrams. But for this piece I was drawing circles, and though it‚Äôs still the simple instruction of a circle, I also added a level of transparency that I hadn‚Äôt used before. The content of the circle becomes transparent over the spreading out, the further you get from the center. As with all of my works, this one was made with a bunch of small steps ‚Äî the transparency was just one of those small steps, but it creates a very different visual result.
With this piece I also wanted to play with the idea of emptiness and things being filled up and busy. There‚Äôs constantly a tension between where you feel like there‚Äôs some space and where it feels very crowded. The script is simple: it‚Äôs just these circles moving from the center outward, getting bigger. They‚Äôre not moving towards you, but there is a false sense of depth, like moving through clouds. I‚Äôve always liked the kinds of paintings where you‚Äôre suggesting depth, but it‚Äôs barely there.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
‚ÄúInfinite Entropy 22‚Äù by Rafa√´l Rozendaal. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Infinite Entropy
‚ÄúInfinite Entropy‚Äù is a series of 25 unique works, each one with its own colors, rhythm, and scale. The script is relatively simple: colorful circles drift from the center of the composition outward, getting bigger as they go. The dense concentration of color at the center of each circle gets more transparent as the circle spreads, creating a soft halo that gives the piece a layered, fuzzy feel. The overall effect is quite different from Rafael Rozendaal‚Äôs usual harder-edged works, though the process of building it from simple shapes and small steps is the same. The circles look as if they‚Äôre moving toward the viewer, implying depth where there is none.
About Rafa√´l Rozendaal
Rafa√´l Rozendaal is a Dutch-Brazilian artist who lives and works in New York. He uses the internet as his canvas. He also creates installations, tapestries, lenticulars, books, and lectures. He has exhibited at Times Square, Centre Pompidou, Whitney Museum, Valencia Biennial, Casa Franca Brasil Rio, Seoul Art Square, and the Stedelijk Museum. His work is included in the collections of the Whitney Museum, Stedelijk Museum, and Towada Art Center.

item.title: Feral File #015 ‚Äî Ten Whistlegraphs Opens May 20th
item.description: Feral File #015 ‚Äî Ten Whistlegraphs Opens May 20th
item.ns0:encoded:
Ten Whistlegraphs
Announcing a new solo exhibition with artist group Whistlegraph
Exhibition Opening:
May 20, 2022
02:30 UTC+0 (19 May 7:30pm Los Angeles, 19 May 11:30pm S√£o Paulo, 4:30am Berlin, 10:30am Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúLoner‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs new solo exhibition with artist group Whistlegraph, who have created ten ‚Äúwhistlegraphs‚Äù ‚Äî an original art form of scored musical drawings ‚Äî for the show. Each work will be auctioned to the highest bidder. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Writer Dorothy Rose Howard on Ten Whistlegraphs:
‚ÄúIn Whistlegraph‚Äôs first solo show and exhibition, the artist group (Jeffrey Scudder, Camille Klein, Alex Freundlich) presents a new body of work featuring creative documentation of a selection of ‚Äúwhistlegraphs‚Äù ‚Äî memorizable lyrical poems that double as graphic scores, resulting in reproducible drawings.
Blending drawing with live performance documentation is Whistlegraph‚Äôs bread and butter; and it is this evasion of capture that also makes artifacts of their work so limitless. A set of files make up each of the ten whistlegraphs curated for Feral File ‚Äî a high definition video performance and graphic score made for the exhibition, in addition to a curated selection of TikToks of that same work, accessible through a custom interactive player. Each whistlegraph piece by the group has generated countless media artifacts and recordings in the form of social media posts (by Whistlegraph and fans alike), works on paper, and live recitals. Part of the beauty of this format is that once you grok it, you can make a whistlegraph yourself. Indeed many do write their own whistlegraphs‚Äîor interact with the group‚Äôs in the form of duets, mashups, and sing-alongs to the tune of digital folk.‚Äù
The show is accompanied by a text written by Dorothy Rose Howard.
About Whistlegraph
Whistlegraph
is composed of artists Jeffrey Scudder, Camille Klein, and Alex Freundlich, who draw, sing, and make videos together. The group formed during the 2020 pandemic in a cabin in Ashland, Oregon, which remains their creative base. Over the past few years, they have honed a distinctive style and practice that speaks to embodied cognition, art education, and experimental composition for live performance.
The group‚Äôs TikTok
@whistlegraph
is an important platform for their work, where they regularly engage with their 2.2 million current followers. Whistlegraph has also toured, performed, and led educational workshops at Kunstverein Hamburg (Germany), Rhizome, The Schneider Museum of Art (Ashland, OR), Oneroom Gallery (Providence, RI), Willem de Kooning Acadamie (Rotterdam, Netherlands), OCCII (Amsterdam, Netherlands), and the Banana School (Bananskole; Copenhagen, Denmark).
Preview of the Artworks:
Loner
(Pictured Above)
Lyrics:
Sitting curled up in myself
I think of a stone, just
waiting very patiently
for time to pass
For this exhibition, ‚ÄúLoner‚Äù is performed by its composer Camille Klein using a Kaweco Sport fountain pen on her Exacompta Bloc FAF Desk Pad.
‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
Mommy Wow
Lyrics:
Here‚Äôs my zigzag
X my circle
PSHH! PEW!
I love mommy WOWWWW
‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù was composed improvisationally by Whistlegraph, each member taking turns. For this exhibition, ‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù is performed in the evening by Whistlegraph outside of the Schneider Museum of Art with Hagoromo Luminous chalk on brick.
‚ÄúPeople Pleaser‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
People Pleaser
Lyrics:
When you‚Äôre told ‚ÄúAmazing! Incredible‚Äù best beware
Someone‚Äôs always saying, words you wanna hear
Products of low self-esteem,
peacefully prove their being mildly mean
to those around them
At the time of its composition by Jeffrey Scudder, ‚ÄúPeople Pleaser‚Äù was the longest whistlegraph in the groups‚Äô repertoire. It is rendered here by Whistlegraph in pencil on a Kamiterior Memoterior Colors Memo Pad.

item.title: Feral File #016 ‚Äî On Screen Presence Opens May 23th
item.description: Feral File #016 ‚Äî On Screen Presence Opens May 23th
item.ns0:encoded:
On Screen Presence
Announcing a new exhibition of five process art performances, curated by Regina Harsanyi.
Exhibition Opening:
May 23, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúRewilded Topography #1‚Äù by Wiena Lin. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce a week of five live streamed performances for the gallery‚Äôs latest exhibition, On Screen Presence.
Access Passes are available on May 23 with a 12-hour group auction. Live stream performances and auctions for 1/1 artworks begin on May 30 with 0xDEAFBEEF; and continue on May 31 with John F. Simon Jr.; June 1 with Wiena Lin; June 2 with Golan Levin; and June 3 with Molly Soda. Each performance is open to the public but an Access Pass includes an editioned recorded video of the performance and, for three of the performances, live interactivity. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Curator Regina Harsanyi on the exhibition:
‚ÄúLike most of the working world, arts workers were also spending more time in front of the screen on video conferencing software. The most intimate, bodied experience one could have was through a webcam in real-time. Although translated to ones and zeros, webcam video has the capacity to create a portal into ‚Äúreal‚Äù space beyond the screen, a space that doesn‚Äôt exist in polygon modeling but organic compounds. Access to another‚Äôs brick and mortar interior has the capacity to psychologically break through the flatness and connect onlookers to the ‚Äúother side.‚Äù Even with a rich 30-year history of what has been referred to as cyberformance, a dated term to describe performance art that often happens live and over the internet, these practices during the global lockdown remained on the fringes.
On Screen Presence began as a frustrated retaliation against scrolling through thumbnails of decontextualized artwork, both digitized and digitally native. This exhibition offers up live streamed presence of artists in their studio among tangible components in the production of their work. While still remaining just out of reach from corporeal intimacy, this selection of process art performances, which end with the creation of a singular work, are interactive. For a few minutes, viewers form a dynamic, active relationship with the artwork that at least temporarily veils isolated experience. Many of the works that will be created during the performances will be tangible, achieving a complete unchaining from the screen and into the hands of a single collector. Live engagement is ephemeral, leaving only the indexical recording of the process behind. And, incidentally, a majority of works in the program require a transient webpage ‚Äî a networked component to facilitate interactivity. Both factors are reminders that On Screen Presence never truly solves but only explores the problematics of computer screen archeology, equally as vulnerable to the digital dark age.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
‚ÄúSketches in Iron‚Äù by 0xDEAFBEEF. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Sketches in Iron
Since 2020, 0xDEAFBEEF has been known primarily for creating generative audiovisual works that explore the limits of blockchain both technically and conceptually. For the first time, ‚ÄúSketches in Iron‚Äù combines the artist‚Äôs core interest in software with a lesser known facet of their background, metalworking. Pushing the boundary further between digital computation and a 6,000 year-old industrial practice that plays out through a choreographed live streamed performance, the artist introduces their own biological, mineral content as catalyst for the work.
Performance and auction on May 30, 2022 17:00 UTC+0. Auction will include unique iron sculpture, unique digital output of render produced by software, codebase, and recorded video of live streamed performance, sent within seven days after live performance.
‚ÄúEvery Icon: BlockPrint‚Äù by John F. Simon Jr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Every Icon: BlockPrint
Since 1996, each iteration of John F. Simon Jr.‚Äôs Every Icon series has been, at its core, a 32 x 32 grid on a digital screen, divided into 1024 squares, each representing a single pixel. But unlike prior versions, ‚ÄúEvery Icon: BlockPrint‚Äù does not have the goal of moving through every computational variation, pixel by pixel, until the grid transforms into a black square. Instead, the artwork introduces variables related to chance and mediated human intervention that can only reflect a concentrated moment in space and time.
Participants are each assigned ten of 1000 available pixels which they can turn either on or off in the span of 30 minutes. Once the clock stops, the grid will freeze. Whether the result is a distinguishable image or an abstract blotch, Simon will proceed to create a traditional woodblock print on fine art paper with oil-based matte black ink, mirroring the born-digital outcome.
Performance and auction on May 31, 2022 20:00 UTC+0. Auction will include unique woodblock print on paper, digital still image of final configuration, and recorded live streamed performance.
Rewilded Topography #1
(Pictured Above)
‚ÄúRewilded Topography #1‚Äù is a tabletop sculpture designed as a dynamic, organic urban landscape. The artist created it in response to an increase in artworks inspired by simulated characteristics or near replicas of nature portrayed on a digital screen.
A type of Stockholm Syndrome has emerged in the form of a greater comfort with confinement. With increasing interest in digital portals leading to the supposed ‚Äúmetaverse,‚Äù there is a growing disregard for the natural universe taking hold, contributing to the acceleration of human demise. Proxies for nature may distract from the urgency around the human species impending extinction. Yet anecdotal and neurobiological findings have made it clear to Lin that identifying oneself with and immersion within the natural world is essential to survival.
Performance and auction on June 1, 2022 17:00 UTC+0. During the livestream, chosen participants will be invited to enter a date which in turn provokes a set of predetermined actions performed in the landscape, leading into a final performance by the artist. Auction will include unique video of Wiena Lin‚Äôs performance and recorded video of live streamed performance, sent within seven days after live performance.
‚ÄúThe Interfered Microscopy Plot‚Äù by Golan Levin. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
The Interfered Microscopy Plot
Golan Levin‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Interfered Microscopy Plot‚Äù reimagines everyday objects as pareidolic landscapes, producing pen-and-ink drawings in a cybernetic process that melds micro vision, computer vision, and human interference. In Levin‚Äôs performance, the live feed of a digital microscope spurs the machine hallucinations of a semiautonomous drawing algorithm, whose interpretations are both coaxed and culled by the artist. Amid Levin‚Äôs interventions, the system‚Äôs digital forms are returned to the macroscopic physical world through the raucous twittering of a relic plotting machine. Extending from his audiovisual performance ‚ÄúScribble‚Äù (2000), ‚ÄúThe Interfered Microscopy Plot‚Äù continues a thread of Levin‚Äôs software arts research that complicates gestural drawing through abstraction, computation, and real-time interaction.
Performance and auction on June 2, 2022 17:00 UTC+0. Auction will include a unique work on paper, exhibition copy of recorded video of live streamed performance, and archival file of live streamed performance, sent within seven days after live performance.
‚ÄúMovie on 06-03-22 at 1.00 PM‚Äù by Molly Soda. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Movie on 06-03-22 at 1.00 PM
Since 2010, Molly Soda has captured audiences by frequently taking videos on the MacOS application Photo Booth with her computer‚Äôs webcam, documenting the mundanity of herself eating, dancing, singing, crying, or talking on the phone. Although many of these moments have been uploaded by the artist to YouTube, for every moment uploaded, there are countless recordings that exist unseen in her archive. Soda recognizes that digital media lends itself to the process of remixing ‚Äî once uploaded to the internet, a video can be saved, re-ordered, stitched, paused, rewound, skipped, and chopped. This realization has led to a longstanding interest from the artist in publicly realizing and facilitating these processes. For ‚ÄúMovie on 06-03-22 at 1.00 PM,‚Äù instead of simply reworking and remixing her own archive for public view, Soda will hand-off hundreds of clips from the last decade over to participants. From the given audiovisual material, 100 viewers will have the ability to collectively create a new Molly Soda video, revealed at the culmination of the live stream.
Performance and Auction on June 3rd, 2022 17:00 UTC+0. Auction will include unique video created by participants and recorded live streamed performance, sent within seven business days of live performance.

item.title: Feral File #018 ‚Äî p1xelfool: g√§mma üéá
item.description: Feral File #018 ‚Äî p1xelfool: g√§mma üéá
item.ns0:encoded:
p1xelfool: g√§mma
Announcing a new solo exhibition with p1xelfool curated by kerry doran, and the first Feral File exhibition on Tezos.
Exhibition Opening:
July 28, 2022
14:00 UTC (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
See the
Price List
for more details.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation between p1xelfool and curator kerry doran on July 28 at 14:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚Äú7 + 0 * 11‚Äù by p1xelfool. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce g√§mma, an exhibition of 33 unique artworks by generative artist p1xelfool, the gallery‚Äôs first exhibition minted on Tezos.
Curator kerry doran on the exhibition:
‚ÄúPixels are the smallest element that can be displayed on a digital screen, groupings of which comprise the billions of still and moving images in circulation today. Pixels are not dissimilar to gamma rays, the shortest yet most powerful of the rays in the electromagnetic spectrum. The difference between them would seem to do with perception: gamma rays are invisible, pixels are not. However, both require specifically designed environments to engender visibility, such as a scintillation detector or a computer with a digital display. Because of the relative ubiquity of the latter, the specificity ‚Äî and necessity ‚Äî of the computer environment may be easily overlooked, if not forgotten, when perceiving pixels. The seduction of the screen, with its pixel-based representations, obfuscates the fusion of software and hardware that illuminate content: code and cold cathode. As p1xelfool says, ‚ÄòCode = light.‚Äô
In g√§mma, p1xelfool fuses pixels with light, with code. With such an emphasis on these materials and their visual properties, the works may seem formalist. Indeed, the generative compositions are strikingly geometric and inorganic; for those familiar with p1xelfool‚Äôs larger body of work, those in g√§mma may come across as austere in comparison. Yet these works are deeper than their surface. p1xelfool‚Äôs approach is intent on reconnecting color and light with the computer environment to create engrossing sensorial experiences specific to it.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
‚Äú0 + 0 * 11‚Äù by p1xelfool. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File
The 33 unique artworks presented in g√§mma are self-contained systems; each contains 3 seeds generated by the system, selected and arranged by the artist to comprise the final composition.
p1xelfool conceptualized these works with Processing, its visual and responsive coding environment feeling more expressive to the artist than analog painting. The works are executed with p5.js, which allowed p1xelfool to program pixels in the browser in real-time. ‚ÄúInstead of asking the program to draw lines, I asked it to manipulate the pixel arrays,‚Äù he describes. This underscores the conceptual motivation of the project, namely, the reappropriation of pixels (and light and code) rather than the visuals produced by them. When viewing the work, there is the option to hit the ‚ÄúP‚Äù key to pause the pattern; hitting the ‚ÄúS‚Äù key will save and download the frame.
p1xelfool‚Äôs generative animations are inspired by the logic of particle systems, yet they share no reference to the natural world. The visual environments of the works are specific only to the computer. In each work, two superimposed and interrelated systems simultaneously interact with one another. Their interrelated velocities determine the speed at which blocks of interplaying (and playful) color seem to descend to the bottom of the screen, cycling through new patterns and creating the illusion of endlessness. Colors and patterns are rhythmic and vibrational; visual pleasure is immense and infinite.
About Feral File
Feral File is where artists, collectors, and curators convene to co-create a new paradigm for digital art. We commission curated exhibitions of file-based artwork, and partner with artists and institutions to establish transparent protocols for exhibiting and collecting. Evolving from the art gallery and digital publishing models, we are borrowing the best traits of each to inform a new kind of art space. Feral File works in tandem with a community of technologists, new media artists, and curators to redefine and frame a sustainable model for digital experimentation.
About Tezos
Tezos is an energy-efficient blockchain where developers, artists, entrepreneurs, brands, and others from around the world build and engage with a network of decentralized applications. Tezos‚Äô modular architecture allows for seamless, community-determined upgrades that deploy new advancements to fuel the next round of innovation.
PRESS CONTACT
Eileen Skyers
Gallery Director, Feral File
eileen@feralfile.com

item.title: Feral File Discord Community Updates
item.description: Feral File Discord Community Updates
item.ns0:encoded:
Feral File Discord Community Updates
To welcome 2023, we‚Äôre introducing new changes to
our community Discord server
to create a more enjoyable experience for everyone.
1) Moving from Chat-focus to Forum Threads
Feral File operates at a different pace. We open a couple of exhibitions per month, so we don‚Äôt expect our community to be around on the server at all times every day. Thus, we felt that allowing long term, gradual conversation to develop would create a friendly environment for new and current community members. We hope that forums allow for deeper exploration of our exhibitions and art-related topics brought up by our community.
Through each exhibition thread (example:
https://discord.com/channels/768706944097058828/1058101057332461669
) and our exhibition list (
https://discord.com/channels/768706944097058828/1050133565142208542
), you will quickly find information around the exhibitions and how to keep conversations going with our artists, curators, and other community members.
If you do want to simply hang out and chat, welcome new members, discuss random things, we welcome this in live-chat and collector-talk.
2) Technical Support is no longer handled on Discord
We enjoy discussing the development of Feral File and Autonomy Digital Wallet App on Discord with you, but individual technical support should be handled securely and privately in-app or through mail. This request relates to‚Ä¶
3) Changes to keep you safe
We are using various server rules to discourage non-serious users from joining the community. We want you to be safe and highly discourage communicating over DMs, including with us - in the past users have tried to emulate Bitmark employees. We believe these changes will foster a safe place for everyone to discuss art together. Web3 was built on the foundations of transparency, and we similarly echo this in our products. When in doubt, communicate publicly.
We always welcome feedback and will keep listening to make this a wonderful space for everyone.

item.title: Feral File‚Äôs Ethereum Bridge has been Launched!
item.description: Feral File‚Äôs Ethereum Bridge has been Launched!
item.ns0:encoded:
I am excited to announce the launch of Feral File‚Äôs Ethereum bridge. It allows you to migrate a Feral File NFT from the Bitmark blockchain to Ethereum. You can then control the resulting NFT with an Etherem wallet of your choice or list it on marketplaces like OpenSea.
You can access this now if you have an edition from
Reflections in the Water
in your collection. (see the screenshot below for how to find the feature). You will need to pay a one-time Ethereum network fee to migrate. Feral File does not profit from this.
We will initially add support for one exhibition per week, working backwards to our first exhibition,
Social Codes
. We should be able to go faster in a few weeks, and you can expect us to finish before the end of the year. For the technical details, we have updated our
documentation
to reflect our latest flows, contracts, data, and metadata.
You can leave us feedback through our #features channel in the Platform section of our
Discord.
Next: Highest-Bidder and Group Auctions
In my daily work, I focus on making Feral File more accessible. To help collectors, I work with our team to make it easier for anyone (regardless of crypto expertise) to participate in our openings, to enjoy the artists and the artworks being exhibited, and to know what‚Äôs going on.
We are working on ways of collecting that remove the time pressure many of you feel during openings, and give us more information about how future exhibitions should be editioned. You will see these starting with our next show in November.
‚Äú
Highest-Bidder Auctions
‚Äù will be deployed for a single edition or set. These auctions probably work exactly as you think. You will have a set time period to place a bid; a new winning bid within the last 5 minutes extends the auction by 10 minutes. The highest bidder at the end of the auction wins.
‚Äú
Group Auctions
‚Äù allow Feral File to sell editions in a way where the price is determined by community consensus. Here‚Äôs an example of how it works:
Let‚Äôs say 100 editions of an artwork are being auctioned together at a minimum price of $75/USDC.
The 100 highest bids will win the auction and those collectors are guaranteed an edition. However, each collector only pays the price of the lowest winning bid. To participate:
1) Make a bid before the auction ends. There is no maximum bid. No information about other bids will be released during the auction.
2) You may prioritize your bid for one edition number. Assuming you have one of the top 100 bids and you are also the highest bidder for that specific edition number, you get that edition. Otherwise, you will be assigned the lowest numbered edition available after higher bids have been assigned editions.
Crypto and credit cards will be accepted for both auction types.
Our goal in implementing these auctions is to give everyone the same opportunity to collect artwork editions. Over time, we will also use the community‚Äôs bidding data to understand how to adjust edition numbers to keep pricing accessible for a wide range of collectors.
If you would like to test out the user interface to make sure we‚Äôre making the bidding process as smooth as possible, you can join the tests through our #features channel in the Platform section of our
Discord.
Connect with Feral File
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.

item.title: Forthcoming from Feral File: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
item.description: Forthcoming from Feral File: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
item.ns0:encoded:
Forthcoming from Feral File: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
‚ÄúBLOOMCORE‚Äù by Rick Silva. Image courtesy of Feral File and the artist.
Join the Discord Conversation
Opening on Feral File on April 20th, BLOOMCORE is an exhibition of a new series by Rick Silva, curated by Claire L. Evans.
Last year, Silva 3D-scanned hundreds of blooming plants throughout the Pacific Northwest, which he later grafted and pruned into a hyper-flora. In 30-second looping videos, eerie vegetal forms rotate and slice through a fog of atmospheric lights. The series, also titled BLOOMCORE, will be available in
a series of 55 artworks
, each priced at .25 ETH.
Exhibition Opening:
April 20, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Curator Claire L. Evans on BLOOMCORE:
‚ÄúIn Silva‚Äôs BLOOMCORE, we encounter beings familiar, yet unknown, and unknowable. Lush rhododendrons, broad-leaved ferns, rare roses, denizens of deep forests: scanned in the spring of 2022, they are each presented in full bloom, at the height of their lives and thus also on the brink of death. As I write these words, most of the real-life plants Silva has volumetrically captured are almost certainly dead, but they‚Äôll remain preserved in perpetuity, on the blockchain, like museum specimens. To me this is profoundly gothic ‚Äî these blooms hanging outside of time in the radiant computational darkness, promising transcendence, concealing poison (Silva has even included a few poisonous pitcher plants in this collection, vegetal carnivores with alluring, vaselike forms). In this he summons the vast dreaming life of plants, their hidden, distributed way of knowing, their collective ancientness, and the slow, halting way they move across the world.‚Äù
About Rick Silva:
Rick Silva is a Brazilian-American artist whose videos, websites, and installations explore virtuality, futurology, and speculative ecologies. His work has been exhibited at institutions including The Centre Pompidou, Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, and The Whitney Museum of American Art. He has been featured in Artforum, Wired, and Rhizome‚Äôs NET ART Anthology. He lives in Eugene, Oregon where he is an Associate Professor at The University of Oregon.
Preview of Selected Artworks:
‚ÄúBLOOMCORE‚Äù by Rick Silva. Images courtesy of Feral File and the artist.
In the spring and summer of 2022, artist Rick Silva 3D-scanned living plants throughout the Pacific Northwest ‚Äî in university greenhouses, coastal redwoods, the high desert, and the Cascade mountains. Following this field work, Silva grafted and pruned the digitized plants into an eternal hyper-flora that rotates and slices through a fog of atmospheric lights. His eerie vegetal forms hover at the edges of representation and abstraction, digital and organic, familiar and alien.
Exhibition Opening:
April 20, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later

item.title: I Know Exhibition: Individual Editions Now on Sale
item.description: I Know Exhibition: Individual Editions Now on Sale
item.ns0:encoded:
I Know: Individual Editions Now on Sale
Turandot 2070, Lovers I
by AES+F. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
View exhibition
Individual editions
from¬†I Know, an exhibition exploring what an aesthetic of truth might be, are now available for sale. Curated by Giorgio Vitale, I Know features an intergenerational group of five artists, each embracing very different aesthetics and artistic strategies. Their works in the show address anxieties about the turmoil we are now experiencing around the world and offer critical reflections on it.
Featuring new artworks from:
aaajiao
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
AES+F
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Cibelle Cavalli Bastos
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Claudia Hart
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Yehwan Song
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
The exhibition was installed¬†last week at
Transmediale/Vorspiel
in Berlin.
Don't miss the Artist Conversations
Please join us for a series of conversations between the curator and the artists.
Recorded: February 2, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
OPENING I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with all of the artists in the show and the curator
Recorded: February 5, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
SECOND I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with aaajiao, Cibelle Cavalli Bastos, and Claudia Hart
Today, February 7, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
THIRD I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with Yehwan Song and AES+F
Curator Giorgio Vitale on I Know:
‚ÄúThe ‚Äòtruth‚Äô considered in this exhibition is not a scientific or academic one, but rather an imaginative one. It is based on the slow unfolding that viewers experience when they sit with an artwork. In our current post-truth society, in which veracity and accuracy are sacrificed on the altar of hyperbole and misinformation, I Know invites artists to reexamine historical moments and to evoke images of the past in order to claim a place within it. These artists struggle with power, inequality, and discrimination, addressing debates about mass surveillance and the architecture of the web3. The works in the exhibition reflect on traditional modes of thinking, both inside of and outside of the arts, and in so doing make way for future possibilities.‚Äù

item.title: Improvements to the Collecting Experience
item.description: Improvements to the Collecting Experience
item.ns0:encoded:
Hi everyone,
I have several Feral File changes to announce.
Starting with the next exhibition,
Reflections in the Water
, (more below) you will have a new way to buy editions: similar to sets, you will be able to simply buy the lowest numbered edition of an artwork available with one click when an exhibition opens for sale. If you would like, you can still manually look for a preferred edition number, but we believe that this option will make the collecting experience more enjoyable for many in our community.
In addition, we have also:
made enhancements to the website speed to avoid slowdowns in peak traffic situations like exhibition openings.
implemented multi-currency display. Now you can see prices in USD/USDC, ETH, or BTC.
2 Minute Request: Help us learn about your experience with NFTs
As part of our work in developing better collecting experiences with Feral File and Autonomy, I‚Äôd love to learn more about your experience with NFTs.
Could you help me by completing this two minute survey? Your personal information will not be shared with us.
Start here:
https://forms.gle/QQHjwBQGVdnW8fjf8
Reflections in the Water
Our next exhibition,
Reflections in the Water
, will open on
October 6, 2021 15:00 UTC+0 (11pm Shanghai, 5pm Berlin, 12pm S√£o Paulo, 8am Los Angeles)
, with collecting to begin one hour later.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Luba Elliott.
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 88 (900 editions for sale), with each edition priced at $222 USD. To learn more, see
our press release
or read on.
Curator Luba Elliott on Reflections in the Water:
‚ÄúLooking into a still pond, we see a clear, gently blurred version of ourselves staring back at us, while turbulent waters return mere rippled echoes of our shape. These changing reflections of ourselves are similar to images generated from data, which can be hyperrealistic depictions of the original, or images that are surreal and barely recognizable, as flaws and errors creep in.
Reflections in the Water looks at the way artists represent nature and humans, using the latest machine learning technologies to conjure seascapes, imaginary marine creatures, autumn leaves as well as musing on the human form, its shapes and possibilities. Masks and faces akin to the grotesque rear their heads, reminding us both of the early errors of these technologies and the eternal human fascination with depicting ourselves. These artists present AI as a tool to both craft new reflections on perennial subject matters as well as a creative partner, conjuring new landscapes, creatures, and human forms.‚Äù
Mario Klingemann, ‚ÄúVague Recollection.‚Äù Image courtesy the artist and Feral File.
Connect with Feral File
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: Announcing In Medias Res by FEMMEBIT
item.description: Announcing In Medias Res by FEMMEBIT
item.ns0:encoded:
Announcing N=12, a collaboratively created group exhibition of generative artists, and the launch of Feral File 2.0
Text Me When You Get Home
by
Nicole Vella
N=12
is¬†a group exhibition that arose out of a dialogue between twelve artists across seven¬†time zones. Selected through a democratic process from the
Generative Artists Club (genartclub)
, these artists have had direct and active conversations with one another for months, sharing their code and artistic processes to generate artworks that give testament to the power of collaboration in a networked world.
N=12
features artists
Anna Lucia
,
Nadieh Bremer
,
Daniel Catt
,
Reva Fan
,
Elsif
,
Lia Coleman
,
Piter Pasma
,
RalenArc
,
Bart Simons
,
Nicole Vella
,
ippsketch
, and
Melissa Wiederrecht
.¬†The exhibition is curated by renowned artist and engineer
Aaron Penne
, who is also the Director of Engineering at
Art Blocks
.
N=12
opens Thursday, July 13
256 Kill-Screen
by
Daniel Catt
Curator Aaron Penne on
N=12
and the unique process behind the exhibition:
‚ÄúThis cross-pollination of ideas pushed each of the artists towards new technical and aesthetic innovations. Each of their works is created with code written by the artists themselves. This has required artists to be equally comfortable ideating with infinite imagination and instructing a machine to translate these ideas into reality. The
Experiments in Art and Technology (E.A.T.)
of the 1960s normalized the collaboration of artists and engineers. In contrast, the artists of this show ‚Äî indeed, much of this generation ‚Äî are themselves all hybrid artist-engineers. Not only do they critique each other‚Äôs aesthetics, they also debug each other‚Äôs code. In such a context, variables, functions, and logic are as open to influence as color palette. These artists are not just sharing outputs with each other, they are sharing their innermost processes.‚Äù
Tesselate
by
RalenArc
Mark your calendars for N=12
Exhibition
opens for viewing on
Thursday,¬†July 13, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
(22:00 Shanghai, 16:00 Berlin, 11:00 S√£o Paulo, 07:00¬†Los Angeles).
Collecting starts¬†Thursday,¬†July 20, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
Collecting ends
Friday,¬†July 21, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
Collecting process¬†and prices¬†will be announced at the opening.
Get ready for FF 2.0
Alongside the opening of
N=12
, we are excited to debut Feral File 2.0.
Look out for a fresh¬†look, a rework of our exhibition program, and a new way to collect artworks.
