item.title: In Medias Res collecting closes in 3 hours
item.description: In Medias Res collecting closes in 3 hours
item.ns0:encoded:
In Medias Res collecting ends in 3 hours
New Landscapes 2023 #28
by
Petra Cortright
There are still sets available from
In Medias Res
,
Feral File's current exhibition¬†of feminist and post-cyberfeminist artists living¬†in Los Angeles
!¬†Collecting closes today¬†at 15:59¬†UTC+0 (23:59¬†Shanghai, 17:59¬†Berlin, 12:59¬†S√£o Paulo, 08:59 Los Angeles).
A total of 33 sets were¬†minted on Ethereum
Each set consists of¬†9 artworks, one from each of the artists. Every artwork is unique.
All remaining sets are available at their base price of 1.33 ETH. Credit card purchases are accepted.
After the collecting period closes, sets will no longer be available on Feral File. Uncollected¬†sets will be taken off the market or¬†burned in accordance with the artists' preference.
Watch
Exhibition Notes:¬†In Medias Res
In Medias Res
, an exhibition celebrating the contributions of feminist and post-cyberfeminist artists living¬†in Los Angeles, is curated by Kate Parsons and Janna Avner of the grassroots platform
FEMMEBIT
. The show features artists
Petra Cortright
,
JJStratford
,
Anna Luisa Petrisko
,
Casey Kauffmann
,
Ellie Pritts
,
Wednesday Kim
,
Eve-Lauryn LaFountain
,
Huntrezz Janos
, and
Tuna Bora
.¬†Take a deeper dive with¬†each of the artists into the process behind their¬†works by checking out our
In Medias Res
YouTube playlist
.
FEMMEBIT
is a grassroots platform and triennial festival of Los Angeles-based artists working in video and new media. As a celebration that includes curated programs, symposiums, screenings and exhibitions, FEMMEBIT examines today‚Äôs society at large as an ever-changing medium. This platform investigates how artists working with and between technologies enables progressive ideas to be born through active creation, and how we, as proponents of these fields, must work together to shape, share, and grow a future receptive to progress.
Drive Time #7
by
Casey Kauffmann
What's new in Feral File 2.0
Feral File Co-Founder Casey Reas and Bitmark CEO, Sean Moss-Pultz, share¬†their vision for the next iteration of Feral File.
FF 2.0 presents¬†a new model to experience and collect exhibitions and a totally refreshed¬†look. It marks a return to our core values by doubling down on what makes Feral File unique in the on-chain art space:
Group exhibitions:
Artists on Feral File collaborate with a curator to create and exhibit artworks around a single, ambitious theme.
Works as series:
Each artist in an exhibition creates work as a series. A series contains multiple unique artworks connected together under a single series theme. Each series in an exhibition has the same number of artworks in it.
Collecting in sets:
Exhibitions are collected in sets that comprise one artwork from each series in an exhibition. Individual artworks are not offered for primary sale. Each set is unique, capturing a different facet of an exhibition‚Äôs full curatorial vision.
Multichain and fully web3:
Feral File 2.0 supports exhibitions on either Ethereum or Tezos and is fully compatible with current web3 standards.
Commitment to artist royalties:
Royalties are now streamed directly to artists, and all precautions are taken to guarantee royalties collection on secondary markets.
Public documentation:
Much more attention is given to documenting, presenting, and preservation the events and other cultural production surrounding exhibitions.
Copyright ¬© *|CURRENT_YEAR|* *|LIST:COMPANY|*
*|IFNOT:ARCHIVE_PAGE|* *|LIST:DESCRIPTION|*
Our mailing address is:
*|HTML:LIST_ADDRESS_HTML|* *|END:IF|*
You can
update your preferences
or
unsubscribe from this list
.]]>

item.title: In Medias Res collecting starts in 3 hours
item.description: In Medias Res collecting starts in 3 hours
item.ns0:encoded:
Collecting period launches soon for FEMMEBIT‚Äôs In Medias Res
New Landscapes 2023 #28
by
Petra Cortright
Get ready to collect¬†your favorite sets from Feral File's 37th exhibition,
In Medias Res
!¬†Collecting begins in 3 hours at 16:00 UTC+0 (24:00 Shanghai, 18:00 Berlin, 13:00 S√£o Paulo, 09:00¬†Los Angeles).
In Medias Res
, an exhibition celebrating the contributions of feminist and post-cyberfeminist artists living¬†in Los Angeles, is curated by Kate Parsons and Janna Avner of the grassroots platform
FEMMEBIT
. The show features artists
Petra Cortright
,
JJStratford
,
Anna Luisa Petrisko
,
Casey Kauffmann
,
Ellie Pritts
,
Wednesday Kim
,
Eve-Lauryn LaFountain
,
Huntrezz Janos
, and
Tuna Bora
.
In Media Res
exhibition sets will be collected through a falling price auction.
The auction starts at an opening price and falls down to its final base¬†price over a duration of 30 minutes. During the auction, you can collect a specific set once it reaches the price you desire. However, note that anyone can purchase that set before you (at a higher price) as well, so don't wait too long! If all sets are not sold in the first 30 minutes, remaining sets are sold at the base price for the next 23.5 hours. After this (24 hours from the start of the sale), any remaining sets are removed from sale at Feral File entirely.
Sets Available
22 sets minted on Ethereum are¬†available for collection.
Each set is comprised of¬†9 artworks, one from each of the artists. Every artwork is unique.
Opening price: 5.32 ETH
Base price: 1.33 ETH
Collecting starts today, August 24, at 16:00 UTC+0.
Collecting ends tomorrow, August 25, at 15:59 UTC+0.
Watch
Exhibition Notes:¬†In Medias Res
More about
In Medias Res

item.title: Today: FEMMEBIT‚Äôs In Medias Res Opens
item.description: Today: FEMMEBIT‚Äôs In Medias Res Opens
item.ns0:encoded:
Opening Aug 17:¬†FEMMEBIT curates In Medias Res on Feral File
Forthcoming from Feral File, we have an exciting exhibition opening
August 17, 2023
:
FEMMEBIT
presents
In Medias Res
Featuring Petra Cortright, JJ Stratford, Anna Luisa Petrisko, Casey Kauffmann, Ellie Pritts, Wednesday Kim, Eve-Lauryn LaFountain, Tuna Bora, and Huntress Janos. Curated by Kate Parsons and Janna Avner of FEMMEBIT.
In Medias Res
is an exhibition of on-chain art by Los Angeles-adjacent, feminist, and post-cyberfeminist artists. Their works reflect today‚Äôs digital uprootedness from time-based narratives of the silver screen to invoke liminal spaces of belonging.
FEMMEBIT
is a grassroots platform and triennial festival of Los Angeles-based artists working in video and new media. Since 2016, the group has showcased the distinctive voices and perspectives of female and non-binary artists, offering ‚Äúa unique, unapologetically feminist perspective on the futuristic zeitgeist.‚Äù (
LA Weekly
)
New Landscapes 2023 #29
by
Petra Cortright
Curators Kate Parsons and Janna Avner on
In Medias Res
:
‚ÄúThe exhibition takes its name from the narrative device, defined as ‚Äòinto the midst of things.‚Äô As this might suggest, the nine artists in the exhibition invite us to engage directly with the heart of their stories, wherein they explore their personal relationships to Los Angeles as they negotiate daily life in relation to Hollywood and the broader SoCal area.
The title is also a comment on the nature of NFTs themselves ‚Äî media without a beginning, middle, or end. As still or looping moving images, NFTs have a strange relationship to time, often depicting states of emergence as powerful vignettes. In this sense, NFTs might be considered ‚Äòin the midst of things,‚Äô post-time and post-narrative, especially in contrast to the conventions of Hollywood storytelling."
Drive Time #29
by
Casey Kauffmann
Mark your calendars for
In Medias Res
In Medias Res
opens for viewing on
Thursday,¬†August 17, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
(22:00 Shanghai, 16:00 Berlin, 11:00 S√£o Paulo, 07:00¬†Los Angeles).
Collecting starts¬†Thursday,¬†August 24, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
Collecting ends
Friday,¬†July 25, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
Pricing will be announced at the opening.
What's new in Feral File 2.0
Feral File Co-Founder Casey Reas and Bitmark CEO, Sean Moss-Pultz, share¬†their vision for the next iteration of Feral File.
FF 2.0 presents¬†a new model to experience and collect exhibitions and a totally refreshed¬†look. It marks a return to our core values by doubling down on what makes Feral File unique in the on-chain art space:
Group exhibitions:
Artists on Feral File collaborate with a curator to create and exhibit artworks around a single, ambitious theme.
Works as series:
Each artist in an exhibition creates work as a series. A series contains multiple unique artworks connected together under a single series theme. Each series in an exhibition has the same number of artworks in it.
Collecting in sets:
Exhibitions are collected in sets that comprise one artwork from each series in an exhibition. Individual artworks are not offered for primary sale. Each set is unique, capturing a different facet of an exhibition‚Äôs full curatorial vision.
Multichain and fully web3:
Feral File 2.0 supports exhibitions on either Ethereum or Tezos and is fully compatible with current web3 standards.
Commitment to artist royalties:
Royalties are now streamed directly to artists, and all precautions are taken to guarantee royalties collection on secondary markets.
Public documentation:
Much more attention is given to documenting, presenting, and preservation the events and other cultural production surrounding exhibitions.

item.title: In/Visible, a group show of 10 Black artists exploring AI, opens Monday
item.description: In/Visible, a group show of 10 Black artists exploring AI, opens Monday
item.ns0:encoded:
In/Visible, a group show of 10 Black artists exploring AI, opens Monday
‚ÄúThe Idunnos, #45‚Äù by Jah.
On Monday, June 12 at 14:00 UTC, we‚Äôre opening
In/Visible
, a landmark exhibition of ten artists exploring AI as a means to be known and seen, to tell their stories, and to hold space for humanity. Curated by
Linda Dounia Rebeiz
, In/Visible presents new work by
Adaeze Okaro, Afroscope, Arclight, Jah, Linda Dounia, Minne Atairu, Nygilia, Rayan Elnayal, Serwah, and Zoe Osborne
.
The exhibition looks at AI as a tool of exclusion, and, as Linda Dounia Rebeiz puts it in their curator‚Äôs note, ‚Äúbrings together artists who are defiantly visible, telling their stories using AI, a tool that, itself, acknowledges its shortcomings in understanding them.‚Äù
In/Visible has been generating a lot of pre-exhibition excitement, including a
Hypebae feature
üôÇ
‚Äú
Don't miss this release ‚Äî I bet this will be one art historians will talk about decades from now‚Ä¶‚Äù¬†‚Äî
Phillip Gara
‚Äú!!!!‚Äù ‚Äî
Tina Rivers Ryan
And here‚Äôs a few of the artists in the exhibition, describing their works in their own words:
‚ÄúPlanet Hibiscus, #5‚Äù by Adaeze Okaro.
On their work ‚ÄúPlanet Hibiscus,‚Äù artist
Adaeze Okaro
writes that, ‚Äúwith the help of Midjourney, I imagined being sent as a photographer to document the coronation and wedding of the fictitious Planet Hibiscus‚Äô new monarch and her partner. I imagined shooting the experience on a medium-format film camera.‚Äù
‚ÄúConfetti, #7‚Äù by Nygilia.
‚ÄúI see life through vibrations,‚Äù writes
Nyglia
, on the experimental work ‚ÄúConfetti,‚Äù which embraces a disco aesthetic and dancehall immersion. ‚ÄúA summer‚Äôs night of dance, shining brighter with each camera flare. To feel the world is to believe in balance. There is no perfect memory. Only beautiful thoughts.‚Äù
Jah
, whose piece ‚ÄúThe Idunnos‚Äù is pictured above, explains that the work depicts ‚Äúbeings that reside in between the nexus of everything and nothing. They stand as gatekeepers in the liminal space where light meets darkness, where silence meets sound, where the known and the unknown converge.‚Äù If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with Jah‚Äôs work, be sure to read
this Twitter thread
, by way of introduction.
The works in In/Visible are minted on
Ethereum.
Update on pricing:
For
24 hours after collecting starts, artworks will be sold in sets for 0.55 ETH per set
. When you purchase a set, you receive an edition of each of the 10 artworks in the show.
After 24 hours, each artwork edition will be available for purchase individually, for 0.055 ETH per edition
.
The exhibition is
opening on
June 12 at 14:00 UTC
(7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai), with
collecting to begin an hour later
.

item.title: June on Feral File
item.description: June on Feral File
item.ns0:encoded:
June on Feral File: Linda Dounia Rebeiz curates In/Visible, Kim Asendorf show sells out, and big news forthcoming
Artwork by
Minne Atairu
, from the upcoming exhibition
In/Visible
New group show, works still available, and soon huge news
Opening June 12
,
In/Visible
presents new work by ten Black artists that explore AI as a means to be known and seen, to tell their stories, and to hold space for humanity. The artists featured are Adaeze Okaro, Afroscope, Arclight, Jah., Linda Dounia Rebeiz, Minne Atairu, Nygilia, Rayan Elnayal, Serwah Attafuah, and Zoe Osborne.
Artwork by
Serwah Attafuah
, from the upcoming exhibition
In/Visible
Last month, we released Kim Asendorf‚Äôs spectacular
COLORS OF NOISE
, which sold out in a matter of hours. As always, you can still
view the exhibition
on the site.¬† We also recently released Rick Silva‚Äôs
BLOOMCORE
, new work created from hundreds of 3D-scans of blooming flowers Rick captured in the Pacific Northwest last spring. There are still editions left of this epic artwork ‚Äî don‚Äôt miss out.
Meanwhile, we‚Äôre busy putting together two exhibitions that get at the very heart of Feral File‚Äôs work over the last years and feature an unreal number of the artists we most admire. It‚Äôs extremely exciting and hard not to talk about, but‚Ä¶ more on that soon.
Kim Asendorf everywhere
‚ÄúCOLORS OF NOISE‚Äù
, Kim Asendorf
Decrypt published a great interview with Kim Asendorf, also known as ‚Äú
The Metallica Video Director Who Makes NFT Art Designed to Hypnotize
.‚Äù Asendorf also has an interview in
Jing Daily
, and his recent exhibition COLORS OF NOISE was written-up in
FAD magazine
and
NFTcalendar.
And ICYMI: We published our own
interview between Kim and curator Peggy Schoenegge
, which covered everything from shades of noise to the role of the algorithm to how it was for Kim to bring his acoustic and visual practices together for his new work.
In other news‚Ä¶
Feral File artists are out there making headlines.
Peter Burr
‚Äôs Exhibition: ‚Äú
The Pixel Generation
‚Äù opens May 17 at Unit London, in collaboration with Right Click Save. Read more about it in an interview between Peter and Charlotte Kent, ‚Äú
PIXEL ART AND THE AGE OF TECHNOSTALGIA
.‚Äù And in July, Peter is launching a new digital artwork at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
Lauren Lee McCarthy
is the recipient of LACMA‚Äôs
2022 Art + Technology Lab Grant
and the new project
Surrogate
was also
written about in CreativeApplications.Net V5
. A
written interview
between Lauren and Bhumikorn Kongtaveelert and a
video conversation
between Lauren, Nora Khan, and Mindy Seu are now available online.
In acquisition news: the Whitney Museum of American Art has acquired
Auriea Harvey
‚Äôs work in conjunction with the exhibition
REFIGURED
! Auriea was also commissioned by the Whitney to create a project for Artport, the result of which is the brilliant
SITE1
.
Feral File 2.0 and Refik forever
Still from
‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA‚Äù,
Refik Anadol
During the weekend of May 19‚Äì21, we hosted a burn event for Refik Anadol‚Äôs
Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA
artwork. The work is a global AI data painting that simulates a latent walk among the Museum of Modern Art‚Äôs digitized collection and was minted as an edition of 5,000 as part of Refik‚Äôs
Unsupervised exhibition
on November 18, 2021.
The goal of the burn was to reduce the total supply of the artwork and reward Refik‚Äôs most loyal collectors. Collectors could opt to burn either 3, 6, or 9 editions of the work in exchange for 3 different reward tiers. Each tier featured a new digital artwork, a new physical work, and a day pass to the MoMA. The burn was a great success, reducing the total supply by 32.4%. All one hundred Tier 3 collections sold out, and 65 Tier 2 and 110 Tier 1 collections were redeemed.
Our team worked hard to bring this project to life, and we are thrilled with the outcome. Thanks to everyone at Refik Anadol Studio and MoMA who supported the project along the way!
And finally, we have some exciting news coming soon! All we‚Äôll say now is keep a look out for Feral File 2.0, which will include a new exhibition program,¬†a new way to collect works, and a totally refreshed look
üëÄ
Thanks for reading! We‚Äôll leave you with
this good tweet
.

item.title: Kim Asendorf‚Äôs new exhibition COLORS OF NOISE is coming soon to Feral File
item.description: Kim Asendorf‚Äôs new exhibition COLORS OF NOISE is coming soon to Feral File
item.ns0:encoded:
Kim Asendorf‚Äôs new exhibition COLORS OF NOISE is coming soon to Feral File
Join the Discord Conversation
Mark your calendars for our next exhibition, COLORS OF NOISE, showing new work by German visual artist Kim Asendorf.
For over a decade, the pixel has been the main building block in Asendorf's work, seemingly alive in his abstractions or rearranged in his iconic Pixel Sorting aesthetics.
For COLORS OF NOISE, curated by Peggy Schoenegge and opening on May 18, Asendorf has developed an algorithm that generates intricate and dynamic patterns of color-based noises, such as pink noise, brown noise, and white noise. These colored noises are visualized in a flickering mesh of lines, creating a moir√© pattern ‚Äî¬†different sounds have different effects, and the listener is directly drawn into the audio-visual experience, immersing into a multisensory artwork.
COLORS OF NOISE is a series of 50 unique artworks minted on Ethereum, 47 of which will be on sale for 0.25 ETH.
Exhibition Opening:
May 18, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
(7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
About Kim Asendorf:
Kim Asendorf is a German visual artist who works with conceptual strategies and generative systems to create abstract animations, images and sculptures. His abstract visual systems are conceptually set and realized in algorithms that are open to a wide range of interpretations. He works on a per-pixel level to create worlds that mix simplicity with complexity, that never sleep, and that can put the viewer in a mesmerizing state. He loves to experiment, is driven by curiosity, and finds satisfaction when the results of his work surprise himself. With roots in Net Art, he likes to keep his work easily accessible, and the Internet is his favorite canvas.
Asendorf also directed the music video for Metallica‚Äôs new song ‚Äú
Chasing Light
,‚Äù which premiered on April 19, 2023 and featured his work in the background.
Curator Peggy Schoenegge on COLORS OF NOISE:
‚ÄúCOLORS OF NOISE lies at the intersection of art and technology, combining Asendorf‚Äôs artistic practice with new technologies and physical laws. Drawing upon his expertise in programming, the artist has developed an algorithm that generates intricate and dynamic patterns of color-based noises. The algorithm processes these noises by shaping different frequencies, creating different properties of different colors. Their sonic qualities are translated into an artistic display of vibrant meshes of lines that evolve and transform with the changing soundscape. By transforming the immaterial sound waves into pixelated lines in black and white, an abstract flickering image appears that forms a moir√© pattern. It becomes an extension of the sonic experience. The network of lines visualizes the audio, emphasizing its characteristics and materializing the colored noise of the sound.‚Äù
Exhibition Opening:
May 18, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
(7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.

item.title: N=12 collecting starts in 1 hour
item.description: N=12 collecting starts in 1 hour
item.ns0:encoded:
Online Collecting begins in ~15 minutes:
E-volved Formulae
This exhibition includes 23 unique fixed-price works by Driessens & Verstappen. Sales open today (December 10, 2024) at 17:00 UTC+0‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss your chance to collect!
COLLECT NOW
Artificial evolution is a powerful process for creating moving images.
To initiate such a process, Driessens & Verstappen designed algorithms that mimic genetic evolution so that their visualizations can be "grown" rather than hand-coded. Each artwork commences with a unique formula that determines the value of each pixel from black to white. These basic mathematical operators invoke a process of variation and selection, so that each new generation of formulae becomes a window into a deeper, multi-dimensional field.
VIEW EXHIBITION
E-volved Formula #08¬†by Driessens & Verstappen
Collecting Mechanics
The
E-volved Formulae
sale will open on December 10, 2024 at 17:00 UTC+0. Each work will be offered for a fixed price of .5 ETH.
E-volved Formula #20 by Driessens & Verstappen
VIEW EXHIBITION
View
E-volved Formulae
at Home
Bring the exhibition home and view one artwork every day on your smart TV through the new Feral File Daily. Download the app today and enjoy Driessens & Verstappen‚Äôs dynamic works, right from your own living room.
GET THE APP
As always, feel free to reach out via
in-app support
if you have any questions.
Simply click the hamburger icon and navigate to Help.

item.title: N=12 collecting period is now Tuesday, July 25!
item.description: N=12 collecting period is now Tuesday, July 25!
item.ns0:encoded:
N=12 collecting period opens early next week
256 Kill-Screen
by
Daniel Catt
We're happy to announce that things are back on track to collect your¬†favorite sets from Feral File's latest exhibition,
N=12
.¬†The new collecting period will commence Tuesday, July 25, at 14:00 UTC+0 (22:00 Shanghai, 16:00 Berlin, 11:00 S√£o Paulo, 07:00¬†Los Angeles).
N=12
exhibition sets will be collected through a falling price auction.
The auction starts at an opening price and falls down to its final "base" price over a duration of 30 minutes. During the auction, you can collect a specific set once it reaches the price you desire. However, note that anyone can purchase that set before you (at a higher price) as well, so don't wait too long! If all sets are not sold in the first 30 minutes, remaining sets are sold at the base price for the next 23.5 hours. After this (24 hours from the start of the sale), any remaining sets are removed from sale at Feral File entirely.
Sets Available
130 sets available for collection
Each set is comprised of¬†12 artworks, one each from of the artists. Every artwork is unique.
Opening price: 7.20 ETH
Base price: 0.72 ETH
Collecting starts¬†Tuesday,¬†July 25, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
Collecting ends
Wednesday,¬†July 26, 2023 14:00 UTC+0
We also support collecting exhibition sets with your credit card.
The N=12 deep dive
Watch "N=12 Exhibition Notes" to experience the behind-the-scenes story of
N=12
.
N=12
is a collaborative group exhibition curated by Aaron Penne. Over the last several months, the twelve artists have been in dialogue across seven different time zones, sharing their code and artistic processes, and creating the works in the exhibition together. The exhibition was minted on Ethereum.The artists featured in N=12 are¬†Anna Lucia, Bart Simmons, Daniel Catt, Elsif, ippsketch, Lia Coleman, Melissa Wiederrecht, Nadieh Bremer, Nicole Vella, Piter Pasma, RalenArc, and Reva Fan.
Learn more about the artists' individual works and the processes behind them on our
N=12 YouTube¬†playlist
.
Please also download the free
N=12 Exhibition Catalog
for a deep dive into¬†Aaron Penne's curatorial vision, artist¬†process sketches, and beautiful documentation of all¬†finished works.
VIEW EXHIBITION
Introducing¬†Feral File 2.0
Feral File Co-Founder Casey Reas and Bitmark CEO, Sean Moss-Pultz, share¬†their vision for the next iteration of Feral File.
N=12
is the first exhibition in the new Feral File 2.0, which represents a major rework of our exhibition program. FF 2.0 presents¬†a new model to experience and collect exhibitions and a totally refreshed¬†look.It marks a return to our core values by doubling down on what makes Feral File unique in the on-chain art space:
Group exhibitions:
Artists on Feral File collaborate with a curator to create and exhibit artworks around a single, ambitious theme.
Works as series:
Each artist in an exhibition creates work as a series. A series contains multiple unique artworks connected together under a single series theme. Each series in an exhibition has the same number of artworks in it.
Collecting in sets:
Exhibitions are collected in sets that comprise one artwork from each series in an exhibition. Individual artworks are not offered for primary sale. Each set is unique, capturing a different facet of an exhibition‚Äôs full curatorial vision.
Multichain and fully web3:
Feral File 2.0 supports exhibitions on either Ethereum or Tezos and is fully compatible with current web3 standards.
Continued commitment to artist royalties:
Royalties are now streamed directly to artists, and additional¬†precautions have been taken to guarantee royalties on secondary markets.
Public documentation:
Much more attention is given to documenting, presenting, and preservation the events and other cultural production surrounding exhibitions.

item.title: New Exhibitions, OpenSea Optimizations, Win an Artwork
item.description: New Exhibitions, OpenSea Optimizations, Win an Artwork
item.ns0:encoded:
Note: broken link

https://feralfile.com
After 3 months, I‚Äôm back with lots of news to share. Read on to hear about how you can win an artwork from Casey Reas‚Äô collection, changes in how artworks are shown on OpenSea, and new tools around your Feral File account.
Also, if you missed them, check out our recent exhibitions. There‚Äôs still some
amazing work available to be collected
, or you can experience these exhibitions online.
Infinite Entropy
by Rafa√´l Rozendaal
Primordium
[Link removed ‚Äì no longer available]
by Sage Jenson, curated by Symbios.wiki
Field Guide
by Jared S Tarbell, Iskra Velitchkova, Sasha Belitskaja, Ilya Shkipin, Sofia Crespo, and curated by Artnome (Jason Bailey)
How Feral File Artworks are now Shown on OpenSea
Back in December
, I asked for your feedback on how Feral File was doing. While the feedback was (thankfully) overwhelmingly positive, we learned that we could improve our listings on OpenSea. It took some work to find the right contact at OpenSea and a lot of waiting as they worked through their backlog, but the integration is now complete. (You can read more about how Feral File editions can be migrated to Ethereum
in our FAQ
)
As an example, let‚Äôs look at
an artwork from Refik Anadol
. On OpenSea, you can now view an edition‚Äôs key information within the title. Search support for this information hasn‚Äôt been fully updated on the OpenSea side, but we‚Äôll continue to monitor and communicate with them to get this fully working. We‚Äôll also look to iterate upon these improvements with your feedback. To learn more about the specifics of the metadata formatting, see
our HackMD documentation
.
Win an Artwork
Help us in order to win a hand-picked artwork from Feral File co-creator Casey Reas.
We‚Äôre asking for help in two areas: 1) Help us find great people to make your Feral File experience better 2) Help us make your Autonomy experience better.
First, thanks to your support over the last year, we‚Äôre now in a position to build out the team. If you refer me to someone we end up hiring, Casey Reas will handpick an artwork edition for you! To follow up with me, send me an email at
michael@bitmark.com
. Include why you think I should consider this person, as well as their contact information. Think of your referral as their cover letter. We‚Äôre hiring for the following roles, all of which can be done from any location.
Business Development
Community Organizer and Program Curator ‚Äì Feral File
Design Lead
(2x)
Gallery Director ‚Äì Feral File
Growth Lead ‚Äì Autonomy
Product Manager ‚Äì Autonomy
Software Engineer
(3x)
Second, many of you are using our Autonomy app to view your NFT collections from the Ethereum, Bitmark (Feral File), and Tezos blockchains. I thank you because I know the app experience is still a bit rough in parts.
This is where we need help: help us find bugs! We will pay $20 into your Wyre wallet on Feral File if you can make Autonomy crash, $10 if you find incorrect data, and $5 for UI bugs. You‚Äôll also be entered in a drawing to win a Feral File (also handpicked by Casey) artwork in May. The bounty reward and drawing entry are given per each unique bug discovered. If multiple people submit the same bug, whoever submitted it first gets the bounty.
To receive your reward, message us in the autonomy-app channel on our
Discord server
or email
support@bitmark.com
. Include the steps we‚Äôll need to follow to replicate the bug, as well as your Feral File alias. Please note that this is only for new bugs ‚Äî you can check against our known issues on
Github
.
As a reminder, you can find Autonomy on
iPhone
and
Android
.
Web3 Wallet and other Enhancements
In 2022, we have been working hard on making Feral File even easier to use. For example, find these in
your account page
:
1) You can choose how you want to sign in to your account and authorize transactions - Email or Web3 wallet (ex. Metamask, Autonomy)
2) Coming this weekend: You can export a complete history of your Feral File transactions for personal archival or accounting purposes.
3) You can change your username at any time through the ‚ÄúAlias‚Äù at the top left of your account page.
We will also be rolling out enhancements to our next group auction to make the bidding process more transparent and enjoyable. These new changes are based on collector feedback and our own internal observations, so thank you to everyone who contributed to making it better.
Our Ethics
Last year, we saw an instance in which an NFT platform was accused of allowing insider trading. From this, we realized we needed to develop our own policy to make sure that everyone on our team understood the problem and to make a public commitment to enforce these ethics for the long-term development of the Feral File community. This was the result, as linked from the Feral File footer:
Employee Participation in Feral File Sales
No set of guidelines can account for every scenario. From these principles, Bitmark employees may not use their knowledge or private access to guide their or others‚Äô purchasing decisions on Feral File.
In application of these principles, Bitmark employees are prohibited from participating in any sale in which Feral File has an information advantage over the public. This includes both direct and indirect participation such as by funding a third party. For example, in highest bidder auctions, Feral File can view collector deposits and use that information to understand upcoming bids ‚Äî employees cannot participate in these auctions. With fixed price sales, however, Feral File has no special access to purchase before others ‚Äî employees may participate in purchasing.
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.
This email was sent to
*|EMAIL|*
why did I get this?

*|LIST:ADDRESSLINE|*]]>

item.title: Now Open: BOOM TOWN by Peter Burr on Ethereum
item.description: Now Open: BOOM TOWN by Peter Burr on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: BOOM TOWN by Peter Burr
Feral File
is pleased to announce BOOM TOWN, new media artist Peter Burr‚Äôs fictional neighborhood built and expanded on the blockchain. Each piece in BOOM TOWN, curated by Julia Kaganskiy, represents a unique, living artwork comprised of 1,000 images that will change over time, evolving as a kind of durational stop-motion animation over an undetermined period pegged to Ethereum‚Äôs block time‚Äîthat is, the length of time it takes to add another block to the blockchain.
In one hour, 12:00 PM EST, collecting starts with a highest bid auction of a complete set of all eight artworks, including 2 unique (1 of 1) artworks, starting at $3,675. This auction will last two hours. At 2:10¬†PM EST, individual editions will be made available for collecting at fixed prices.
In total, this exhibition features:
1 of 1: POWER PLANT ($1,000)
1 of 1: LUXURY HOME ($1,000)
3 editions : FACTORY($350)
3 editions: OFFICE PARK($350)
3 editions: SHOPPING PLAZA ($350)
3 editions: WAREHOUSE ($350)
12 editions: APARTMENT BLOCK ($250)
Open Edition: EMPTY LOT ($75)
Please note that any artworks that are sold in the set auction will not be available as individual editions.
Collectors receive the full set of images as part of their acquisition package and can browse or even create prints of the work‚Äôs past or future state, but they cannot make the work advance any faster or slower than block time. What will reach its end first, the work seems to be asking, the durational performance of BOOM TOWN? Or the technology it‚Äôs powered by? There‚Äôs only one way to find out.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on December 14 at 18:30 UTC (1:30pm EST).
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
Curator Julia Kaganskiy on BOOM TOWN:
‚ÄúLike most of his works, Peter Burr‚Äôs BOOM TOWN is a richly crafted narrative world that is deeply evocative while remaining mysterious and restrained. Displaying the artist‚Äôs gift for creating images and environments that hover on the boundary between abstraction and figuration, they invite the viewer to fill in the blanks with their own interpretation, suggesting a story that is barely legible yet unmistakably present. Inspired by the tools and aesthetics of video games, Burr‚Äôs compositions draw on generative dynamics and the complexity that emerges from simple, rule-based systems. Each of the eight works in BOOM TOWN follows a precise logic for generating the structure‚Äôs architecture, its ground and field, its shadows, planes, and colors. The resulting images are reminiscent of 8-bit video games and early computer graphics, as well as the flat diagrammatic quality of CAD architectural drawings.‚Äù
About Peter Burr:
Peter Burr is an artist from Brooklyn, New York. His practice often engages with tools of the video game industry in the form of immersive cinematic artworks. These pieces have been presented internationally by various institutions, including Documenta 14, Athens; MoMA PS1, New York; and The Barbican Centre, London.
Previously Burr worked under the alias Hooliganship and founded the video label Cartune Xprez through which he produced hundreds of live multimedia exhibitions and touring programs showcasing a multi-generational group of artists at the forefront of experimental animation. His practice has been recognized through grants and awards including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Creative Capital Grant, and a Sundance New Frontier Fellowship.
Preview of the artworks:
Every one of the structures in BOOM TOWN represents a unique, living artwork comprised of 1,000 images that will change over time, evolving as a kind of durational stop-motion animation over an undetermined period pegged to Ethereum‚Äôs block time ‚Äî that is, the length of time it takes to add another block to the blockchain. Collectors receive the full set of images as part of their acquisition package and can browse or even create prints of the work‚Äôs past or future state, but they cannot make the work advance any faster or slower than block time.
Burr‚Äôs process blends traditional animation techniques with the affordances of generative algorithmic systems. Each work originates with ‚Äúintentionally unoptimized algorithms‚Äù developed by Burr‚Äôs collaborator, Dave Tandem, and follows a precise composition logic that dictates its form, ground and field, shadows, planes, colors, and weight. The software allows Burr to draw structures on a gravity-influenced canvas and to animate them changing over time. Burr is interested in highlighting the unique fingerprints of various software and in his practice often works across tech pipelines to weave these diverse fingerprints into a unique aesthetic, reveling in the compression and dithering that occurs through this approach. The final images are outputted into a custom framework built by Tandem that uses block time to advance their evolution.
APARTMENT BLOCK
‚ÄúAPARTMENT BLOCK‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Like a chunk of houses glued together and cut into cubes, each with a standalone reality ‚Äî the apartment blocks aren‚Äôt meant to be good because the community enjoys the process of making them better.
FACTORY
‚ÄúFACTORY‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
We‚Äôll sustain half the town with a small factory.¬† The taller the smokestack, the better we‚Äôll spread our invisible byproducts.
SHOPPING PLAZA
‚ÄúSHOPPING PLAZA‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
A good town needs a few places to go when you‚Äôre bored. None of them are here, but the food court has an arcade.
View Now

item.title: Now Open: Chain Reaction, curated by Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
item.description: Now Open: Chain Reaction, curated by Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: Chain Reaction, curated by
Christiane Paul, minted on Ethereum
‚ÄúSeed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124‚Äù by Amelia Winger-Bearskin. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
View exhibition
Chain Reaction, an exhibition of inventive experimental gestures that set into motion a course of action, is now open for viewing. Curated by Christiane Paul, curator of digital art at the Whitney Museum, Chain Reaction features tokenized visual artworks by eight renowned artists, each of which emphasize the concept, process, and capacity to trigger events.
Featuring new artworks from:
Amelia Winger-Bearskin
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Ira Greenberg
and Marina Zurkow
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Alfredo Salazar-Caro
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Stephanie Dinkins
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Sara Ludy
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Jennifer and Kevin McCoy
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Each artwork will be released as an edition of 93, with each edition priced at $100 USD.
Exhibition Opening:
March 7, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour from opening.
Please join us right now on
Twitter Spaces
(March 7 at 14:00 UTC, 9am EST) for a conversation between the curator and the artists.
Curator Christiane Paul on Chain Reaction:
‚ÄúChain Reaction strives to underscore the inherent connections between the blockchain as a list of data blocks facilitating the recording of transactions and tracking of assets, and the generative social, aesthetic, and environmental contexts and networks in which these assets are embedded. The works in this exhibition explore their existence as ‚Äòtokens‚Äô beyond just being technological records of a transaction: they function as catalysts in precipitating events or actions, from environmental preservation and sustainability of a creative process to aesthetic choices. NFTs are functionally defined by their non-fungible status. They are capable of encapsulating and proving ownership of digital artworks that are often characterized by malleable, generative, untraceable, or imperceptible qualities. The artworks in Chain Reaction highlight the porous boundaries between NFTs as a mechanism for unique identification, on the one hand, and as a common ‚Äòkeepsake‚Äô of a social contract and commitment, or collective action, on the other.‚Äù
Preview of Selected Artworks:
‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù by Jennifer and Kevin McCoy. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Public View / Private View by Jennifer and Kevin McCoy
Jennifer and Kevin McCoy‚Äôs ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù opens up the artistic process of creation ‚Äî usually driven by artists‚Äô concepts and aesthetic choices ‚Äî to a community of donors and art supporters connected to the McCoys. Collectors receive an animated composite of a series of images that are based on pictures submitted to the McCoys by a group of donors of the artists‚Äô work who thereby participated in the NFT‚Äôs creation process. ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù is based on the McCoys‚Äô 2018 project ‚ÄúPublic Key / Private Key‚Äù for which they produced a short 16mm film, donated it to the Whitney Museum‚Äôs Special Collection, then issued 50 Ethereum ERC-721 tokens to represent the right to be named as one of the ‚Äúdonors of record‚Äù for the film and selected 50 donors from an open call for applications. The tokens were allowed to freely circulate for a period of six months. For ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View,‚Äù the McCoys asked these 50 donors of record to submit an image personally meaningful to them and created a coded interpretation of it. The interpretations of the donors‚Äô 50 images were then combined into the animation that collectors can purchase as NFT. The 50 donors receive an ink-on-paper version of the image. While ‚ÄúPublic Key / Private Key‚Äù made the donation process accessible to a wider public, ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù involves the donors in the creation process itself. Using the blockchain as authentication and distribution mechanism, the two projects form a creative chain that not only binds the artists as makers to an expanding community of interested supporters, but makes the nodes along the way a formal part of the work itself. In ‚ÄúPublic View / Private View‚Äù the blockchain anchors the creation, distribution, and archiving process of the artwork.
Seed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124 by Amelia Winger-Bearskin
(Image Above)
Amelia Winger-Bearskin‚Äôs ‚ÄúSeed Protocol - Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time (DLITE) 43:28:22.0004124‚Äù involves collectors in her ongoing artwork inspired by seeds and their caretakers. The NFT edition consists of an image of an identical pile of corn seeds that have been colored by the artist in 100 variations, wrapping the seeds in hand-drawn patterns. As still life, the seed piles imagine what the future seven generations of corn seeds might look like, suggesting textile and beading patterns or more alien mutations. Corn is one of the ‚Äúthree sisters‚Äù (corn, beans, and squash) according to the knowledge of the Haudenausaunee people. (Winger-Bearskin is an enrolled member of the Seneca-Cayuga Nation of Oklahoma, which is part of the Haudenosaunee confederacy.) The three sisters are grown together, giving nutrients, shade, and support. The ‚Äúseven generations‚Äù concept reminds us that our current knowledge is built on that of the seven generations before us, and that we must make good decisions for our descendants seven generations in the future.
Each of the seed pile variations has a unique DLITE (Dynamical Lunar Indigenous Time) number, riffing on the Terrestrial Dynamical Time that NASA uses as a timestamp for celestial voyages.¬†The future that Winger-Bearskin imagines for seeds is inspired in equal parts by several sources: the celestial storytelling of the Seneca-Cayuga; NASA‚Äôs Project Artemis; as well as the work of her colleagues‚Äô Robert Ferl and Anna-Lisa Paul, plant molecular biologists who lead a team focused on growing plants in space at the University of Florida Space Plant Lab.
Along with the NFT, collectors receive a participation contract and access to the Seed Protocol website, asking¬† them to contribute to the larger seed protocol project. They will receive regular updates on all online and in-person events related to Seed Protocol project 2023-2024. Collectors will also play an active role in shaping the project by agreeing to make contributions: engaging with a local seed bank or heirloom seed society in their area and uploading information about the organization to Amelia Winger-Bearskin‚Äôs Seed Bank Directory or engaging with one of the seed groups with whom the artist is working.
‚ÄúThe Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater‚Äù by Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
The Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater by Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow
Ira Greenberg and Marina Zurkow‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Dorises - Oystercraft from silicon to saltwater‚Äù allows collectors to purchase an oyster, a unique NFT in the digital ocean. While the outsides of the oyster shells are similar, there are categories and variations across the 100 oysters in the edition. The insides are structured through custom generative software according to four categories, each based on an aspect of oyster physiology, purpose, and lore: Oyster Engineer (plumbing, cleaning, sifting, filtering machinery); Oyster Artist (creating beauty, wonder, inspiration, well-being); Oyster Sex Symbol (aphrodisiacal and sex-changing); and Oyster Kin (with humans who ‚Äúfarm‚Äù and eat them). The artists used AI to generate the oyster elements and backgrounds; embedded across the four categories are fifteen unique surprises, with varying degrees of rarity.
Along with their oyster, collectors receive a unique password that gives them access to the OysterCraftReef website, where they see their NFT come together with the other collected oysters to form a visual reef. As a collective structure, the oyster reef supports real-world projects such as oyster reef cultivation, conservation, and awareness work. After no more than 90 days after the birth of the reef, collectors will vote on distributing the funds generated through their purchase to three different groups supporting oyster reef conservation, which has been identified by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) as a priority. The project title, ‚ÄúThe Dorises,‚Äù alludes to Doris, a sea goddess in Greek mythology. Doris was one of the 3000 Oceanids, daughters of the Titans Oceanus and Tethys, and represents the fertility of the ocean. Her name connects the two words¬†D√¥ron, meaning ‚Äúgift‚Äù or ‚Äúabundance,‚Äù and¬†Z√¥ros, meaning the ‚Äúpure‚Äù and ‚Äúunmixed,‚Äù often used to describe fresh water.

item.title: Now Open: FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
item.description: Now Open: FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: FeralVerse, our first poetry exhibition, curated by theVERSEverse on Tezos
Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
View exhibition
Please join us for a
Twitter Spaces
today at 15:00 UTC+0 (11am EST)¬†for a conversation between the curator and the artists.
Feral File
is pleased to open FeralVerse, an exhibition that explores the myriad ways in which words and image intertwine. Curated by
theVERSEverse
, a collective of poets, artists, and technologists interested in the creative potential for poetry on the blockchain, FeralVerse is the first exhibition of verse on Feral File. It includes 10 new works, each of which is a collaboration between a writer and an artist and each offered as an edition of 50.
Featuring new artworks from:
Victoria Chang
x
Alexandra Crouwers
Lillian Yvonne Bertram
x
Dina Chang
P. Scott Cunningham
x
Connie Bakshi
John James
x
Solim√°n L√≥pez
Seth Bockley
x
Helena Sarin
Denise Duhamel
x
Diane Drubay
Ana
Mar√≠a
Caballero
x
Nancy Baker-Cahill
Kalen Iwamoto
x
Julien Silvano
Sasha Stiles
x
Nathaniel Stern
Marci Calabretta Cancio-Bello
x
Gretta Louw
In true literary form, FeralVerse will be initially offered as an anthology to collectors: for the first 72 hours, all 10 of the artworks in the exhibition will be sold together in sets for $1,000 USD. Collectors of the full set will receive an exclusive edition of a poem written by VERSA, theVERSEverse's emergent AI poet, trained on the corpus of poems published by this literary gallery. This poem was seeded using words from the poems in FeralVerse.
Any sets remaining after 72 hours will be broken into individual editions, with each edition priced at $100 USD, until April 16 at 14:00 UTC +0.
Exhibition Opening:
April 6, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins in one hour.
Curators Sasha Stiles, Kalen Iwamoto, and Ana Mar√≠a Caballero (theVERSEverse) on FeralVerse:
‚ÄúOur Feral File offering ‚Äî the first exhibition of verse on this platform ‚Äî is planted here as a seed for the poetry journal of the future, in which authorial imagination is unbounded, language and art exist in symbiosis, and every contributor is a vital force in a literary ecosystem in which connection to verse can lead to collection.
In celebration of both National Poetry Month and Earth Month, the texts published here as non-fungible Tezos tokens ‚Äì each a collaborative performance between writers and artists at the avant-garde of web3 poetry, including some of the planet‚Äôs most renowned voices ‚Äì reflect diverse perspectives, aesthetics, and approaches to the worlds around us and inside us, always in flux. Every work invites its reader to step into a reality augmented through the art of poetry, and to engage deeply with the untamed universe of possibilities for writers on (and off) the blockchain.‚Äù
About theVERSEverse:
Launched in November 2021, theVERSEverse is a collective of critically acclaimed poets, writers, artists, and creative technologists working on and off the blockchain to unlock the literary potential of web3. Through hybrid events, community outreach, and partnerships, theVERSEverse is creating new opportunities for writers and reshaping the future of literature.
Preview of Selected Artworks:
‚ÄúSpring So Uneasy‚Äù by Lillian-Yvonne Bertram x Dina Chang. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
Spring So Uneasy by Lillian-Yvonne Bertram x Dina Chang
‚ÄúSpring So Uneasy‚Äù is a collaboration between poet Lillian-Yvonne Bertram and artist Dina Chang, in which Chang‚Äôs visuals provide a stunning photographic take on Bertram‚Äôs poem ‚ÄúThe Body Deformed by Tidal Forces.‚Äù The poem is a muscular lyrical meditation on the physics of tidal forces that simultaneously create solidity and changes of season through rotation and gravitational push/pull and threaten destruction when the same forces of these rotating celestial bodies are brought into too close a contact to sustain their individual integrities. The same phenomenon, Bertram suggests, literally and figuratively applies to earth-bound human bodies and the ways people too are bound to an ungodly planet spinning ferociously through the cosmos.
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù by Seth Bockley x Helena Sarin. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù by Seth Bockley x Helena Sarin
‚ÄúNotes From A Hackberry Seed‚Äù is part of Seth Bockley‚Äôs Nature Speaks! series. This initiative, created through the poet‚Äôs position as director of creative engagement for Sovereign Nature Initiative, a web3 tech/theory/art collective, imagines giving human voice to nonhuman experiences, while recognizing the impossibility of fully translating those experiences. Helena Sarin‚Äôs visual rendering pays homage to the hackberry seed itself, the wood of the tree, its germination, pulsating, becoming, and the smile and energy with which the poet delivers the poem.
‚ÄúFuturum Febris‚Äù by Denise Duhamel x Diane Drubay. Image courtesy of theVERSEverse and Feral File.
Futurum Febris by Denise Duhamel x Diane Drubay
‚ÄúFuturum Febris,‚Äù fruit of the collaboration between the poet Denise Duhamel and visual artist Diane Drubay, takes us on a journey towards a distressing transcendence. The planet becomes a metaphor for the memories and thoughts of the narrator of ‚ÄúPilgrims,‚Äù Duhamel‚Äôs poem. Like a path that accompanies the text, going from the naivety of youth to the realization of a conflicting system, the exploration of the two planets invites us to travel towards a feverish future.
The visual piece is composed of an excerpt from Duhamel‚Äôs poem ‚ÄúPilgrims,‚Äù encircling the planets like a blue guiding thread. The two rotating 3D objects are covered with photographs of interference colors captured in the sky. One is calming and peaceful, creating a meditative state and a moment of harmony. The second is heated and alarming, causing a sense of fascination and panic at the same time. Drubay uses psycho-active colors and the feeling of total isolation to heighten the senses and embrace new ideas and perspectives.
This work plays with a descriptive narrative that takes the viewer/reader into a scene of changing emotions and states, calling for transformation by creating true impact.

item.title: Now Open: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
item.description: Now Open: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
Turandot 2070, Lovers I
by AES+F. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
View exhibition
Feral File
and
synthesis gallery
are pleased to announce I Know, an exhibition exploring what an aesthetic of truth might be. Curated by Giorgio Vitale, I Know features an intergenerational group of five artists, each embracing very different aesthetics and artistic strategies. Their works in the show address anxieties about the turmoil we are now experiencing around the world and offer critical reflections on it.
Featuring new artworks from:
aaajiao

Exhibition Opening:
February 2, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
A physical installation of I Know will also be at
Transmediale/Vorspiel
in Berlin.
Visit the exhibition:
February 2-5, 2023
Salon am Moritzplatz
Oranienstrasse 58, 10969
Join us for a series of conversations
Please join us for a series of conversations between the curator and the artists.
Today, February 2, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
OPENING I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with all of the artists in the show and the curator
Sunday, February 5, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
SECOND I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with aaajiao, Cibelle Cavalli Bastos, and Claudia Hart
Sunday, February 5, 18:00 UTC+0 (7pm CET)
INSTAGRAM LIVE
curator tour with Giorgio Vitale from the physical exhibition in Berlin
Tuesday, February 7, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
THIRD I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with Yehwan Song and AES+F
Curator Giorgio Vitale on I Know:
‚ÄúThe ‚Äòtruth‚Äô considered in this exhibition is not a scientific or academic one, but rather an imaginative one. It is based on the slow unfolding that viewers experience when they sit with an artwork. In our current post-truth society, in which veracity and accuracy are sacrificed on the altar of hyperbole and misinformation, I Know invites artists to reexamine historical moments and to evoke images of the past in order to claim a place within it. These artists struggle with power, inequality, and discrimination, addressing debates about mass surveillance and the architecture of the web3. The works in the exhibition reflect on traditional modes of thinking, both inside of and outside of the arts, and in so doing make way for future possibilities.‚Äù

item.title: Now Open: LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
item.description: Now Open: LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works from a pioneer of digital art, minted on Tezos
‚ÄúLMG4.PCX‚Äù by Lee Mullican. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
View exhibition
Please join us right now for a
Twitter Spaces
conversation between curator Anika Meier, Cole Root, director of the Estate of Lee Mullican,¬†Alex Estorick,¬†writer and editor-in-chief of Right Click Save,¬†and Susanne P√§ch, wife of Herbert W. Franke.
Feral File
is pleased to open LeeMullican.PCX, an exhibition of early computer works by Lee Mullican (1919-1998), a renowned painter and pioneer of digital art. An institutionally recognized painter with works in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, among others, Mullican started making digital art in 1986, at the age of 66. Curated by Anika Meier in collaboration with Cole Root, director of the Estate of Lee Mullican, this exhibition features 12 of Mullican‚Äôs digital works. Each artwork will be released as an edition of 20.
The exhibition will be sold initially through 20 sets featuring an edition of all 12 artworks for $2,400. Sets will be sold for the first 24 hours; any remaining sets will then be broken up into individual editions¬†priced at $200 USD.
Exhibition Opening:
March 23, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins in one hour
Curator Anika Meier on LEEMULLICAN.PCX:
‚ÄúAs a pioneer of computer art, Lee Mullican has devoted his life to finding new ways to create images. He embraced new technologies and tools of the day. In the fall of¬†1986, Lee Mullican participated in UCLA‚Äôs Advanced Design Research Center‚Äôs Program for Technology in the Arts. The program allowed the then¬†66-year-old Mullican to start exploring the digital realm.
The exhibition LeeMullican.PCX presents 12 NFTs that demonstrate the artist‚Äôs relentless experimentation. Mullican is an institutionally recognized painter, he is in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, among others. He skillfully used his knowledge of painterly techniques as a guide when he began working with computers and found common ground with his own style of painting and the chance made possible by the computer.‚Äù
About Lee Mullican:
Lee Mullican was born in 1919 in Chickasha, Oklahoma and died in Los Angeles in 1998. Upon his graduation from the Kansas City Art Institute in 1942, Mullican was drafted into the army, serving four years as a topographical draftsman before moving to San Francisco in 1946.
After winning a prestigious Guggenheim Fellowship in 1959, he spent a year painting in Rome before returning to Los Angeles where he joined the UCLA Art Department in 1961, keeping his position for nearly 30 years. He divided the later part of his life between his homes in Los Angeles and Taos, traveling internationally and co-organizing exhibitions at UCLA. A retrospective spanning 50 years of the artist‚Äôs work was organized by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2005.
Mullican is in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, New York; the San Francisco Museum of Art; the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles; and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, among others.

item.title: Now open: Peer to Peer, the first survey of the leading artists engaged with blockchains presented by an American museum.
item.description: Now open: Peer to Peer, the first survey of the leading artists engaged with blockchains presented by an American museum.
item.ns0:encoded:
We are pleased to announce that
Peer to Peer
, organized with
Buffalo AKG Art Museum
and curated by
Dr. Tina Rivers Ryan
, is now open.
Please join us today
on Discord
or on
Twitter Spaces
at 16:00 UTC for an opening conversation between curator Tina Rivers Ryan and artists LaTurbo Avedon, Simon Denny, Sarah Friend, and Rhea Myers. See below for upcoming Twitter Spaces conversations with the other artists in the show.
Collecting will begin next week from November 29 to December 2;
those details are now viewable on the exhibition pages
.
About the show:
Peer to Peer is the first survey of the leading artists engaged with blockchains presented by an American museum. The exhibition stages exchanges between these artists and their historical ‚Äúpeers‚Äù in the Buffalo AKG‚Äôs iconic collection of modern and contemporary art, highlighting the continued relevance of the historical ‚Äúpeers‚Äù and the contributions of the emerging ‚Äúpeers‚Äù to art‚Äôs expanding network of ideas.
Peer to Peer features 13 new artworks from:
LaTurbo Avedon
Mitchell F. Chan
Entangled Others
(Sofia Crespo and Feileacan McCormick)
Simon Denny
Amir H. Fallah
Sarah Friend
Auriea Harvey
Rhea Myers
Osinachi
Casey Reas
Anne Spalter
Itzel Yard
(aka Ix Shells)
Sarah Zucker
Half the proceeds from the sales will benefit the museum, which reopens in 2023 with a state-of-the-art gallery dedicated to media art and a hands-on digital technology lab.
Join us for a series of conversations
Mark your calendars for a series of conversations between the curator and the artists.

on abstraction/AI/generative art with:
Entangled Others, Casey Reas, Anne Spalter, Itzel Yard
If you will be in Miami for Art Week, please join the AKG team at the Peer to Peer

on November 29 at the Mondrian South Beach. VIP tickets benefit the museum; a limited number of public tickets will be released soon, depending on availability.

open for viewing now

item.title: Now Open: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
item.description: Now Open: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: Rick Silva‚Äôs Solo Exhibition BLOOMCORE
‚ÄúBLOOMCORE‚Äù by Rick Silva. Image courtesy of Feral File and the artist.
View exhibition
Opening now, BLOOMCORE is an exhibition of a new series by Rick Silva, curated by Claire L. Evans.
Last year, Silva 3D-scanned hundreds of blooming plants throughout the Pacific Northwest, which he later grafted and pruned into a hyper-flora. In 30-second looping videos, eerie vegetal forms rotate and slice through a fog of atmospheric lights. The series, also titled BLOOMCORE, will be available in
a series of 55 unique artworks
, each priced at .25 ETH.
Exhibition Opening:
April 20, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins in one hour
Curator Claire L. Evans on BLOOMCORE:
‚ÄúIn Silva‚Äôs BLOOMCORE, we encounter beings familiar, yet unknown, and unknowable. Lush rhododendrons, broad-leaved ferns, rare roses, denizens of deep forests: scanned in the spring of 2022, they are each presented in full bloom, at the height of their lives and thus also on the brink of death. As I write these words, most of the real-life plants Silva has volumetrically captured are almost certainly dead, but they‚Äôll remain preserved in perpetuity, on the blockchain, like museum specimens. To me this is profoundly gothic ‚Äî these blooms hanging outside of time in the radiant computational darkness, promising transcendence, concealing poison (Silva has even included a few poisonous pitcher plants in this collection, vegetal carnivores with alluring, vaselike forms). In this he summons the vast dreaming life of plants, their hidden, distributed way of knowing, their collective ancientness, and the slow, halting way they move across the world.‚Äù
About Rick Silva:
Rick Silva
is a Brazilian-American artist whose videos, websites, and installations explore virtuality, futurology, and speculative ecologies. His work has been exhibited at institutions including The Centre Pompidou, Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth, and The Whitney Museum of American Art. He has been featured in Artforum, Wired, and Rhizome‚Äôs NET ART Anthology. He lives in Eugene, Oregon where he is an Associate Professor at The University of Oregon.
Preview of Selected Artworks:
‚ÄúBLOOMCORE‚Äù by Rick Silva. Images courtesy of Feral File and the artist.
In the spring and summer of 2022, artist Rick Silva 3D-scanned living plants throughout the Pacific Northwest ‚Äî in university greenhouses, coastal redwoods, the high desert, and the Cascade mountains. Following this field work, Silva grafted and pruned the digitized plants into an eternal hyper-flora that rotates and slices through a fog of atmospheric lights. His eerie vegetal forms hover at the edges of representation and abstraction, digital and organic, familiar and alien.
Join the Discord Conversation

item.title: Opening In 2 hours: Feral File #015 ‚Äî Ten Whistlegraphs Opens May 20th
item.description: Opening In 2 hours: Feral File #015 ‚Äî Ten Whistlegraphs Opens May 20th
item.ns0:encoded:
Ten Whistlegraphs
Announcing a new solo exhibition with artist group Whistlegraph
Exhibition Opening:
May 20, 2022
02:30 UTC+0 (19 May 7:30pm Los Angeles, 19 May 11:30pm S√£o Paulo, 4:30am Berlin, 10:30am Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúLoner‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs new solo exhibition with artist group Whistlegraph, who have created ten ‚Äúwhistlegraphs‚Äù ‚Äî an original art form of scored musical drawings ‚Äî for the show. Each work will be auctioned to the highest bidder. (
Please see the Price List for complete detail
)
Writer Dorothy Rose Howard on Ten Whistlegraphs:
‚ÄúIn Whistlegraph‚Äôs first solo show and exhibition, the artist group (Jeffrey Scudder, Camille Klein, Alex Freundlich) presents a new body of work featuring creative documentation of a selection of ‚Äúwhistlegraphs‚Äù ‚Äî memorizable lyrical poems that double as graphic scores, resulting in reproducible drawings.
Blending drawing with live performance documentation is Whistlegraph‚Äôs bread and butter; and it is this evasion of capture that also makes artifacts of their work so limitless. A set of files make up each of the ten whistlegraphs curated for Feral File ‚Äî a high definition video performance and graphic score made for the exhibition, in addition to a curated selection of TikToks of that same work, accessible through a custom interactive player. Each whistlegraph piece by the group has generated countless media artifacts and recordings in the form of social media posts (by Whistlegraph and fans alike), works on paper, and live recitals. Part of the beauty of this format is that once you grok it, you can make a whistlegraph yourself. Indeed many do write their own whistlegraphs‚Äîor interact with the group‚Äôs in the form of duets, mashups, and sing-alongs to the tune of digital folk.‚Äù
The show is accompanied by a text written by Dorothy Rose Howard.
About Whistlegraph
Whistlegraph
is composed of artists Jeffrey Scudder, Camille Klein, and Alex Freundlich, who draw, sing, and make videos together. The group formed during the 2020 pandemic in a cabin in Ashland, Oregon, which remains their creative base. Over the past few years, they have honed a distinctive style and practice that speaks to embodied cognition, art education, and experimental composition for live performance.
The group‚Äôs TikTok
@whistlegraph
is an important platform for their work, where they regularly engage with their 2.2 million current followers. Whistlegraph has also toured, performed, and led educational workshops at Kunstverein Hamburg (Germany), Rhizome, The Schneider Museum of Art (Ashland, OR), Oneroom Gallery (Providence, RI), Willem de Kooning Acadamie (Rotterdam, Netherlands), OCCII (Amsterdam, Netherlands), and the Banana School (Bananskole; Copenhagen, Denmark).
Preview of the Artworks:
Loner
(Pictured Above)
Lyrics:
Sitting curled up in myself
I think of a stone, just
waiting very patiently
for time to pass
For this exhibition, ‚ÄúLoner‚Äù is performed by its composer Camille Klein using a Kaweco Sport fountain pen on her Exacompta Bloc FAF Desk Pad.
‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
Mommy Wow
Lyrics:
Here‚Äôs my zigzag
X my circle
PSHH! PEW!
I love mommy WOWWWW
‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù was composed improvisationally by Whistlegraph, each member taking turns. For this exhibition, ‚ÄúMommy Wow‚Äù is performed in the evening by Whistlegraph outside of the Schneider Museum of Art with Hagoromo Luminous chalk on brick.
‚ÄúPeople Pleaser‚Äù by Whistlegraph. Image courtesy of the artists and Feral File.
People Pleaser
Lyrics:
When you‚Äôre told ‚ÄúAmazing! Incredible‚Äù best beware
Someone‚Äôs always saying, words you wanna hear
Products of low self-esteem,
peacefully prove their being mildly mean
to those around them
At the time of its composition by Jeffrey Scudder, ‚ÄúPeople Pleaser‚Äù was the longest whistlegraph in the groups‚Äô repertoire. It is rendered here by Whistlegraph in pencil on a Kamiterior Memoterior Colors Memo Pad.

item.title: Opening Now: Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
item.description: Opening Now: Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Opening Now: Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
Gray Matter¬†is now open on
Feral File
. Join us on
Twitter Spaces
in 6¬†hours (20:00 UTC, 12PM PST, 3PM EST) for a talk with curator Gaia Bob√≤¬†and Auriea Harvey.
Auriea Harvey
‚Äôs solo exhibition
Gray Matter
, curated by Gaia Bob√≤, features eleven interactive sculptures originating from scans of new physical works: assemblages composed of previously discarded fragments and 3D prints. Auctioned pieces are accompanied by a physical bronze sculpture and all works come with 3D printable files.
Eight editions of 8 artworks will be available for sale at a per edition fixed price of $1,000. Three 1:1 artworks will be (highest bid) auctioned at a starting price of $5,000.¬† One artwork will be available as an unlimited (open) edition for $100.
Exhibition Opening:
November 10, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
‚ÄúGray Matter‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce
Gray Matter
, a new solo exhibition by artist Auriea Harvey, curated by Gaia Bob√≤.
Curator Gaia Bob√≤ on Gray Matter:
‚ÄúAuriea Harvey‚Äôs solo show
Gray Matter
presents a body of work emerging from an undefined and fluid ambient, where mud-like protoplasm is molded from a neutral background, solidifying into metaphysical apparitions. These data-based objects are marked by the memory of their material roots, similarly to archeological artifacts or witnesses. Indeed, the artist plays with the tools of archaeological research in the creation of her mythology and methodology. Auriea uses polygons in place of plaster, staging a non-literal and paradoxical practice of casting in a ping-ponging circularity from the sensual world to the digital one and back again. As in Pompeii‚Äôs casts, where the transition from the void left by an incinerated body is impressed into the durable matter of a plaster form, the artist seeks that continuum in the tension between ethereal and corporal, attempting to answer the question: what is this void made of?‚Äù
About Auriea Harvey:
Auriea Harvey is a sculptor living and working in Rome. Her practice encompasses virtual and tangible sculptures, drawings, and simulations that blend digital and handmade production including 3D printing, AR, and VR. She is primarily concerned with making the mythological world visible through form, interaction, and immersion. Her works are a synthesis of art historical reference and imagination. And she is engaged across time, media, and material to define what sculptural production means in the present moment. She is half of the artist duo which over time has been known as Entropy8Zuper!/Tale of Tales/Song of Songs, award-winning for their pioneering works in Internet art, video games, and mixed reality. Her work can be found in the permanent collections of institutions such as Buffalo AKG Art Museum, Walker Art Center, KADIST Collection,¬† RF.C Collection, and Rhizome‚Äôs Net Art Anthology. Her videogames and VR works have had international success, including exhibitions at the Tinguely Museum, Basel; the Victoria & Albert Museum, London; the New Museum, New York; Brooklyn Academy of Music, New York; and ZKM, Karlsruhe.
Preview of the Artworks:
Gray Matter
(pictured above)
‚ÄúGray Matter,‚Äù the work that gives its name to the exhibition, is a statement on indefiniteness in the matter of thought: a triple portrait of a girl, a cyclops inside the cave of her mind with a candle-like flame burning at its eye, and a stylized emerging skull, all suspended in a gray infinity. The possibilities of interaction highlight the implicit potential in stretching, distorting, and playing with the materiality of the digital polygon, shifting perception and meaning.
AlleluiaAlleluia
‚ÄúAlleluiaAlleluia‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In ‚ÄúAlleluiaAlleluia,‚Äù a singing, polymorphic being swings in a zero-gravity nocturnal background, with two moon wedges positioned at the extremities of the piece, creating a mesmerizing atmosphere. Here, the self-portrait of the artist is combined with a scan of one wing of the Nike of Samothrace.
Messenger (fragment)
‚ÄúMessenger (fragment)‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
The perceptive experience of the work ‚ÄúMessenger (fragment)‚Äù is a sense of disorientation given by a glitch that occurred while scanning, which turned the bottom of the original sculpture into a cloud-like mass. Amplifying the impossibility of catching the whole ensemble of this sculpture all at once, in this digital piece, everything floats.
View Now

item.title: Opening Now: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
item.description: Opening Now: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
item.ns0:encoded:
Opening Now: I Know, an exhibition on the aesthetic of truth
‚ÄúTurandot 2070‚Äù by AES+F. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
synthesis gallery
are pleased to announce I Know, an exhibition exploring what an aesthetic of truth might be. Curated by Giorgio Vitale, I Know features an intergenerational group of five artists, each embracing very different aesthetics and artistic strategies. Their works in the show address anxieties about the turmoil we are now experiencing around the world and offer critical reflections on it.
Featuring new artworks from:
aaajiao
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
AES+F
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Cibelle Cavalli Bastos
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Claudia Hart
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Yehwan Song
Twitter
|
Instagram
|
Website
Exhibition Opening:
February 2, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Add the exhibition to
Google Calendar
, or
Apple Calendar
.
Join us on Discord
Mark your calendars for a series of conversations between the curator and the artists.
Thursday, February 2, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
OPENING I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with all of the artists in the show and the curator
Sunday, February 5, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
SECOND I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with aaajiao, Yehwan Song, and Claudia Hart
Sunday, February 5, 18:00 UTC+0 (7pm CET)
INSTAGRAM LIVE
curator tour with Giorgio Vitale from the physical exhibition in Berlin
Tuesday, February 7, 17:00 UTC+0 (6pm CET)
THIRD I KNOW TWITTER SPACE
with Cavalli Bastos and AES+F
Curator Giorgio Vitale on I Know:
‚ÄúThe ‚Äòtruth‚Äô considered in this exhibition is not a scientific or academic one, but rather an imaginative one. It is based on the slow unfolding that viewers experience when they sit with an artwork. In our current post-truth society, in which veracity and accuracy are sacrificed on the altar of hyperbole and misinformation, I Know invites artists to reexamine historical moments and to evoke images of the past in order to claim a place within it. These artists struggle with power, inequality, and discrimination, addressing debates about mass surveillance and the architecture of the web3. The works in the exhibition reflect on traditional modes of thinking, both inside of and outside of the arts, and in so doing make way for future possibilities.‚Äù
Exhibition Opening:
February 2, 2023
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
