item.title: Opening Now: Julia Kaganskiy's Harbingers including Zach Blas, Sofia Crespo et al.
item.description: Opening Now: Julia Kaganskiy's Harbingers including Zach Blas, Sofia Crespo et al.
item.ns0:encoded:
Opening Now:¬†Julia Kaganskiy's Harbingers including Zach Blas, Sofia Crespo et al.
Harbingers is open now on
Feral File
. Join us on
Twitter Spaces
in 3 hours (17:00 UTC, 10AM PST, 1PM EST) for a talk with curator Julia Kaganskiy and exhibition artists. For more information on this exciting innovative exhibition, read on below.
Julia Kaganskiy
curates
Harbingers
, the new Feral File exhibition bringing together a bestiary of the posthuman.¬†Harbingers takes on a new, experimental approach, using blockchain data to manipulate and mutate each artwork. Every time the works are sold and traded on-chain, a random glitching process will progressively distort the works.
Harbingers features 14 new artworks in total from:
Zach Blas
Pinar Yoldas
Ricardo Dominguez / *particle group*
Shu Lea Cheang
Sofia Crespo
33¬†editions of each artwork¬†will be available for sale at a per edition price of $75. Of these editions, 10¬†will be initially available only in exhibition sets during the exhibition's first twenty-four hours¬†for¬†$1,050¬†($75¬†√ó 14¬†artworks).
Exhibition Opening:
September 28, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
‚ÄúGeneric Mannequin Gets Flayed‚Äù by Zach Blas. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce Harbingers, an exhibition of five international artists assembling visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties.
Curator Julia Kaganskiy on the exhibition:
‚ÄúFor millennia, speculations about how technoscientific innovations could transform living organisms ‚Äî by accident or design ‚Äî have animated our imaginaries of cyborgs, mutants, automatons, and replicants. As our environment becomes increasingly synthetic, polluted, and governed by planetary-scale computation, what kind of lifeforms will it support?
The group show Harbingers brings together a bestiary of the posthuman, assembling artistic visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties in an age of accelerated biosocial transformation. A menagerie of mutant creatures emerges from the recombinant crucible of computational manipulation, genetic engineering, viral mutation, biohacking, and cross-species contamination. Novel corporeal formations, at once familiar and strange, are produced through complex interrelations of nature, culture, and technology. Modernity becomes an agent of metamorphosis through the vectors of engineering, adaptation, and aberration. Each work in Harbingers offers a portal into a fabulated mirror world governed by its own mythology. The organisms assembled here include coded chimeras, genetically modified superhumans, bodies held captive by the algorithmic surround, and plants and animals that have evolved to metabolize plastics and toxic waste. All serve as sentinels of the transfigurative powers of technology and ecocide.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Generic Mannequin Gets Flayed
(pictured above)
‚Äú
Generic Mannequin Gets Flayed‚Äù is a corporate term for digital representations of bodies that are examined for risks and anomalies during airport body scans. Zach Blas appropriated this non-image in his installation ‚ÄúSANCTUM‚Äù (2018), a security-detention-center-meets-sex-dungeon environment that probes the dynamics of power, exposure, and desire inherent in surveillance and predictive policing through the lens of BDSM. Rendered silent and pliant through biometric capture, we see the mannequin bound, whipped, contained, and harvested for use in the creation of new weapons or sex toys. By invoking queer aesthetics and consentual power play, Blas leaves the question of complicity up for debate ‚Äî are the mannequins prisoners, sex slaves, worshippers, or experimental test subjects? The work‚Äôs ambiguity problematizes our symbiotic relationship with technology, examining the nature of personal agency, surveillance, and control in a world shaped by data mining and social engineering.
LES MUTANTS, #3
‚ÄúLES MUTANTS, #3‚Äù by Shu Lea Cheang. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
This excerpt from UKI, Shu Lea Cheang‚Äôs forthcoming feature length sci-fi viral cinema, recounts the adventures of Reiko, a de-commissioned replicant. UKI is the sequel to Cheang‚Äôs iconic cyberpunk porn film I.K.U. (2000), which tells the story of biotech company Genom Corporation and its plan to harvest orgasm data to engineer and sell addictive orgasms. Discarded on the toxic waste dump E-trashville, Reiko encounters Les Mutants, creatures who have evolved over generations of e-trash remixing, toxic pollution, and viral infection. Les Mutants help Reiko reboot themself back to existence and transform into¬† the virus UKI, capable of infiltrating and sabotaging Genom Corp‚Äôs BioNet. In ‚ÄúLES MUTANTS, #1,‚Äù we see Reiko meeting the mutants‚Äô Mother Yeast, a body of ever expanding blobs, appearing like lumps of dough rising in all directions, and VARIUS, a black and white photograph of a 1900s boy whose face and body are pockmarked from smallpox infection.
Ojo! Don't Slip On the Ba-nano Peal
‚ÄúOjo! Don't Slip On the Ba-nano Peal‚Äù by *particle group*. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
This nanopoem was co-created by Amy Sara Carroll and Ricardo Dominguez of *particle group,* along with Maribel Montero (a nanolithography specialist). It was produced with a Raith50 E-beam Writer on silicon coupons at nano3 (UCSD). The writing field of the coupons was between 0.5 um (nanometers) to 5.0 um (for the sake of comparison, recall that a white blood cell is 7,000 nanometers in width). Two trajectories were at play in developing these nanolithographs ‚Äî the work focuses on the year 2012, the year that the Mayan Calendar ended/shifted. Representations of that time-change oscillated between the apocalyptic and the utopic, paralleling representations of ‚Äúnanocausts and nanotopias‚Äù tracked by the artists in their work. The year 2012 also marked the inauguration of the Tijuana Institute of Nanotechology (TIN), a speculative space for nano-scale research and art production where these signs first were ‚Äútaken for wonders.‚Äù
View Now

item.title: Opening Now: Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process including Behnaz Farahi, Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha et al.
item.description: Opening Now: Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process including Behnaz Farahi, Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha et al.
item.ns0:encoded:
Opening Now: Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process including Behnaz Farahi, Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha et al.
Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process is now open on
Feral File
. Join us on
Twitter Spaces
in 1 hour (15:00 UTC, 8AM PST, 11AM EST) for a talk with curator Jesse Damiani¬†and exhibition artists.
This new group exhibition curated by
Jesse Damiani
looks¬†into the ‚Äúsketchbooks‚Äù of new media artists in order to explore our relationships with digital tools.
Simulation Sketchbook features 11 new artworks from:
Alida Sun
Anne Spalter
Botto
Behnaz Farahi
David OReilly
IX Shells
John Gerrard
Mimi Onuoha
Monica Rizzolli
Qianqian Ye
Reeps One
88 editions of each artwork¬†will be available for sale at a per edition price of $100. Minted on Tezos.
Exhibition Opening:
October 20, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
Those in the Los Angeles area can view the exhibition¬†installed at
Vellum
from October 21st to 23rd.
RSVP to join
Jesse Damiani and select exhibition artists at the¬†opening party tonight from 7-9 PM PST.
"Unveiling" by Behnaz Farahi. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process, a group exhibition curated by Jesse Damiani, which explores the various forms ‚Äúsketches‚Äù can take for artists working in new media and digital art. The exhibition will also feature Feral File‚Äôs first-ever physical pop-up at Vellum LA, and includes an LED billboard campaign in Downtown Los Angeles.
Curator Jesse Damiani on the exhibition:
‚ÄúAn artist‚Äôs sketchbook is one of the most precious spaces for research and experimentation. In its ideal, the sketchbook is an intimate domain where artists capture ideas, test compositions, wrestle with subjects, and scribble marginalia, engaging in an ongoing inner dialogue that audiences don‚Äôt witness.
In analog forms, sketches are highly correlated with drawing on paper. Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process poses a simple question: what does a sketch look like for an artist working in more experimental modes like digital art and time-based media? What is a sketch when it‚Äôs not a conventional drawing?
Whether they take the form of code, video, 3D models, immersive spaces, or multimodal explorations that don‚Äôt fit a neat categorization, these ‚Äúsketches‚Äù are no less integral to the development of the respective artist‚Äôs body of work. Because of the relative novelty among audiences, the technical and conceptual merits of these process-oriented arts can be difficult to grasp, leaving underlying poetics invisible or misinterpreted. Worse still is the assumption that this work is tantamount to button-pushing, that machines are the true authors‚Äîtrivializing the years spent developing a unique relationship with these materials‚Ä¶In this way, their sketches create a cascade of insight: regarding the art, the artist, and the new ways we might understand the relationship among ourselves and the tools of our daily lives.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
"Unveiling" by Behnaz Farahi. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúUnveiling‚Äù by Behnaz Farahi
Behnaz Farahi‚Äôs ‚ÄúUnveiling‚Äù addresses the representation of the female body through the veiling and unveiling of identity. It was created in direct response to the Mahsa Amini protests in Iran that began in September 2022 ‚Äî and supplanted the work that the artist had originally intended to contribute to the Simulation Sketchbook exhibition. Produced in less than two weeks, the work channels the artist‚Äôs raw processing of the feminist uprising taking place in her country of birth. By drawing herself into the final moments of ‚ÄúUnveiling,‚Äù Farahi reflects on her own connection to these issues in her personal narrative, and her current position as an expat working in the West, halfway across the world. As the artist writes, ‚ÄúWhy are there various laws controlling the bodies and lives of women? Where does the autonomy of the female body reside? While much feminist discourse is informed by a Western woman‚Äôs perspective, some of the largest-ever feminist protests are happening right now on the streets of Iran. With the Iranian uprising, ‚ÄòWoman, Life, Freedom‚Äô has become an expression of freedom and a political slogan to recognize the importance of the autonomy of the female body.‚Äù
Note: all proceeds from the sale of ‚ÄòUnveiling‚Äô will be donated to charities supporting Women's Rights.
‚ÄúMachine Sees More Than It Says‚Äù by Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha
‚ÄúMachine Sees More Than It Says‚Äù by Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
As an artist interrogating the role of data collection in contemporary society, Mimi ·ªån·ª•·ªçha seeks to reveal what‚Äôs missing in our algorithmic lives. The presumption that technology is objective and indifferent is a boon to the powerful, often conveniently obscuring those power structures from view. ·ªån·ª•·ªçha‚Äôs work is an act of sensemaking, revealing these underlying dynamics and relationships in powerful clarity. ‚ÄúMachine Sees More Than It Says‚Äù consists of clips of footage gathered from archival videos made between the 1950s and the 1980s. Stitched together, they form a machine's imagining of itself and the courses of development that formed it, hinting at processes of resource extraction, transport, technical advancement, interfaces, and labor. In the words of the artist: ‚ÄúI was working on a completely different piece and kept stumbling across this footage from an array of different videos, all of which seemed to share an aesthetic feel and to hint at much deeper computational stories...as if the tools I was using were intervening to speak of themselves."
‚ÄúMachine Inspired Voice 00.1‚Äù by Reeps One
‚ÄúMachine Inspired Voice 00.1‚Äù by Reeps One.¬† Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Artists working in generative formats have different ways of thinking about their tools. For some, it‚Äôs just that: tools. For others, it‚Äôs more akin to collaborating with a partner. Across much of his work at the cutting-edge of voice and technology, Harry Yeff frames a connected system of AI tools collectively as a sparring partner or workout buddy, a sort of composite machine rival through which to refine his (human) voice‚Äôs range and capability. In so doing, the artist uses AI to question the limit of his own voice, an opponent like duet and mentorship that pushes to new-voice and expression. Already among the best beatboxers in the world, Yeff‚Äôs lines of pursuit training with machines have pushed his capabilities into realms that truly begin to sound un-, non-, or post-human. ‚ÄúMachine Inspired Voice‚Äù is an ongoing research exploring multiple AI driven processes to develop new articulations, phraseologies and compositions in human voice expression. In ‚ÄúMachine Inspired Voice 00.1‚Äù Harry Yeff first interacts in real time with a synthetic vocalist using his own voice. Harry Yeff‚Äôs ability to develop complex machine-like vocal phrases is then ‚Äúlistened to‚Äù by the system and a reply is generated. This artwork offers a glimpse in process, and functions as a pre-release artist proof for a forthcoming series of over 300 AI and Human vocal phraseologies. The work is also presented as a spectrogram, which further reveals the range of audio frequencies visually.
View Now

Our next exhibition, Refik Anadol‚Äôs
Unsupervised
, will open on
November 18, 2021, 9pm New York (11pm S√£o Paulo, 3am Berlin (Nov 19), 10am Shanghai (Nov 19))
, with collecting to begin one hour later.
Join us on Discord
to engage with other collectors, the artists, and curator Casey Reas.
This exhibition will span three days, with each day unveiling new artworks. This will also be the first time we roll out our highest bidder and group auction formats. You can
revisit our notes
on these auction models from our last newsletter.
To learn more, see our
press release
or read on below.
Refik Anadol Studio on Unsupervised:
‚ÄúUnsupervised processes 138,151 pieces of publicly available metadata from the vast collection of The Museum of Modern Art in the mind of a machine. Using StyleGAN2 ADA to capture the machine‚Äôs ‚Äòhallucinations‚Äô of modern art in a multi-dimensional space, Anadol trains a unique AI model with subsets of the archive of MoMA‚Äôs collection of artworks, creating embeddings in 1024 dimensions. The sorted image datasets are then clustered into thematic categories to better understand the semantic context of data. This expanding data universe not only represents the interpolation of data as synthesis, but also becomes a latent cosmos in which hallucinatory potential arises from a novel form of artistic creativity interpreting MoMA‚Äôs unparalleled collection of modern and contemporary art.‚Äù
A still from ‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe‚Äù by Refik Anadol.
Additions to the Ethereum Bridge and other notes
This week, Feral File‚Äôs Ethereum Bridge added support for two exhibitions, Jan St. Werner‚Äôs Polyarrythmia, and P1x3L. You can
learn more
about the bridge from our last newsletter.
Our team has been working extremely hard on various UI and backend enhancements in preparation for a fantastic schedule to close out the year. We appreciate everyone‚Äôs comments and are aggressively rolling out changes to make Feral File better for everyone.
You can help us further by sharing feedback and participating in user tests through our #features channel in the Platform section of our
Discord
.
Lastly, on Monday, November 15, our crypto payments provider Wyre will be performing critical database updates for a maximum of 3 hours starting at 9PM EST (GMT-05:00). This means that crypto payments and transfer transactions cannot be handled during the update.
Connect with Feral File
With all our changes, feel free to send us feedback on how they‚Äôre working for you and how we can do better. In addition to Discord, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

This is a final email reminder for Peter Burr‚Äôs BOOM TOWN TOWN Hall starting on Friday, January 27. To participate:
You need to own
an edition of Empty Lot
from his BOOM TOWN exhibition by end of day January 26th UTC+0.
Make sure your email address is filled out in
your account page
. If you purchased Empty Lot through a secondary market, sign into Feral File with your web3 wallet and enter your email in the same manner.
Before the event starts, we will email you a Discord link to a private chat to engage with Peter and other collectors.
We will see you there! ¬†In the meantime, join Peter and the community‚Äôs discussion for BOOM TOWN
on Discord
.
About Peter Burr:
Peter Burr is an artist from Brooklyn, New York. His practice often engages with tools of the video game industry in the form of immersive cinematic artworks. These pieces have been presented internationally by various institutions, including Documenta 14, Athens; MoMA PS1, New York; and The Barbican Centre, London.
Previously Burr worked under the alias Hooliganship and founded the video label Cartune Xprez through which he produced hundreds of live multimedia exhibitions and touring programs showcasing a multi-generational group of artists at the forefront of experimental animation. His practice has been recognized through grants and awards including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Creative Capital Grant, and a Sundance New Frontier Fellowship.

item.title: Peter Burr‚Äôs BOOM TOWN to close 2022, Platform Enhancements on the way
item.description: Peter Burr‚Äôs BOOM TOWN to close 2022, Platform Enhancements on the way
item.ns0:encoded:
Hi everyone,
Watching Peter Burr, his collaborator Dave Tandem, and curator Julia Kaganskiy work together on
our final exhibition of the year, BOOM TOWN
, has been immensely rewarding. A couple of months ago, Peter told me the works were basically done, and to see him and Dave squeeze in extra details up to the final moments before the opening is a testament to how much they care about what‚Äôs being presented tomorrow.
I hope that you have the chance to join us for the opening, read Julia‚Äôs notes on the works, and participate in whichever way you feel comfortable, from viewing the artworks, purchasing a $75 edition, or perhaps even bidding on a complete set which includes 1:1s. Their idea of living artworks that are changing over time, and then comparing different works together over a long period of time, is really exciting.
Read
our announcement here
, and please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on December 14 at 18:30 UTC (1:30pm EST).
BOOM TOWN is minted on Ethereum.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
Platform News
We will be removing the ability to deposit crypto into your Feral File Wyre wallet by the end of the year as you are now able to purchase directly with your web3 wallet. If you have any funds on Feral File, please withdraw them!
Perhaps you‚Äôve noticed our logo change (see¬†the top of this email) ‚Äî we have a series of design overhauls coming to the Feral File website and Autonomy app within Q1 2023.
Our secondary market has been disabled. After we migrate off the Bitmark chain (later this month) it will be easy to purchase Feral File artworks on existing secondary markets like Objkt and OpenSea. Part of the Feral File redesign will make it easy for you to find available secondary market editions.
We are on track to migrate all editions currently held by Feral File to Ethereum and Tezos blockchains in December.
Autonomy Digital Art Wallet users: we will migrate your editions currently held by Feral File to Tezos and Ethereum addresses linked in Autonomy for free. More information coming via separate email.
If you are in New York City this winter, don‚Äôt forget to visit
Refik Anadol‚Äôs installation at MoMA
, running until March 5th, 2023. Not only is the installation breathtaking (I got to visit myself a few weeks ago), but you‚Äôll be able to claim a free digital memento from your visit. A new memento is being launched on December 19th, and there will be different ones launching on unannounced dates afterwards, so don‚Äôt miss out!
We are restructuring¬†our
Discord community server
to encourage longer lasting discussions through forum threads. We hope it will now be easier for new and long-time members to engage and explore art together and have also instituted new rules to discourage bots and less serious users. See the completed changes within the next week.
Don't Forget
Peer to Peer (Ethereum)
The first survey of the leading artists engaged with blockchains presented by an American museum, Buffalo AKG Art Museum. Curated by
Andy Warhol Foundation Arts Writers Grant
winner and
Artnet Innovators List 2022
honoree Dr. Tina Rivers Ryan. Peer to Peer has been discussed in the
New York Times
,
Artnet
,
Artdaily
, and
Mutual Art
, among other media.
Auriea Harvey: Gray Matter (Ethereum)
A solo show featuring interactive sculptures created from scans of physical sculptures, each of which was made from discarded material of previous works. The auction pieces also come with a physical sculpture. Last month, Harvey was named in
The Artsy Vanguard 2022
, was part of the Peer to Peer exhibition, and was featured in
Outland
,
Re-Edition
,
Damn Magazine
,
Y-Not Magazine
,
Contemporary Art Issue
, and
ArtNet
, among other media.
Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process (Tezos)
A group show curated by Jesse Damiani that looks into the ‚Äúsketchbooks‚Äù of new media artists in order to explore our relationships with digital tools.
Harbingers (Tezos)
A group show curated by Julia Kaganskiy that assembles visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties. Every time the works are sold and traded on-chain, a random glitching process progressively manipulates and mutates them.
Ecotone (Tezos)
A group show with works from the Glitch community that explore the entanglements of digital and natural ecologies, curated by Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick.
Doppelganger (Tezos)
A group show that crosses and fuses notions of digital and physical self, curated by Chris Coleman. First collectors receive a corresponding 3D print from Shapeways.
Wetware (Bitmark)
A group show of cyberfeminist works, curated by Mindy Seu, in support of Seu‚Äôs new book Cyberfeminism Index.
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: Presenting BOOM TOWN, a New Solo Exhibition by Peter Burr, minted on Ethereum
item.description: Presenting BOOM TOWN, a New Solo Exhibition by Peter Burr, minted on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Presenting BOOM TOWN, a New Solo Exhibition by Peter Burr, minted on Ethereum
Feral File
is pleased to announce BOOM TOWN, new media artist Peter Burr‚Äôs fictional neighborhood built and expanded on the blockchain. Each piece in BOOM TOWN, curated by Julia Kaganskiy, represents a unique, living artwork comprised of 1,000 images that will change over time, evolving as a kind of durational stop-motion animation over an undetermined period pegged to Ethereum‚Äôs block time‚Äîthat is, the length of time it takes to add another block to the blockchain.
Collectors receive the full set of images as part of their acquisition package and can browse or even create prints of the work‚Äôs past or future state, but they cannot make the work advance any faster or slower than block time. What will reach its end first, the work seems to be asking, the durational performance of BOOM TOWN? Or the technology it‚Äôs powered by? There‚Äôs only one way to find out.
Exhibition Opening:
December 14, 2022
16:00 UTC+0 (11am New York, 1pm S√£o Paulo, 5pm Berlin, 12am Shanghai (Dec 15))
Collecting begins one hour later
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on December 14 at 18:30 UTC (1:30pm EST).
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
Curator Julia Kaganskiy on BOOM TOWN:
‚ÄúLike most of his works, Peter Burr‚Äôs BOOM TOWN is a richly crafted narrative world that is deeply evocative while remaining mysterious and restrained. Displaying the artist‚Äôs gift for creating images and environments that hover on the boundary between abstraction and figuration, they invite the viewer to fill in the blanks with their own interpretation, suggesting a story that is barely legible yet unmistakably present. Inspired by the tools and aesthetics of video games, Burr‚Äôs compositions draw on generative dynamics and the complexity that emerges from simple, rule-based systems. Each of the eight works in BOOM TOWN follows a precise logic for generating the structure‚Äôs architecture, its ground and field, its shadows, planes, and colors. The resulting images are reminiscent of 8-bit video games and early computer graphics, as well as the flat diagrammatic quality of CAD architectural drawings.‚Äù
About Peter Burr:
Peter Burr is an artist from Brooklyn, New York. His practice often engages with tools of the video game industry in the form of immersive cinematic artworks. These pieces have been presented internationally by various institutions, including Documenta 14, Athens; MoMA PS1, New York; and The Barbican Centre, London.
Previously Burr worked under the alias Hooliganship and founded the video label Cartune Xprez through which he produced hundreds of live multimedia exhibitions and touring programs showcasing a multi-generational group of artists at the forefront of experimental animation. His practice has been recognized through grants and awards including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Creative Capital Grant, and a Sundance New Frontier Fellowship.
Preview of the artworks:
Every one of the structures in BOOM TOWN represents a unique, living artwork comprised of 1,000 images that will change over time, evolving as a kind of durational stop-motion animation over an undetermined period pegged to Ethereum‚Äôs block time ‚Äî that is, the length of time it takes to add another block to the blockchain. Collectors receive the full set of images as part of their acquisition package and can browse or even create prints of the work‚Äôs past or future state, but they cannot make the work advance any faster or slower than block time.
Burr‚Äôs process blends traditional animation techniques with the affordances of generative algorithmic systems. Each work originates with ‚Äúintentionally unoptimized algorithms‚Äù developed by Burr‚Äôs collaborator, Dave Tandem, and follows a precise composition logic that dictates its form, ground and field, shadows, planes, colors, and weight. The software allows Burr to draw structures on a gravity-influenced canvas and to animate them changing over time. Burr is interested in highlighting the unique fingerprints of various software and in his practice often works across tech pipelines to weave these diverse fingerprints into a unique aesthetic, reveling in the compression and dithering that occurs through this approach. The final images are outputted into a custom framework built by Tandem that uses block time to advance their evolution.
APARTMENT BLOCK
‚ÄúAPARTMENT BLOCK‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Like a chunk of houses glued together and cut into cubes, each with a standalone reality ‚Äî the apartment blocks aren‚Äôt meant to be good because the community enjoys the process of making them better.
FACTORY
‚ÄúFACTORY‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
We‚Äôll sustain half the town with a small factory.¬† The taller the smokestack, the better we‚Äôll spread our invisible byproducts.
SHOPPING PLAZA
‚ÄúSHOPPING PLAZA‚Äù by Peter Burr. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
A good town needs a few places to go when you‚Äôre bored. None of them are here, but the food court has an arcade.
We look forward to seeing you
at the opening on Feral File
.
Exhibition Opening:
December 14, 2022
16:00 UTC+0 (11am New York, 1pm S√£o Paulo, 5pm Berlin, 12am Shanghai (Dec 15))
Collecting begins one hour later
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on December 14 at 18:30 UTC (1:30pm EST).
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal

item.title: Presenting Ecotone - A Glitch Community Group Exhibition, Minted on Tezos
item.description: Presenting Ecotone - A Glitch Community Group Exhibition, Minted on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Presenting Ecotone - A Glitch Community Group Exhibition, Minted on Tezos
Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick have¬†curated
Ecotone
, the
new Feral File¬†exhibition
showing¬†the entanglements of digital and natural ecologies.
Ecotone
features artists and technologists from the Glitch community:
Sarah Friend
Jakob Kudsk Steensen
Gene Kogan
Kalen Iwamoto
aur√®ce vettier
Iannis Bardakos
Primavera De Filippi
&
Wolfgang Natlacen
ORLAN
141¬†editions of all eight artworks will be available for sale at a per edition price of $150. Of these editions, 70 will be initially available only in exhibition sets during the exhibition's first twenty-four hours¬†for¬†$1,200 ($150 √ó 8 artworks).
Exhibition Opening:
September 14, 2022
15:00 UTC+0 (8am Los Angeles, 12pm S√£o Paulo, 5pm Berlin, 11pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on September 14 at 15:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúBecoming Illegible (Mirror Studies #1)‚Äù by Sarah Friend. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Curator Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick on the exhibition:
‚ÄúOur exhibition Ecotone distills the creative outflows of the Glitch community of artists and technologists. This growing network considers digital and natural ecologies to be innately entangled, with cross-border collaboration a vital means of generating new social realities. Involving over 60 participants from around the world, Glitch is a spectrum of strategies and a model for a new creator ecology ‚Äî artistic, poetic, and human-machinic. For this show with Feral File, Glitch is represented by a number of leading artists, whose range of approaches reflects the plurality of the community.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Becoming Illegible (Mirror Studies #1)
(pictured above)
Under the larger project, Becoming Illegible, which engages with both social media face filters and facial recognition, Sarah Friend‚Äôs ‚ÄúMirror Studies #1‚Äù is an interactive browser-based facefilter. Placing the facefilter form in dialogue with idealized ecological imagery, this work translates the questions of how we become legible to machine learning into the arena of how a landscape becomes legible to society. These images of landscapes and faces blend together ‚Äî at times familiar and recognizable, at others alien, Cthulhu-like, and abstract.
Interplanetary
‚ÄúInterplanetary‚Äù by Gene Kogan. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Gene Kogan‚Äôs video ‚ÄúInterplanetary‚Äù depicts an infinite progression of lush and exotic alien creatures residing symbiotically in organic vegetation. The technique by which Kogan made the video uses a generative neural network trained over millions of images and controlled through natural language. By prompting the model with unusual sentence constructions mixing Earthly ecology with sci-fi alien plots, strange interplanetary juxtapositions are generated.
Littor[alter]ms
‚ÄúLittor[alter]ms‚Äù by Kalen Iwamoto. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Kalen Iwamoto‚Äôs ‚ÄúLittor[alter]ms‚Äù is at once a conceptual poem and a teaser for a forthcoming crypto-literary experiment. As a conceptual poem, it illustrates the (e)merging worlds of literature, NFTs, and crypto literature in a literal/literary translation of the ecotone. As a teaser, it unveils the main features and the underlying thrust of an upcoming experimental crypto-literary work whose seed was planted in a particularly fertile, ecotonal moment. The line of poetry in iambic pentameter set in relief at the meeting point of Shakespearean theater and NFTs reveals the crux of the experiment and our deep-seated ambivalence vis-√†-vis a relationship that is both wholesome and transgressive.
We look forward to seeing you
at the opening on Feral File
.
September 14, 2022
15:00 UTC+0 (8am Los Angeles, 12pm S√£o Paulo, 5pm Berlin, 11pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on September 14 at 15:00 UTC.
Add to

item.title: Presenting Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
item.description: Presenting Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
item.ns0:encoded:
Presenting Gray Matter, a New Solo Exhibition by Auriea Harvey, minted on Ethereum
Auriea Harvey
‚Äôs solo exhibition
Gray Matter
, curated by Gaia Bob√≤, features eleven interactive sculptures originating from scans of new physical works: assemblages composed of previously discarded fragments and 3D prints. Auctioned pieces are accompanied by a physical bronze sculpture and all works come with 3D printable files.
Eight editions of 8 artworks will be available for sale at a per edition fixed price of $1,000. Three 1:1 artworks will be (highest bid) auctioned at a starting price of $5,000.¬†One artwork will be available as an unlimited (open) edition for $100.
Exhibition Opening:
November 10, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on November 10 at 19:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúGray Matter‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce
Gray Matter
, a new solo exhibition by artist Auriea Harvey, curated by Gaia Bob√≤.
Curator Gaia Bob√≤ on Gray Matter:
‚ÄúAuriea Harvey‚Äôs solo show
Gray Matter
presents a body of work emerging from an undefined and fluid ambient, where mud-like protoplasm is molded from a neutral background, solidifying into metaphysical apparitions. These data-based objects are marked by the memory of their material roots, similarly to archeological artifacts or witnesses. Indeed, the artist plays with the tools of archaeological research in the creation of her mythology and methodology. Auriea uses polygons in place of plaster, staging a non-literal and paradoxical practice of casting in a ping-ponging circularity from the sensual world to the digital one and back again. As in Pompeii‚Äôs casts, where the transition from the void left by an incinerated body is impressed into the durable matter of a plaster form, the artist seeks that continuum in the tension between ethereal and corporal, attempting to answer the question: what is this void made of?‚Äù
About Auriea Harvey:
Auriea Harvey is a sculptor living and working in Rome. Her practice encompasses virtual and tangible sculptures, drawings, and simulations that blend digital and handmade production including 3D printing, AR, and VR. She is primarily concerned with making the mythological world visible through form, interaction, and immersion. Her works are a synthesis of art historical reference and imagination. And she is engaged across time, media, and material to define what sculptural production means in the present moment. She is half of the artist duo which over time has been known as Entropy8Zuper!/Tale of Tales/Song of Songs, award-winning for their pioneering works in Internet art, video games, and mixed reality. Her work can be found in the permanent collections of institutions such as Buffalo AKG Art Museum, Walker Art Center, KADIST Collection,¬† RF.C Collection, and Rhizome‚Äôs Net Art Anthology. Her videogames and VR works have had international success, including exhibitions at the Tinguely Museum, Basel; the Victoria & Albert Museum, London; the New Museum, New York; Brooklyn Academy of Music, New York; and ZKM, Karlsruhe.
Preview of the Artworks:
Gray Matter
(pictured above)
‚ÄúGray Matter,‚Äù the work that gives its name to the exhibition, is a statement on indefiniteness in the matter of thought: a triple portrait of a girl, a cyclops inside the cave of her mind with a candle-like flame burning at its eye, and a stylized emerging skull, all suspended in a gray infinity. The possibilities of interaction highlight the implicit potential in stretching, distorting, and playing with the materiality of the digital polygon, shifting perception and meaning.
AlleluiaAlleluia
‚ÄúAlleluiaAlleluia‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In ‚ÄúAlleluiaAlleluia,‚Äù a singing, polymorphic being swings in a zero-gravity nocturnal background, with two moon wedges positioned at the extremities of the piece, creating a mesmerizing atmosphere. Here, the self-portrait of the artist is combined with a scan of one wing of the Nike of Samothrace.
Messenger (fragment)
‚ÄúMessenger (fragment)‚Äù by Auriea Harvey. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
The perceptive experience of the work ‚ÄúMessenger (fragment)‚Äù is a sense of disorientation given by a glitch that occurred while scanning, which turned the bottom of the original sculpture into a cloud-like mass. Amplifying the impossibility of catching the whole ensemble of this sculpture all at once, in this digital piece, everything floats.
We look forward to seeing you at the opening on Feral File.
Exhibition Opening:
November 10, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (9am New York, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a live conversation between artist and curator on November 10 at 19:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|

item.title: Presenting Harbingers, a new Experimental Exhibition using Blockchain Data to Manipulate and Mutate Each Artwork, Minted on Tezos
item.description: Presenting Harbingers, a new Experimental Exhibition using Blockchain Data to Manipulate and Mutate Each Artwork, Minted on Tezos
item.ns0:encoded:
Presenting Harbingers, a¬†new Experimental Exhibition using Blockchain Data to Manipulate and Mutate Each Artwork, Minted on Tezos
Julia Kaganskiy
curates
Harbingers
, the
new Feral File exhibition
bringing together a bestiary of the posthuman.¬†Harbingers takes on a new, experimental approach, using blockchain data to manipulate and mutate each artwork. Every time the works are sold and traded on-chain, a random glitching process will progressively distort the works.
Harbingers features 14 new artworks in total from:
Zach Blas
Pinar Yoldas
Ricardo Dominguez / *particle group*
Shu Lea Cheang
Sofia Crespo
33¬†editions of each artwork¬†will be available for sale at a per edition price of $75. Of these editions, 10¬†will be initially available only in exhibition sets during the exhibition's first twenty-four hours¬†for¬†$1,050¬†($75¬†√ó 14¬†artworks).
Exhibition Opening:
September 28, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on September 28 at 17:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúGeneric Mannequin Gets Flayed‚Äù by Zach Blas. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce Harbingers, an exhibition of five international artists assembling visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties.
Curator Julia Kaganskiy on the exhibition:
‚ÄúFor millennia, speculations about how technoscientific innovations could transform living organisms ‚Äî by accident or design ‚Äî have animated our imaginaries of cyborgs, mutants, automatons, and replicants. As our environment becomes increasingly synthetic, polluted, and governed by planetary-scale computation, what kind of lifeforms will it support?
The group show Harbingers brings together a bestiary of the posthuman, assembling artistic visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties in an age of accelerated biosocial transformation. A menagerie of mutant creatures emerges from the recombinant crucible of computational manipulation, genetic engineering, viral mutation, biohacking, and cross-species contamination. Novel corporeal formations, at once familiar and strange, are produced through complex interrelations of nature, culture, and technology. Modernity becomes an agent of metamorphosis through the vectors of engineering, adaptation, and aberration. Each work in Harbingers offers a portal into a fabulated mirror world governed by its own mythology. The organisms assembled here include coded chimeras, genetically modified superhumans, bodies held captive by the algorithmic surround, and plants and animals that have evolved to metabolize plastics and toxic waste. All serve as sentinels of the transfigurative powers of technology and ecocide.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Generic Mannequin Gets Flayed
(pictured above)
‚Äú
Generic Mannequin Gets Flayed‚Äù is a corporate term for digital representations of bodies that are examined for risks and anomalies during airport body scans. Zach Blas appropriated this non-image in his installation ‚ÄúSANCTUM‚Äù (2018), a security-detention-center-meets-sex-dungeon environment that probes the dynamics of power, exposure, and desire inherent in surveillance and predictive policing through the lens of BDSM. Rendered silent and pliant through biometric capture, we see the mannequin bound, whipped, contained, and harvested for use in the creation of new weapons or sex toys. By invoking queer aesthetics and consentual power play, Blas leaves the question of complicity up for debate ‚Äî are the mannequins prisoners, sex slaves, worshippers, or experimental test subjects? The work‚Äôs ambiguity problematizes our symbiotic relationship with technology, examining the nature of personal agency, surveillance, and control in a world shaped by data mining and social engineering.
LES MUTANTS, #3
‚ÄúLES MUTANTS, #3‚Äù by Shu Lea Cheang. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
This excerpt from UKI, Shu Lea Cheang‚Äôs forthcoming feature length sci-fi viral cinema, recounts the adventures of Reiko, a de-commissioned replicant. UKI is the sequel to Cheang‚Äôs iconic cyberpunk porn film I.K.U. (2000), which tells the story of biotech company Genom Corporation and its plan to harvest orgasm data to engineer and sell addictive orgasms. Discarded on the toxic waste dump E-trashville, Reiko encounters Les Mutants, creatures who have evolved over generations of e-trash remixing, toxic pollution, and viral infection. Les Mutants help Reiko reboot themself back to existence and transform into¬† the virus UKI, capable of infiltrating and sabotaging Genom Corp‚Äôs BioNet. In ‚ÄúLES MUTANTS, #1,‚Äù we see Reiko meeting the mutants‚Äô Mother Yeast, a body of ever expanding blobs, appearing like lumps of dough rising in all directions, and VARIUS, a black and white photograph of a 1900s boy whose face and body are pockmarked from smallpox infection.
Ojo! Don't Slip On the Ba-nano Peal
‚ÄúOjo! Don't Slip On the Ba-nano Peal‚Äù by *particle group*. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
This nanopoem was co-created by Amy Sara Carroll and Ricardo Dominguez of *particle group,* along with Maribel Montero (a nanolithography specialist). It was produced with a Raith50 E-beam Writer on silicon coupons at nano3 (UCSD). The writing field of the coupons was between 0.5 um (nanometers) to 5.0 um (for the sake of comparison, recall that a white blood cell is 7,000 nanometers in width). Two trajectories were at play in developing these nanolithographs ‚Äî the work focuses on the year 2012, the year that the Mayan Calendar ended/shifted. Representations of that time-change oscillated between the apocalyptic and the utopic, paralleling representations of ‚Äúnanocausts and nanotopias‚Äù tracked by the artists in their work. The year 2012 also marked the inauguration of the Tijuana Institute of Nanotechology (TIN), a speculative space for nano-scale research and art production where these signs first were ‚Äútaken for wonders.‚Äù
We look forward to seeing you
at the opening on Feral File
.
Exhibition Opening:
September 28, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on September 28 at 17:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal

item.ns0:encoded:
Congratulations on participating in
Doppelganger
, curated by Chris Coleman. As you may know, the first collector of each edition receives a physical print, produced and shipped by our partner, Shapeways.
‚ÄúMetamultimouse‚Äù by Matthew Plummer-Fern√°ndez. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Your next step is to go to your account page on Feral File:
https://feralfile.com/account
. Find the ‚Äú
SHIPPING ADDRESS (OPTIONAL)
‚Äù section in the lower left of this page and enter your shipping information.
This is a limited time offer: we will batch collector information to Shapeways every two weeks starting
September 12th EDT
until 2 months after the launch of the exhibition (late October). Please keep in mind that only first collectors can redeem this print; print rights cannot be transferred. If you purchased multiple editions, you only need to enter your shipping information once to receive prints of each edition.
The cost of the print is included in your purchase price; however, international collectors may need to pay local import taxes on the value of the print ($50 USD).
Shapeways will email you once the print is produced and shipped to you.
A couple of final notes: 1) if you collected Jeremy Bailey, we will assign slices in the order of purchase rather than correlating them to the edition number. 2) if you collect multiple editions from Sophie Kahn, we will ensure that you do not get multiples of the same model.
Please email me (
michael@bitmark.com
) with any questions, and I appreciate your continued support of our artists,
Michael Nguy·ªÖn

item.title: Refik Anadol's Unsupervised: MoMA seen through the mind of a machine
item.description: Refik Anadol's Unsupervised: MoMA seen through the mind of a machine
item.ns0:encoded:
Unsupervised: MoMA seen through the mind of a machine
Announcing a new solo exhibition with media artist Refik Anadol
Exhibition Opening:
November 18, 2021
9pm New York (11pm S√£o Paulo, 3am Berlin (Nov 19), 10am Shanghai (Nov 19))
Collecting begins one hour later
Three images from the ‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Machine Hallucinations ‚Äî MoMA ‚Äî Dreams‚Äù series by Refik Anadol Studio. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the gallery‚Äôs ninth exhibition, featuring artworks by media artist Refik Anadol, who has trained a unique AI model with the metadata of The Museum of Modern Art‚Äôs unparalleled collection. The result is a series of software works, video works, and data paintings that capture the machine‚Äôs ‚Äúhallucinations‚Äù of modern and contemporary art at MoMA. Each work will be made available to collectors as NFTs.
Starting with the exhibition opening, new artworks will be revealed over three days. On November 18 at 10pm EST, one 1/1 software artwork and two 1/1 video artworks (shipped with accompanying hardware) will be auctioned to the highest three bidders. The next day at the same time, nine artworks in editions of 100 will be sold via nine group auctions. One day later, one video in an edition of 5,000 will be sold via set price. All auctions will take place over 24 hours.
Refik Anadol Studio on Unsupervised:
‚ÄúUnsupervised processes 138,151 pieces of publicly available metadata from the vast collection of The Museum of Modern Art in the mind of a machine. Using StyleGAN2 ADA to capture the machine‚Äôs ‚Äòhallucinations‚Äô of modern art in a multi-dimensional space, Anadol trains a unique AI model with subsets of the archive of MoMA‚Äôs collection of artworks, creating embeddings in 1024 dimensions. The sorted image datasets are then clustered into thematic categories to better understand the semantic context of data. This expanding data universe not only represents the interpolation of data as synthesis, but also becomes a latent cosmos in which hallucinatory potential arises from a novel form of artistic creativity interpreting MoMA‚Äôs unparalleled collection of modern and contemporary art.‚Äù
Spanning more than 200 years of art, from paintings to photography to cars to video games, the MoMA collection is an extraordinary dataset‚Äîwithin which works from artistic movements such as Surrealism, not unlike the works in Unsupervised, explored automatism, chance, and systems to generate unprecedented new art forms. The AI-based abstract images and shapes in Unsupervised are interpretations of the Museum‚Äôs wide-ranging collection, weighted toward the
special exhibition of new artworks on view at MoMA this fall.
Preview of Select Artworks:
Unsupervised ‚Äî Machine Hallucinations ‚Äî MoMA ‚Äî Dreams (Pictured Above)
‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Machine Hallucinations ‚Äî MoMA ‚Äî Fluid Dreams‚Äù is a series of algorithmic AI data paintings showcasing Refik Anadol‚Äôs unique collaboration with machine learning at the intersection of technology and aesthetics. Each image in the series displays a cluster of chosen ‚Äúdream sequences,‚Äù as the artist goes through serendipitous allusions to modern visual expressions in the machine-mind.
Still image from ‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA‚Äù video by Refik Anadol Studio. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA
‚ÄúUnsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA‚Äù is a global AI data painting that simulates a latent walk among the Museum‚Äôs digitized collection. The artist and his team used MoMA archives‚Äô metadata for the creation of UMAP Data Universe, which helped them construct seven dimensions of the artwork: x, y, z, r, g, b, and time. It combines Anadol‚Äôs vision of handling data within a universe that it creates for itself with his approach to data visualization‚Äôs latent space as a locus for never-ending, self-generating contemplation.
About Refik Anadol:
Refik Anadol (b. 1985, Istanbul, Turkey) is a media artist and pioneer in the aesthetics of machine intelligence, and the director of Refik Anadol Studio in Los Angeles. Since 2008, his works have explored the space among digital and physical entities by creating a symbiotic relationship between architecture, science, technology, and media arts. As an artist and a spatial thinker, he addresses the challenges, and the possibilities, that ubiquitous computing has imposed on humanity, and what it means to be a human in the age of AI. Anadol‚Äôs site-specific audio/visual performances have been featured at other iconic landmarks, museums, and festivals worldwide, such as Venice Architecture Biennale, Walt Disney Concert Hall, The Centre Pompidou, Florence Biennale, Hammer Museum, Art Basel, Dongdaemun Design Plaza, The Portland Building, Daejeon Museum of Art, Artechouse, International Digital Arts Biennial Montreal, Ars Electronica Festival, Arc De Triomf, Zollverein | SANAA‚Äôs School of Design Building, santralistanbul Contemporary Art Center, Istanbul Design Biennial, and Sydney City Biennale among many others. Anadol has partnered, and continues to work with, teams at Google, Nvidia, Microsoft, NASA JPL, Intel, IBM, Siemens, Epson, MIT, UCLA, Caltech, Harvard, Stanford University, and UCSF to apply the latest cutting-edge science, research, and technologies to his work.

item.title: Feral File Reopening
item.description: Feral File Reopening
item.ns0:encoded:
p1xelfool: g√§mma
Announcing a new solo exhibition with p1xelfool curated by kerry doran, and the first Feral File exhibition on Tezos.
Exhibition Opening:
July 28, 2022
14:00 UTC (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
See the
Price List
for more details.
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation between p1xelfool and curator kerry doran on July 28 at 14:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚Äú7 + 0 * 11‚Äù by p1xelfool. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
is pleased to announce g√§mma, an exhibition of 33 unique artworks by generative artist p1xelfool, the gallery‚Äôs first exhibition minted on Tezos.
Curator kerry doran on the exhibition:
‚ÄúPixels are the smallest element that can be displayed on a digital screen, groupings of which comprise the billions of still and moving images in circulation today. Pixels are not dissimilar to gamma rays, the shortest yet most powerful of the rays in the electromagnetic spectrum. The difference between them would seem to do with perception: gamma rays are invisible, pixels are not. However, both require specifically designed environments to engender visibility, such as a scintillation detector or a computer with a digital display. Because of the relative ubiquity of the latter, the specificity ‚Äî and necessity ‚Äî of the computer environment may be easily overlooked, if not forgotten, when perceiving pixels. The seduction of the screen, with its pixel-based representations, obfuscates the fusion of software and hardware that illuminate content: code and cold cathode. As p1xelfool says, ‚ÄòCode = light.‚Äô
In g√§mma, p1xelfool fuses pixels with light, with code. With such an emphasis on these materials and their visual properties, the works may seem formalist. Indeed, the generative compositions are strikingly geometric and inorganic; for those familiar with p1xelfool‚Äôs larger body of work, those in g√§mma may come across as austere in comparison. Yet these works are deeper than their surface. p1xelfool‚Äôs approach is intent on reconnecting color and light with the computer environment to create engrossing sensorial experiences specific to it.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
‚Äú0 + 0 * 11‚Äù by p1xelfool. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File
The 33 unique artworks presented in g√§mma are self-contained systems; each contains 3 seeds generated by the system, selected and arranged by the artist to comprise the final composition.
p1xelfool conceptualized these works with Processing, its visual and responsive coding environment feeling more expressive to the artist than analog painting. The works are executed with p5.js, which allowed p1xelfool to program pixels in the browser in real-time. ‚ÄúInstead of asking the program to draw lines, I asked it to manipulate the pixel arrays,‚Äù he describes. This underscores the conceptual motivation of the project, namely, the reappropriation of pixels (and light and code) rather than the visuals produced by them. When viewing the work, there is the option to hit the ‚ÄúP‚Äù key to pause the pattern; hitting the ‚ÄúS‚Äù key will save and download the frame.
p1xelfool‚Äôs generative animations are inspired by the logic of particle systems, yet they share no reference to the natural world. The visual environments of the works are specific only to the computer. In each work, two superimposed and interrelated systems simultaneously interact with one another. Their interrelated velocities determine the speed at which blocks of interplaying (and playful) color seem to descend to the bottom of the screen, cycling through new patterns and creating the illusion of endlessness. Colors and patterns are rhythmic and vibrational; visual pleasure is immense and infinite.
About Feral File
Feral File is where artists, collectors, and curators convene to co-create a new paradigm for digital art. We commission curated exhibitions of file-based artwork, and partner with artists and institutions to establish transparent protocols for exhibiting and collecting. Evolving from the art gallery and digital publishing models, we are borrowing the best traits of each to inform a new kind of art space. Feral File works in tandem with a community of technologists, new media artists, and curators to redefine and frame a sustainable model for digital experimentation.
About Tezos
Tezos is an energy-efficient blockchain where developers, artists, entrepreneurs, brands, and others from around the world build and engage with a network of decentralized applications. Tezos‚Äô modular architecture allows for seamless, community-determined upgrades that deploy new advancements to fuel the next round of innovation.
PRESS CONTACT
Eileen Skyers
Gallery Director, Feral File
eileen@feralfile.com

item.title: See Feral File in Miami, New York and more exciting developments
item.description: See Feral File in Miami, New York and more exciting developments
item.ns0:encoded:
Feral File in Miami, New York City, and other exciting developments
As we head toward the end of the year, it‚Äôs been a good time to reflect upon the year. Despite the volatility in the world, I‚Äôm thankful for the continued support from the wonderful curators and artists in the Feral File community. They have invested in our vision of making digital art more accessible to experience and collect.
But before we close out the year, we still have two more exhibitions coming up.
Opening on November 21 is Peer to Peer, minted on Ethereum, with the Buffalo AKG Art Museum (formerly the Albright-Knox Art Gallery), curated by Dr. Tina Rivers Ryan. I could fill this entire newsletter with thoughts about the show, but I‚Äôll link to
our announcement email instead
. If you‚Äôre in Miami for Art Basel at the end of this¬†month, join
AKG and Feral File at the Peer to Peer Launch Party
. Attendees will receive an exclusive digital souvenir that‚Äôs connected to the heritage of the Museum, which is reopening early next year. I can‚Äôt share what it is, but it‚Äôs worth your time to get to the party. The exhibition is a fundraiser for the museum ‚Äî by collecting, you‚Äôre directly impacting the museum and its future support for the digital art we love.
Next week, we will also unveil a special gift for those who can‚Äôt join us in Miami and more details around collecting the exhibit.
Our second exhibition is a solo show with a Feral File alumnus curated by different Feral File alumnus, opening on December 8. We‚Äôll have more on that soon ‚Äî it‚Äôs worthy of its own email.
ICYMI, our work with MoMA, Refik Anadol, and AKG were discussed in this
recent New York Times article
. Last year, we were proud to present Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised. This year, from November 19 (tomorrow) to March 05, 2023, Unsupervised will
be viewable at MoMA‚Äôs Gund Lobby
. As with the AKG party in Miami, visitors will receive an exclusive NFT gift from our
digital art wallet Autonomy
in this collaboration with MoMA.
Hint: you may want to visit the installation multiple times in the coming months‚Ä¶.I‚Äôll be there opening weekend to claim my gift.
Platform News
We have delayed migration off the Bitmark Blockchain
You may remember that
we‚Äôre in the process of moving
all of our Bitmark blockchain NFTs to either Ethereum or Tezos. This was originally scheduled for this time now, but we‚Äôve decided to delay things to the end of the year as we prioritize the work of executing the remainder of our exhibition schedule.
Native Web3 Support for Ethereum and Tezos Collectors
Starting with
Auriea Harvey‚Äôs solo exhibition, Gray Matter
, we now provide native web3 support for your wallet. This means when we run an Ethereum exhibition like Gray Matter, you can use your Ethereum wallet to collect just as you would on any other platform; the same is true for Tezos, which you can try out with exhibitions like
Ecotone
.
Now that we have native support, you‚Äôll no longer need to deposit funds into our Wyre wallet. We‚Äôll be discontinuing that shortly ‚Äî please move forward with transferring any funds you have there into your web3 wallet.
Don't Forget
As it‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve written to everyone, I‚Äôd like to remind you of some of the excellent exhibitions we‚Äôve had recently that are still open for collecting:
Auriea Harvey: Gray Matter (Ethereum)
A solo show featuring interactive sculptures created from scans of physical sculptures, each of which was made from discarded material of previous works. The auction pieces also come with a physical sculpture. Just this week, Harvey was named in
The Artsy Vanguard 2022
.
Simulation Sketchbook: Works in Process (Tezos)
A group show curated by Jesse Damiani that looks into the ‚Äúsketchbooks‚Äù of new media artists in order to explore our relationships with digital tools.
Harbingers (Tezos)
A group show curated by Julia Kaganskiy that assembles visions of transhumanist desires and technogenic anxieties. Every time the works are sold and traded on-chain, a random glitching process progressively manipulates and mutates them.
Ecotone (Tezos)
A group show with works from the Glitch community that explore the entanglements of digital and natural ecologies, curated by Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick.
Doppelganger (Tezos)
A group show that crosses and fuses notions of digital and physical self, curated by Chris Coleman. First collectors receive a corresponding 3D print from Shapeways.
Wetware (Bitmark)
A group show of cyberfeminist works, curated by Mindy Seu, in support of Seu‚Äôs new book Cyberfeminism Index.
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: Starting in 2 Hours! Join the curators and artists on Twitter Spaces for a discussion on Ecotone
item.description: Starting in 2 Hours! Join the curators and artists on Twitter Spaces for a discussion on Ecotone
item.ns0:encoded:
Starting in 2 Hours! Join the curators and artists on Twitter Spaces for a discussion on Ecotone
Please join us on
Twitter Spaces
for a conversation with the artists on September 14 at 15:00 UTC.
Exhibition Opening:
September 14, 2022
15:00 UTC+0 (8am Los Angeles, 12pm S√£o Paulo, 5pm Berlin, 11pm Shanghai)
Collecting starts one hour later
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick have¬†curated
Ecotone
, the
new Feral File¬†exhibition
showing¬†the entanglements of digital and natural ecologies.
Ecotone
features artists and technologists from the Glitch community:
Sarah Friend
Jakob Kudsk Steensen
Gene Kogan
Kalen Iwamoto
aur√®ce vettier
Iannis Bardakos
Primavera De Filippi
&
Wolfgang Natlacen
ORLAN
141¬†editions of all eight artworks will be available for sale at a per edition price of $150. Of these editions, 70 will be initially available only in exhibition sets during the exhibition's first twenty-four hours¬†for¬†$1,200 ($150 √ó 8 artworks).
‚ÄúBecoming Illegible (Mirror Studies #1)‚Äù by Sarah Friend. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Curator Primavera De Filippi, Stina Gustafsson, and Alex Estorick on the exhibition:
‚ÄúOur exhibition Ecotone distills the creative outflows of the Glitch community of artists and technologists. This growing network considers digital and natural ecologies to be innately entangled, with cross-border collaboration a vital means of generating new social realities. Involving over 60 participants from around the world, Glitch is a spectrum of strategies and a model for a new creator ecology ‚Äî artistic, poetic, and human-machinic. For this show with Feral File, Glitch is represented by a number of leading artists, whose range of approaches reflects the plurality of the community.‚Äù
Preview of the Artworks:
Becoming Illegible (Mirror Studies #1)
(pictured above)
Under the larger project, Becoming Illegible, which engages with both social media face filters and facial recognition, Sarah Friend‚Äôs ‚ÄúMirror Studies #1‚Äù is an interactive browser-based facefilter. Placing the facefilter form in dialogue with idealized ecological imagery, this work translates the questions of how we become legible to machine learning into the arena of how a landscape becomes legible to society. These images of landscapes and faces blend together ‚Äî at times familiar and recognizable, at others alien, Cthulhu-like, and abstract.
Interplanetary
‚ÄúInterplanetary‚Äù by Gene Kogan. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Gene Kogan‚Äôs video ‚ÄúInterplanetary‚Äù depicts an infinite progression of lush and exotic alien creatures residing symbiotically in organic vegetation. The technique by which Kogan made the video uses a generative neural network trained over millions of images and controlled through natural language. By prompting the model with unusual sentence constructions mixing Earthly ecology with sci-fi alien plots, strange interplanetary juxtapositions are generated.
Littor[alter]ms
‚ÄúLittor[alter]ms‚Äù by Kalen Iwamoto. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Kalen Iwamoto‚Äôs ‚ÄúLittor[alter]ms‚Äù is at once a conceptual poem and a teaser for a forthcoming crypto-literary experiment. As a conceptual poem, it illustrates the (e)merging worlds of literature, NFTs, and crypto literature in a literal/literary translation of the ecotone. As a teaser, it unveils the main features and the underlying thrust of an upcoming experimental crypto-literary work whose seed was planted in a particularly fertile, ecotonal moment. The line of poetry in iambic pentameter set in relief at the meeting point of Shakespearean theater and NFTs reveals the crux of the experiment and our deep-seated ambivalence vis-√†-vis a relationship that is both wholesome and transgressive.
View Now

item.title: Thank You for Your Support, WalletConnect Integration
item.description: Thank You for Your Support, WalletConnect Integration
item.ns0:encoded:
Happy holidays and thank you for supporting Feral File. Since our launch in March, it‚Äôs been a tremendous experience learning, building, and preparing Feral File for the future, and I deeply appreciate your support.
In case you‚Äôre looking for last-minute gifts this holiday season, we have
some fantastic artworks still available
at a fixed price.
My Year-End Thoughts
I‚Äôd like to copy something I shared internally with our team a couple of weeks ago:
‚ÄúWe want to provide the best art collecting experience in the world. This is by allowing anyone, regardless of their wealth and past experience with art or crypto, to:
Experience and collect art
Buy using the methods they are accustomed to, and
Understand what they are buying through clear
Artist and Collector Rights.
When we fail, we need to be the best at providing support and using that experience to improve steps 1‚Äì3 so customers never need to contact us again.‚Äù
So How Are We Doing?
Now that you know my perspective on Feral File, I wanted to ask for your time on this two-question survey. I simply want to know, how are we doing, and how can we be better?
Please find it here.
Our next show is scheduled for late January ‚Äî until then, we‚Äôll be quietly working on making Feral File better for you and our artists. We have an amazing lineup already scheduled for 2022, and I cannot wait to unveil it.
Casey Reas‚Äô Year-End Thoughts
I‚Äôd also like to share Feral File co-creator Casey Reas‚Äô reflections on this year:
We now have a modular set of parts that can be used for different kinds of exhibitions, to be mixed and matched for each show.
In October, we launched our first solo exhibition with
(008) Jan St Werner‚Äôs Polyarrythmia
, our first audio-only show.
With
(009) Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised
, we launched the ability to have auctions for 1/1 artworks and what we call "
group auctions
" for editions. We also experimented with an edition of 5,000 and it went well.
For
(010) -GRAPH
, we released our first software 1/1 exhibition, which is one piece of code that can generate many pre-minted 1/1 editions.
Early in 2022, we will be able to mint directly onto Tezos and Ethereum when that's the preference of the artists.
We released an
open call for curators
and all or most of the shows in the second half of 2022 will come from that, in order to bring in new artists and curators.
We're settling in to having two exhibitions each month, usually one group exhibition and one solo show.
The Ethereum "bridge
" has been launched for all past exhibitions‚Äîthis means burning on Bitmark and minting fresh on Ethereum with the provenance attached.
The FAQ has been updated to go over all of this in more depth:
https://feralfile.com/docs/faq.
New WalletConnect Support
Feral File now supports WalletConnect-compatible wallets such as MetaMask and Autonomy (that's from us! Find it on
Android
and
iOS
). Currently, you can use your wallet for decentralized login and 2FA. In the coming month, we will support deposits from your wallet and add other functionality. If you already have an account, access it on your
Account Page
. Otherwise, you can connect your wallet through a new account when you first sign in.
You can help us by sharing feedback and participating in user tests through our #features, #feedback, and #troubleshooting channels in the Platform section of our
Discord
.
Redemption for Refik Anadol, MoMA, -GRAPH
Since the past newsletter, we have reached out to collectors who qualify for additional benefits based on their participation in past shows.
You can refresh yourself on the details of those promotions here:
-GRAPH
(First owners - these emails will go out by Christmas weekend)
Refik Anadol‚Äôs Unsupervised
(Owners as of December 01)
Refik Anadol + MoMA:
First owners in Unsupervised - Machine Hallucinations (1/1, 1/100 artworks) receive 1 year MoMA membership
First owners in Data Universe (1/5000 artworks) receive a 1 day ticket to MoMA in New York City.
If you qualify for these promotions and did not receive an email to enroll in them, please reach out to me and I‚Äôll get this corrected.
Finally, the bridge for
For Your Eyes Only
has been released as well. See the option to migrate your edition to Ethereum when you view a specific artwork in your collection. We‚Äôre working on getting future bridges to launch at the same time as new exhibitions so there will no longer be a wait period.
Connect with Feral File
Feel free to send us feedback on how everything is working for you and how we can do better. In addition to
Discord
, we‚Äôre also on
Instagram
and
Twitter
.
As always, I appreciate your support. Message me anytime with your questions and thoughts.
‚Äî
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com
Be Your Own Gatekeeper with Bitmark. Awarded as World Economic Forum Technology Pioneer in 2020.

item.title: Today: See Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition in Los Angeles and on Feral File
item.description: Today: See Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition in Los Angeles and on Feral File
item.ns0:encoded:
Today: See Lu Yang‚Äôs First NFT Exhibition in Los Angeles and on Feral File
‚ÄúMaterial World Knight" from "The Great Adventure of Material World,‚Äù by Lu Yang, courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
View exhibition
See
Material Wonderland
, the first exhibition of NFT works by Chinese multimedia artist Lu Yang, presented online at Feral File and physically at Vellum LA from February 16-March 5, 2023 in Los Angeles. The exhibition is co-curated by Alice Scope, curator of Vellum LA, and Barry Threw, executive and artistic director of San Francisco-based cultural incubator Gray Area.
Feral File Exhibition Opening:
February 16, 2023
14:00 UTC (6am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 3pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later.
Exhibition Artworks ‚Äî Minted on Ethereum.
The exhibition features:
Material World Knight: Fighting Mode
1 Edition, $22,000
Material World Knight: Flying Mode
1 Edition, $22,000
Material World Knight: Fight the Universe
1 Edition, $22,000
Material World Knight: Giant Heart
1 Edition, $29,000
Material World Knight: Full Armed Fighting Mode
1 Edition, $22,000
Material World Knight: Head Forest
1 Edition, $29,000
Material World Knight: Vajra Power
1 Edition, $29,000
Material World Knight: Bardo Tunnel
1 Edition, $29,000
Material World Knight: Poster
88 Editions, $88 each
Join the Discord Conversation
Please join us for the opening reception at Vellum LA on Thursday, February 16th from 6‚Äì9pm PST. RSVP here:
https://bit.ly/luyangsoloshow
Physical exhibition at Vellum LA:
February 16-March 5
Vellum LA, 7673 Melrose Ave
Los Angeles, CA 90046
Gallery hours: Thursday‚ÄìSunday 1PM‚Äì6PM PST
About the show:
Material Wonderland includes eight new NFT works minted on Ethereum, which will be available to purchase through Feral File. Also shown at Vellum LA will be works available as non-NFT digital files: two full-length video works exploring the game world as well as a massive video triptych of ‚ÄúMaterial World Knight,‚Äù presenting genome-edited human beings, human-machine composites with powered exoskeleton, and robots on an immersive 600 sq ft panoramic LED wall for Vellum LA‚Äôs opening reception.
The NFT works in the series are video loops rendered from within Lu Yang‚Äôs 2019 computer game, ‚ÄúThe Great Adventure of Material World,‚Äù first shown at the 2018 Shanghai Biennale. The game is initially experienced as a standard Japanese anime role-playing computer game, where players embody the Material World Knight as they complete quests and battle enemies together with other characters drawn from the artist‚Äôs earlier works, while growing in power and abilities. However, over the course of ten stages players undergo multiple identity transformations as they move beyond tropes of popular manga culture to explore the control of identity liberated from the rigid confines of nationality, gender, and sexuality.
Material Wonderland is set in dialogue with the LACMA‚Äôs Coded: Art Enters the Computer Age, 1952‚Äì1982, open from February 12th, which explores how the rise of computer technology, together with its emergence in popular consciousness, impacted the making of art in the age of the mainframe.
About Lu Yang
Lu Yang (b.1984 China, based in Tokyo, Japan) creates fantastical, often painful and shocking images which represent a blend of religion, philosophy, neuroscience, psychology and modern technology, as well as references to real life forms and structures of natural and religious origin. Lu Yang‚Äôs output spans gaming engines, 3D-animated films, video game installations, holograms, motion capture performances, virtual reality and software manipulation. The artist also collaborates with acclaimed scientists, psychologists, performers, designers, experimental composers, music producers, robotics companies and pop stars.
Yang‚Äôs work has been shown in major exhibitions at the UCCA, Centre Pompidou, ICA London, Mus√©e d‚Äôart Contemporain Lyon, Momentum Berlin, MAXXI National Museum of XXI Arts, and the Asia Society NY Art Triennial. He has also participated in numerous Biennales such as: Shanghai Biennale, (2018 and 2012), Athens Biennale (2018), Liverpool Biennial (2016), Montreal International Digital Art Biennial (2016), and Fukuoka Asian Art Triennale (2014). Lu Yang was selected for the Chinese Pavilion at the 2015 Venice Biennale and has featured new work in The Milk of Dreams exhibition at the 2022 Venice Biennale.

Join us today¬†for the Truth collecting period and¬†conversation
Vitreous #9
by
Charlotte Dann
Get ready to collect¬†your favorite sets from Feral File's 39th exhibition,
Truth
!¬†Collecting begins in 3 hours at 16:00 UTC+0 (00:00 Shanghai, 18:00 Berlin, 13:00 S√£o Paulo, 09:00¬†Los Angeles).
Please also join us at 15:00 UTC+0 (an hour before collecting starts) for our
collecting day conversation
with the curator¬†and artists.
Truth
is¬†a group exhibition of some of the most exciting emerging artists in the space curated by
Adam Berninger
of generative art platform
TENDER
.
Collecting essentials
116¬†sets are available for collection from the¬†128-set series.
Each set is comprised of 7 artworks, one from each of the artists. Every artwork is unique.
The falling price auction will start at 2.0 ETH¬†and will fall to the base price of 0.2 ETH over 30 minutes.
Collecting ends tomorrow, Friday, October 20, at 15:59 UTC+0.¬†After the collecting period ends, all unsold sets will be removed from sale at Feral File.
Five collectors who acquire a set of
Truth
above the base price will be randomly chosen to receive a fine art print of one printable piece from their set!

October 19 | 15:00 UTC+0 |

With curator Adam Berninger and exhibiting artists, including Charlotte Dann, Presstube, Tyler Boswell, and Hal09999

Cuneiform #98
by
Presstube x bzor
In the words of Adam Berninger: ‚Äú
Truth
is a show about finding a common underlying philosophy behind the works of seven very different generative artists working in abstraction. Here, each artist has created a new series that explores the building blocks of our universe at different scales, ultimately accentuating the relative sameness in what they represent.‚Äù¬† Artists include
HAL09999
,
Charlotte Dann
,
David Seven
,
Presstube
x
bzor
,
Ella Hoeppner
,
Tyler Boswell
, and
Lisa Orth
.
Please visit our
Truth
YouTube playlist
for in-depth conversations with the curator and each of the artists about
Truth
.
VIEW PLAYLIST
Join artist HAL09999 as he discusses his generative artwork series "A broken symmetry ‚Äî the cat's parabola" with Feral File communications lead Elisabeth Sweet.

john gerrard‚Äôs

is officially open‚ú®
Happy summer solstice ‚ú®
Today marks the official beginning of john gerrard‚Äôs
ùò§ùò≥ùò∫ùò¥ùòµùò¢ùò≠ùò≠ùò™ùòØùò¶ ùò∏ùò∞ùò≥ùò¨

You can now watch in real time as the prismatic robot enacts its ‚Äúice-generation‚Äù algorithm to create unique archetypes‚Äîsuch as masks, solar crosses, mandalas, stars, trees, snowflakes, and mycelium.
Every time the robot completes an archetype, the performance is dropped into the Feral File gallery as a tokenized 3D WebGL art piece documenting the creation of that unique solar moment.

gerrard‚Äôs

enables collectors to experience their own moment from the robot‚Äôs performance as an immersive virtual world. Once you collect a work, here‚Äôs how to best experience it:
Drag within the scene to look around

‚ÄúM‚Äù exports the generated archetype as a 3D model for usage in 3D prints or virtual world building
