Unsupervised ‚Äî Data Universe ‚Äî MoMA Migration
Hi everyone,
If you're looking to migrate your Refik Feral File NFTs to be able to participate in the burn, do not use the Autonomy free migration feature. While we'd love for you to try Autonomy, the migrations won't be fast because we're optimizing for gas fees.
Thus, if you need the migrations done right away, please do a manual migration (1 at a time, you pay the fee). You can find this feature in the individual artwork page under your collection on Feral File.
If you have requested an Autonomy migration, and need to cancel it, you can do so by clicking ‚ÄúCancel Web3 Move‚Äù at the top of Feral File‚Äôs home page on the top of the header.

item.description: UPDATED OPENING ANNOUNCEMENT: +GRAPH curated by Casey Reas
item.ns0:encoded:
Now Open: +GRAPH curated by¬†Casey REAS
ANATOMY of a rabbit but bird
by
Iskra Velitchkova
, 2023.
+GRAPH
, an exhibition of software + plotter drawings curated by
Casey Reas
, is open now. Thirty sets of 6 unique artworks by
Licia He
,
Joanie Lemercier
,
Aleksandra Jovaniƒá
,
James Merrill
,
Iskra Velitchkova
, and
Julien Gachadoa
t
are exhibiting now on Feral File.
Visit the show
, read the curator statement
"Obscure Objects"
by Casey Reas, and explore the¬†artworks.
+GRAPH Exhibition Trailer with Aleksandra Jovaniƒá, James Merrill, Iskra Velitchkova, Licia He, Julien Gachadoat, Joanie Lemercier, and curator Casey Reas.
Schedule of Events
November 14
at 16:00 UTC+0
: Join Casey Reas and the artists for the Exhibition Walkthrough. Hosted on Zoom. RSVP
here
.
November 16 at 16:00 UTC+0:
24-hour highest-bid auction starts
November 17 at 15:59 UTC+0:
Auction ends
Breakpoint
by
James Merrill
, 2023.
Collecting¬†+GRAPH
Sets 1-8 are a2p (artist-to-peer) sets, reserved for the curator, the artists, and Feral File.
Sets 9-30 are available to collect.
The 24-hour highest-bid auction starts¬†November 16, 16:00 UTC+0.
The Reserve Set Price is 2.1 ETH.
Collectors will receive 1 plotter drawing ¬†per piece in their set at no extra charge.
These pieces will be plotted by the artist who created the artwork.
To receive your physical plotted works, be sure to include your shipping address in your Feral File profile.
Anyone can place a bid during the auction. All you have to do is connect your wallet to Feral File.
Bids placed in the last 5 minutes of the auction extend the auction window by another 10 minutes.
The auction ends after nobody places a bid within the extension window.
fine particles
by
Joanie Lemercier
, 2023.
A bit about +GRAPH
Two years ago, we opened
‚ÄìGRAPH
, what would become an iconic exhibition for Feral File‚Äôs first year of existence. Now two years later,¬†+GRAPH continues in the tradition of exhibiting generative art drawn with plotters. Like the original, this new exhibition explores the deep historical connection between coding and drawing and brings together artists who engage with both. Five artists ‚Äî
Licia He
,
Aleksandra Jovaniƒá
,
James Merrill
,
Iskra Velitchkova
, and
Julien Gachadoat
‚Äî from ‚ÄìGRAPH join us again, with the very exciting addition of
Joanie Lemercier
.
Each of the six artists in +GRAPH created generative software that is capable of making limitless new drawings, and has transformed 30 of these variations into physical works using a plotter machine. Every plotter drawing in this exhibition is a 1/1 artwork, meaning only one will ever be created. Along with each of these unique drawings, there are millions of other compositions that are embedded in the original code.
As part of our Exhibition Notes series, we are excited to share extended talks with the artists exhibiting in +GRAPH.
Watch the Exhibition Trailer
here
and the Exhibition Notes video
here
+ below.
Don‚Äôt forget to
register
for the Exhibition Walkthrough with the curator and artists on November 14 at 16:00 UTC+0, hosted on Zoom.
+GRAPH Exhibition Notes with Aleksandra Jovaniƒá, James Merrill, Iskra Velitchkova, Licia He, Julien Gachadoat, Joanie Lemercier, and curator Casey Reas.
Visit
+GRAPH
today!

item.title: Now Open: Feral File #017 ‚Äî WETWARE üîÆ
item.description: Now Open: Feral File #017 ‚Äî WETWARE üîÆ
item.ns0:encoded:
WETWARE: Cyberfeminism Index Benefit¬†Sale
Announcing a new exhibition of eleven cyberfeminist works, curated by Mindy Seu.
Exhibition Opening:
June 15, 2022
14:00 UTC+0 (7am Los Angeles, 11am S√£o Paulo, 4pm Berlin, 10pm Shanghai)
Collecting begins one hour later
Please join us on Twitter Spaces for a series of conversations with the artists beginning June 15 at 15:00 UTC.
Add to
Google Calendar
|
iCal
‚ÄúI.K.U.: Expand, an interface‚Äù by Shu Lea Cheang. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce WETWARE, featuring Cornelia Sollfrank, Danielle Brathwaite-Shirley, Linda Dement, Mary Maggic, Morehshin Allahyari, Prema Murthy, Shu Lea Cheang, Skawennati, and VNS Matrix, on the occasion of the upcoming publication CYBERFEMINISM INDEX.
Curator Mindy Seu on the exhibition:
‚ÄúCoined in the early 1990s by the British cultural theorist Sadie Plant and artist collective VNS Matrix, the word cyberfeminism takes on its prefix ‚Äúcyber‚Äù ‚Äî recast from Cybernetics, a 1948 book by Norbert Wiener, and ‚Äúcyberspace,‚Äù from William Gibson‚Äôs 1984 novel Neuromancer ‚Äî as a provocation. This cyberspace of the 1980s was stocked with and characterized by cyberbabes and fembots, a techno-utopian imaginary of the male gaze. ‚ÄúCyberfeminism‚Äù prompted women and marginalized communities to imagine how a reoriented cyberspace could look. By now, three decades after its origination, cyberfeminism has shifted from a loose artistic movement exploring the emancipatory potential of cyberspace towards a collective drive to provide software, hardware, and wetware education and to get marginalized groups online. Today, with questions of technology more and more clearly ‚Äòbound together with questions of ecology and the economy,‚Äô as noted by Cornelia Sollfrank, the term is self-reflexive: technology is not only the subject of cyberfeminism, but its means of transmission. It‚Äôs all about feedback.‚Äù
WETWARE showcases nine artists to celebrate and support their work and the upcoming publication CYBERFEMINISM INDEX, slated for an October 2022 release with Inventory Press.
Preview of the Artworks:
I.K.U.: Expand, an interface
(Pictured Above)
‚ÄúThis is not love. This is sex.‚Äù Shu Lea Cheang‚Äôs feature-length cyberpunk sci-fi porn film I.K.U. (2000) tells the story of the internet porn enterprise Genom Corporation that dispatches I.K.U. coders to collect ‚Äúorgasm data,‚Äù developing the ability to sell profitable and addictive on-demand orgasms. ‚ÄúI.K.U. is a phenomenon that wants to refuse definition ‚Ä¶. As much trans-genre as it is trans-gender, I.K.U. also wants to merge video and film into a fresh digital universe large-scale enough to overwhelm the viewer.‚Äù In conjunction with the film release, Cheang created an interactive website called ‚ÄúExpand, an interface‚Äù (2001) with stills from I.K.U. Using horizontally expanding and glitching panels to reveal I.K.U. coders such as Reiko or Tokyo Rose, ‚ÄúExpand, an interface‚Äù challenges the censorship in cinema versus online. The website is no longer online, and this screen recording was recaptured by Shu Lea Cheang in 2022, alongside stills from the film as well as the interface.
‚ÄúContested Zone‚Äù by VNS Matrix. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Contested Zone
Contested Zone (1993) by VNS Matrix is a digital image created for the 1993 project ALL NEW GEN. Part artwork, part computer game, ALL NEW GEN was released as a CD-ROM and distributed widely in Australia and internationally. The CD-ROM was also exhibited as the centerpiece of the ALL NEW GEN installation with lighboxes, soundworks, photography, sculptural elements, video and a Bonding Booth for pleasurable distraction.
Join the cyber warrior All New Gen and the renegade tribes of the Contested Zone to sabotage the databanks of Big Daddy Mainframe and launch the New World Disorder. Enter the Contested Zone, a labyrinth of bizarre and mysterious cyberworlds, where the future is now, and Big Daddy Mainframe is in control. Manipulating the minds of the online masses through his nasty neural nets, BDM is expanding his transplanetary empire and nothing will get in his way. But resistance is not futile! All New Gen, an omnipresent being (computer virus, bio simsystem, intelligent mist) is on a mission with the renegade tribes to sabotage the info core of the insidious data dictator. All New Gen is assisted on her mission by the DNA Sluts, a band of renegade Sheroes; along with ferals, data deviants, cortex crones and code warriors.
‚ÄúSocial Capital Fights‚Äù by Danielle Brathwaite-Shirley. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Social Capital Fights
In a time of cancel culture and click bait, Danielle Brathwaite-Shirley wants us to be able to argue again. This type of conflict is a necessary part of communication, to be able to voice our opinions, disagree, and still have empathy for one another. ‚ÄúSocial Capital Fights‚Äù (2022) is a provocation for raucous disagreements and against the erasure of similitude. The music video speaks of trans people who are in support of having difficult conversations in our increasingly public, online environments, rather than narrowing our social bubbles even more. ‚ÄúDemon babies‚Äù populate the music video as mannequin heads covered in a balaclava made of hair, hair tools, and hair accessories, as a way to grapple with Brathwaite-Shirley‚Äôs own hair loss; the demons look after her. Brathwaite-Shirley created this work specifically for this exhibition.

item.title: We‚Äôre upgrading to a true native Web3 Experience
item.description: We‚Äôre upgrading to a true native Web3 Experience
item.ns0:encoded:
Hi,
Now that Ethereum has successfully migrated to proof of stake, Feral File will complete two major changes by the end of October:
Native Web3 Wallet Experience:
Feral File will work like any other Web3 experience. Moving forward, the curator and artist for each exhibition will select the chain they want to mint on. You will be able to sign into Feral File with your preferred Tezos or Ethereum wallet. You can then pay crypto directly (no more deposits or conversion to USDC) and hold the artwork with your own wallet. And yes, credit card payments will still be supported.
Feral File will have two types of accounts, one in which Feral File holds your assets as it does today (custodial), and one in which you hold them (native web3 / self-custody) in your own wallet.
Our recommendation is to hold assets in your own wallet.
Crypto wallets are usually chain-specific; if you would like to collect across all of Feral File‚Äôs exhibitions without needing multiple accounts and wallets, we would love for you to try
our Autonomy digital art wallet
.
Bitmark Chain NFT Migration:
We will bridge all Feral File artworks that are still on the Bitmark chain to either Tezos or Ethereum, depending on artist preference. The Bitmark chain will become an archive-only registry.
As I send this email, we have launched native web3 support for Tezos wallets. Ethereum support will follow in a few weeks. In October, we will replace Feral File‚Äôs secondary market with third party secondary market listings (objkt, OpenSea). Your listings on Feral File will no longer function.
How to transfer your Feral File artworks and account balance to your web3 wallet
You can migrate any edition minted on Bitmark to your Ethereum wallet now. If you do nothing by November 15, your Bitmark NFTs will be automatically migrated to Tezos or Ethereum depending on the preference of the artist who created that artwork. These NFTs will be under the control of your existing Fearl File (custody) account. You can then transfer them from Feral File into your own crypto wallet.
We view blockchain preference as a personal decision. Both Ethereum and Tezos are great public blockchains with vibrant communities and their own unique values. Our promise is to abstract away the technical details to provide a single, consistent experience for your artwork regardless of the underlying chain.
If you have any questions, feel free to reply to me here or on Discord in
our Troubleshooting channel
.
Thanks for your continued support,
Michael Nguy·ªÖn
Head of Operations, Bitmark
michael@bitmark.com

item.title: ‚ÄúA P1√ó3L is vibrant and alive.‚Äù Opening September 23rd.
item.description: ‚ÄúA P1√ó3L is vibrant and alive.‚Äù Opening September 23rd.
item.ns0:encoded:
P1√ó3L
Announcing a new exhibition of digital artworks that foreground the materiality of their medium, curated by Casey Reas.
Exhibition Opening:
September 23, 2021
14:00 UTC+0 (10pm Shanghai, 4pm Berlin, 11am S√£o Paulo, 7am Los Angeles)
Collecting begins one hour later
4 ORBS by Nicolas Sassoon. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
Feral File
and
Bitmark
are pleased to announce the platform‚Äôs sixth exhibition, which will feature digital and generative artworks by a group of five international artists who have been committed to these fields for over a decade. Encompassing a variety of formats, each work will be made available to collectors as editioned NFTs.
Participating artists:
Nicolas Sassoon (Vancouver, CA)
Francoise Gamma (Barcelona, ES)

Curator Casey Reas on P1√ó3L:
‚ÄúA P1√ó3L is the atomic unit of digital and generative art. It can‚Äôt be quantified. A P1√ó3L is vibrant and alive. Artists choreograph P1√ó3Ls and P1√ó3Ls possess artists. P1√ó3Ls are ideas about image-making that transcend the technology they flow through‚Ä¶. This remarkable group of artists has each pushed the boundaries of the fields of digital and generative art in their own ways. As a counterpoint to the stream of technology being developed to make itself invisible, these artists foreground the materiality of their medium.
Online spaces for digital and generative art are at the highest energy I‚Äôve seen in over two decades, and things have shifted even since we started organizing this exhibition in June. I‚Äôm thrilled to present this new work from this group of artists who committed to digital and generative art over a decade ago and remain vibrant creators. Their past work has stood the tests of time and their current work pushes forward.‚Äù
Preview of Select Artworks:
Nicolas Sassoon ‚Äî 4 ORBS
(Pictured Above)
Nicolas Sassoon‚Äôs ‚Äú4 ORBS‚Äù is a new digital moir√© animation that is part of a series of animated optical patterns created from geometric shapes and motifs. Its geometry is informed by optical and kinetic art of the 1960s and 1970s, created by artists like Jes√∫s Rafael Soto and Victor Vasarely. The series is also influenced by science fiction book covers from the collection ‚ÄúAilleurs et Demain‚Äù (Elsewhere and Tomorrow) published in France in 1969. ‚Äú4 ORBS‚Äù is released along with its companion work ‚Äú3 ORBS.‚Äù
Raquel Meyers ‚Äî Picnic 001
Picnic 001 by Raquel Meyers. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In describing her ‚ÄúPicnic 001,‚Äù Raquel Meyers writes, ‚ÄúWe keep going backwards no matter what,‚Äù and she calls it a ‚Äúdecoration for high-resolution screens. A roadside picnic for civil care.‚Äù Raquel lives in the Basque Country in Spain, and within this artwork she brings together the industrial heritage of that area, the new dress code for women in Afghanistan, and the mediation of the smartphone. Raquel created the frames of this GIF animation with techniques she developed over years of engaging with vintage computer technologies, specifically Teletext systems and Commodore 64 computers.
p1xelfool ‚Äî k.a9
k.a9 by p1xelfool. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
In the long tradition of kinetic art and experimental film and video, p1xelfool‚Äôs works contain a world within themselves. We might be looking at the inside of an atom or the birth of a simulated universe ‚Äî the work leaves room for broad interpretation. There‚Äôs enough within them to trigger recognition and association, but the lack of resolution creates space for mystery. In ‚Äúk.a9‚Äù specifically, we experience two objects rotating around one another in an endless dance of forces in balance. This software is one of a pair of p1xelfool‚Äôs first ever generative, live-code releases. We‚Äôre thrilled to feature this new direction on Feral File.

Cut-up language with erratic meaning goes hand-in-hand with the animations of Francoise Gamma. ‚ÄúHatless‚Äù was created through a process of experimentation where the body, movement, transformation, and dimension were simultaneously pushed into new directions within the same sequence of drawings. The result is a GIF loop that contrasts flatness and 3D, is glitched and smooth, is anatomically proportional and distorted. According to Francoise, this GIF animation was made specifically to circulate on the web and to exist within that milieu.
ertdfgcvb ‚Äî POST 1
POST 1 by ertdfgcvb. Image courtesy of the artist and Feral File.
‚ÄúPOST 1‚Äù is a grid of fixed-width alphanumeric and graphic symbols. These elements create a soft architecture that supports evolving geometric compositions that transition from one configuration to another. The focus is on the choreography of the image and how it changes through time. He uses an older pixel font, but as he puts it, the ‚Äúpieces are cold,‚Äù without a nostalgic warmth for retro-computing aesthetics.
